meanings.definition: a public exam in a particular subject that was taken in the past in British schools by some children aged 15 or 16, or the qualification from this:
examples: She's got ten O levels.
O levels were replaced by GCSEs in 1988.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for
        
         Organization and Methods
used after a number from one to twelve to say the time when it is exactly that hour:
examples: It's two o'clock.
He called me at four o'clock in the morning.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a time of day when you usually do or have a particular thing:
examples: For many mums, the kids' bedtime is chocolate o'clock.
It's wine o'clock!

meanings.definition: used after a number from one to twelve to state the time:
examples: She called at nine o’clock this morning.

meanings.definition: over:
examples: O'er land and sea they sped.

meanings.definition: the 15th letter of the English alphabet
used in speech to mean zero:
examples: My phone number is three, one, o, five, one, double o (= 3105100).
The year 1705 is usually pronounced seventeen o five.

meanings.definition: used when talking to someone or something, or expressing something in an emotional or formal way:
examples: O Zeus! Hear my prayer.

meanings.definition: used in writing to represent "of" when the letter f is not pronounced:
examples: a bottle o' beer

meanings.definition: used as part of many last names:
examples: Jeanne O'Connor

meanings.definition: the 15th letter of the English alphabet
(spelled the way it is often spoken) zero
used when addressing someone or something, or when expressing strong emotion:
examples: "O! Canada" is the Canadian national anthem.

meanings.definition: written abbreviation for or near(est) offer: used in advertisements for things that people are trying to sell to show that they will accept slightly less money than the price they are asking for:
examples: Ladies' bike - excellent condition. £80 o.n.o.

meanings.definition: written abbreviation for or nearest offer: used in advertisements for used goods or other products that someone is selling to say that they will accept slightly less than the price stated:
examples: Child's bike for sale - £100 ono.

meanings.definition: written abbreviation for on or before: used before a date in a document, invoice, etc. to show that the date shown is the last acceptable date for something to be paid or done:
examples: Investments must be received o/b April 5.

meanings.definition:
written abbreviation for 
        
         overdraft
a stupid, rude, or awkward person, especially a man:
examples: a drunken/insensitive/stupid oaf
You clumsy oaf! You broke it!

meanings.definition: a big, stupid, awkward person, esp. a man
stupid, rude, or awkward:
examples: oafish behaviour
an oafish young man

meanings.definition: in a stupid, rude, or awkward way:
examples: I always end up behaving oafishly when I'm near her, unable to just be myself.
The group of teenagers oafishly pushed their way to the front of the queue.

meanings.definition: the quality of being stupid, rude, or awkward:
examples: He did not defend her against the oafishness of their host.
The film manages throughout to make his oafishness endearing.

meanings.definition: a large tree that is common in northern parts of the world, or the hard wood of this tree:
examples: a mighty oak
The timbers of those old sailing ships were mostly oak.
an oak table/cupboard

meanings.definition: a large tree common in northern countries, or the hard wood of this tree:
examples: The floors in their home are made from oak.

meanings.definition: made of oak wood:
examples: The warriors carried huge oaken shields.

meanings.definition: thin fibres covered in a sticky substance and used for filling gaps. Oakum was traditionally made from old ropes and used to fill the gaps between the long, flat pieces of wood on a ship's deck (= floor):
examples: We packed the cracks with oakum.
Then she saw a group of prisoners sitting in a dark cellar picking oakum (= separating the fibres from old ropes).

meanings.definition: Oaky wine has a slight flavour of wood, especially because it has been left to develop in a container made of oak:
examples: a deliciously oaky red wine

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for
        
         old age pensioner UK :
examples: OAPs get cheaper bus and train tickets.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for
        
         old age pensioner
a long pole with a wide, flat part at one end, used for rowing a boat:
examples: a pair of oars
She dipped her oars into the water and pulled.

meanings.definition: a long pole with a wide, flat part at one end which is used to row a boat (= move it through water)
a U-shaped device or hole on each side of a rowing boat in which the oars (= poles with flat ends used to move a boat) are held
a person who rows a boat, especially in competitions
a woman who rows a boat

abbreviation for 
        
         Organization of American States  : a group of countries in North, South, and Central America that help and support each other:
examples: Chávez threatened to leave the OAS if the court ruled against him.
Foreign ministers will meet on March 17 at the OAS headquarters in Washington.
The president met with OAS Secretary General José Miguel Insulza.

meanings.definition:
plural of 
        
         oasis
a place in a desert where there is water and therefore plants and trees and sometimes a village or town
a calm, pleasant place in the middle of somewhere busy and unpleasant:
examples: Her office was an oasis of peace and sanity amid the surrounding chaos.

meanings.definition: an area in a desert where there is water and trees can grow
made of or from oats:
examples: oat crackers
oat bran/cereal

meanings.definition: any of several kinds of grass that look like oats (= a type of grain):
examples: The cows are fed on clover, trefoil, and oat grass.
The tall oat grass swayed in front of the benches.

meanings.definition: a white liquid made from water and oats (= a type of grain), used instead of milk from a cow, goat, or sheep :
examples: I have soy or oat milk with my coffee.
It's not too grey and murky like some oat milks.

meanings.definition: a thin savoury (= not sweet) biscuit made from oats, often made in Scotland
a western (= a film based on stories about life in the west of the US in the past):
examples: This oater is the only movie directed by Burt Lancaster.
Forty Guns is a 1957 oater about an infamous lawman who takes on a female outlaw and her private army of 40 gunmen.

meanings.definition: a promise, especially that you will tell the truth in a law court:
examples: Medieval knights took an oath of allegiance/loyalty to their lord.
The witness placed her hand on the Bible and took the oath (= promised to tell the truth).

meanings.definition: an offensive word, especially one that uses a name for God:
examples: muttering/mouthing oaths

meanings.definition: a serious promise that you will tell the truth or that you will do what you have said:
examples: Presidents take an oath to uphold the Constitution.

meanings.definition: an offensive word, esp. one that uses a name for God
an official promise, especially when you promise to tell the truth in court:
examples: The witness took the oath.
A psychologist cannot be compelled to attend a disciplinary hearing or to swear on oath.

meanings.definition: a type of flour made from oats:
examples: oatmeal bread

meanings.definition: a thick, soft food made from oats boiled in milk or water, eaten hot for breakfast
crushed oats, esp. cooked as a breakfast food
a plant that is a type of grass, or its grain used in baking and cooking or to feed animals:
examples: a field of oats
rolled oats (= oats that have been pressed flat)
These biscuits contain oats.
porridge oats

meanings.definition: a tall plant grown for its grain, or the grain from this plant used for food

informal for
        
         obstetrician specialized

abbreviation for
        
         organizational behaviour
abbreviation for obstetrician-gynecologist: a doctor who specializes in pregnancy, birth, and diseases affecting women's reproductive organs
abbreviation for obstetrics and gynecology (= a part of medicine that manages pregnancy, birth, and a woman's ability to reproduce)
a name given to the Affordable Care Act, a law introduced by President Obama in 2010 to make it easier for people in the US to get insurance for medical treatment
in a piece of music, a necessary part that is played by a single instrument to accompany (= play with) a singer:
examples: Each singer offered a rendition with a lovely flute obbligato.
One nice touch is the series of clarinet obligatos that wind through the arias.

meanings.definition: necessary: used in written music to show that a part must be played:
examples: The obbligato bassoon lends the aria a sense of the unknown.
May I add a further word of praise for the proficient obbligato players?
It's a shame that the two best obligato violin parts are not included in the performance.

meanings.definition: the quality of being very determined to act in a particular way despite what anyone else says:
examples: The failure of the peace talks was caused by the obduracy of both leaders.
Her obduracy on the subject was driving away her friends and supporters.

meanings.definition: the quality of refusing to change your mind, or of being difficult to deal with or change:
examples: The obduracy of the police in failing to take the complaint seriously is deeply troubling.
Analysts have been surprised by the obduracy of the price of oil.

meanings.definition: extremely determined to act in a particular way and not to change despite what anyone else says:
examples: The president remains obdurate on immigration.

meanings.definition: used to describe a person who refuses to change their mind, or someone or something that is difficult to deal with or change:
examples: Union leaders remain obdurate that working conditions and pay improve.
Several obdurate facts/differences remain, preventing a compromise solution.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows that someone is extremely determined to act in particular way and not to change despite what anyone else says:
examples: The obdurately intransigent attitudes of the two leaders made it hard to see how an agreement could ever be reached.
The President was obdurately resistant to any suggestion of tax cuts.
She just folded her arms and glared back at me, obdurately.

meanings.definition: in a way that is difficult to deal with or change:
examples: The price of gas remained obdurately above the $3 mark.

meanings.definition: the fact that people or animals do what they are told to do:
examples: He demands unquestioning obedience from his soldiers.

meanings.definition: doing, or willing to do, what you have been told to do by someone in authority:
examples: Students are expected to be quiet and obedient in the classroom.
an obedient dog

meanings.definition: doing or willing to do what you have been asked or ordered to do by someone in authority:
examples: an obedient child

meanings.definition: in a way that does, or shows that you are willing to do, what you have been told to do by someone in authority:
examples: The dog trotted obediently to his master.
She nodded obediently as I gave my instructions.

meanings.definition: the fact of obeying or respecting someone, or something you do that expresses this:
examples: One by one the noblemen made their obeisances (= bent at the waist) to the queen.

meanings.definition: a tall stone column with four sloping sides and a pointed top, made in honour of an important person or event:
examples: His burial place was marked by a white marble obelisk.
The pointed tip of the obelisk represents the ground on which the sun god stood to create the universe.

meanings.definition: the symbol †, usually used to show a footnote (= a note at the bottom of a page of text) if the asterisk symbol * has already been used:
examples: The obelisk is used as a reference to the bottom of the page.
The history of the asterisk is linked to that of the obelisk.

meanings.definition: the symbol − or ÷, used in ancient documents to show that part of the text may not be correct or is not necessary:
examples: Biblical names are marked with a warning obelus.
The obeli indicate a problem with the text.

meanings.definition: the symbol †, usually used to show a footnote (= a note at the bottom of a page of text) if the asterisk symbol * has already been used:
examples: The obelus is a symbol represented by a small dagger.

meanings.definition: extremely fat in a way that is dangerous for health:
examples: She was not just overweight; she was clinically obese.

meanings.definition: extremely fat
the fact of being extremely fat, in a way that is dangerous for health:
examples: The National Institute of Health is discussing ways of tackling the problem of childhood obesity.
A diet that is high in fat and sugar can lead to obesity.

meanings.definition: to act according to what you have been asked or ordered to do by someone in authority, or to behave according to a rule, law, or instruction:
examples: The soldiers refused to obey (orders).
to obey the rules of international law

meanings.definition: to behave according to a scientific principle:
examples: Falling objects obey the law of gravity.

meanings.definition: If your body or part of your body does not obey you, it does not work in the way it should:
examples: She was so tired her legs just wouldn't obey her any longer.

meanings.definition: to do what you are told or expected to do according to someone in authority or a rule or law:
examples: The toddler refused to obey.
Residents are expected to obey the house rules.

meanings.definition: to make something less clear and harder to understand, especially intentionally:
examples: She was criticized for using arguments that obfuscated the main issue.
Companies deliberately obfuscate figures in complicated annual reports.
Instead of concealing or obfuscating, the doctors involved admitted their fault and launched an investigation.

meanings.definition: to put false or confusing information on the internet, especially using special software, in order to stop search engines being able to collect information about you:
examples: You can confuse web trackers by obfuscating your movements online.
The browser extension is designed to obfuscate browsing data and protect users from tracking by advertising networks.

meanings.definition: to create computer code (= instructions used to program computers) that is difficult for humans to understand, in order to reduce the code size and hide it from other people:
examples: Much source code encryption software obfuscates the code.
Deliberately obfuscated source code is not allowed.

present participle of 
        
         obfuscate

examples: She was criticized for using arguments that obfuscated the main issue.
Companies deliberately obfuscate figures in complicated annual reports.

meanings.definition: to put false or confusing information on the internet, especially using special software, in order to stop search engines being able to collect information about you:
examples: You can confuse web trackers by obfuscating your movements online.

examples: Much source code encryption software obfuscates the code.
Deliberately obfuscated source code is not allowed.

meanings.definition: the act of making something less clear and less easy to understand, especially intentionally, or an instance of this:
examples: They accused the White House of obstruction and obfuscation.
She criticized the company's deliberate obfuscation of its finances.
Myths, obfuscations, and lies have long enshrouded the disgraced leader.

meanings.definition: the act of putting false or confusing information on the internet, especially using special software, in order to stop search engines being able to collect information about you:
examples: Obfuscation gets you used to the idea that you do not have to provide real information about yourself.
Obfuscation does not actually curtail online tracking.

meanings.definition: the act of creating computer code (= instructions used to program computers) that is difficult for humans to understand, in order to reduce the code size and hide it from other people:
examples: Obfuscation is a technique by which code is transformed into a form that is semantically the same as the original program, but is difficult to extract meaning from.
Obfuscation will drastically reduce the size of the file, so data transfers between server and client will be fast.

meanings.definition: a report, especially in a newspaper, that gives the news of someone's death and details about their life
a notice, esp. in a newspaper, of a person’s death, usually with details about his or her life
a thing that you can see or touch but that is not usually a living animal, plant, or person:
examples: a solid/material/physical object
a collection of precious objects
Several people reported seeing a strange object in the sky.

meanings.definition: a noun or noun phrase that is affected by the action of a verb or that follows a preposition:
examples: In the sentence "I like ice cream", "ice cream" is the object of the verb "like".

meanings.definition: a reason for doing something, or the result you wish to achieve by doing it:
examples: The object of their expedition was to discover the source of the River Nile.

meanings.definition: someone or something that causes particular feelings in or actions by others:
examples: He became an object of ridicule among the other workers.

meanings.definition: to feel or express opposition to or dislike of something or someone:
examples: Would anyone object if we started the meeting now?
He objects to the label "magician".
No one objected when the boss said it was time to go home.

meanings.definition: a thing that can be seen, held, or touched, usually not a living thing:
examples: Distant objects look blurry to me.

meanings.definition: a purpose or aim of some effort or activity:
examples: The object of the game of chess is to checkmate your opponent.

meanings.definition: the particular person or thing to which others direct thoughts, feelings, or actions:
examples: The court has been the object of recent criticism.

meanings.definition: a noun, pronoun, or noun phrase that represents the person or thing toward which the action of a verb is directed or to which a preposition relates:
examples: In the sentence, "Give the book to me," "book" is the direct object of the verb "give," and "me" is the indirect object.

meanings.definition: to feel or express opposition, dislike, or disapproval:
examples: I don’t think anyone will object to leaving early.
She objected that the price was too high.

meanings.definition: a thing that you can see and hold:
examples: He seeks ingenious design solutions for everyday objects such as telephones and cutlery.

meanings.definition: something you are planning to do or the result you hope to achieve:
examples: Their object is to produce something that will be able to compete with the market leader.
The object of the exercise is to improve your interpersonal skills.

meanings.definition: a piece of data and the instructions that a computer or a computer specialist needs to work with the data and use it with other software to build programs
to say that you disagree with something or disapprove of it:
examples: His attorneys asked for more time to file pleadings and U.S. prosecutors did not object.
If the City does not like the impact on borrowing costs, it can hardly object to the tax reforms.
Several members of the board strongly objected to the proposed merger.
Some unions object that company profit-sharing schemes merely hold down basic pay.

meanings.definition: a standard computer language into which other less common languages are changed when writing programs
an action or story that teaches you how or how not to act, or that clearly shows the facts of a situation, usually a bad one:
examples: The disaster was an object lesson in how not to run a ship.

meanings.definition: in computing, refers to something based on groups of information and their effects on each other, rather than on a series of instructions:
examples: C++ is a common object-oriented programming language.

meanings.definition: object-oriented language, programming, technology, etc. is based on groups of information or data and the way they work with each other, rather than working on its own:
examples: We write most of our own applications using object-oriented software.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         object
to feel or express opposition to or dislike of something or someone:
examples: Would anyone object if we started the meeting now?
He objects to the label "magician".
No one objected when the boss said it was time to go home.

meanings.definition: treating people like tools or toys, as if they had no feelings, opinions, or rights of their own:
examples: Pornography is often an example of the objectification of women by men.

meanings.definition: to treat a person like a tool or toy, as if they had no feelings, opinions, or rights of their own:
examples: She denied that the magazine objectified women.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         object
to feel or express opposition to or dislike of something or someone:
examples: Would anyone object if we started the meeting now?
He objects to the label "magician".
No one objected when the boss said it was time to go home.

meanings.definition: the act of expressing or feeling opposition to or dislike of something or someone:
examples: Her objection to/against the plan is based on incorrect facts.
A couple of people raised/voiced objections to the proposal.
I have no objection except that it may cost more than expected.

meanings.definition: a feeling or expression of opposition, dislike, or disapproval:
examples: A couple of people raised/voiced objections to the plan.
Does anyone have any objections?

meanings.definition: an expression or feeling that shows that you disapprove of something or disagree with it:
examples: The two companies will learn this week whether there are still objections to the merger deal.
A large number of people raised objections to the proposed plan.
People's main objection was that it had been priced too high.
We have no objection to a slight postponement.

meanings.definition: used to describe people or things that you dislike or oppose because they are so unpleasant or wrong:
examples: an objectionable smell
I found the violence in that film really objectionable.

meanings.definition: causing offense or opposition:
examples: objectionable behavior

meanings.definition: in a way that is unpleasant or wrong:
examples: If you continue to behave so objectionably, I'm going to go home.
It only took a couple of drinks for him to become objectionably drunk.

meanings.definition: something that you plan to do or achieve:
examples: Her main/prime objective now is simply to stay in power.
Can the sales team achieve/meet its financial objectives?

meanings.definition: based on real facts and not influenced by personal beliefs or feelings:
examples: an objective and impartial report
I can't really be objective when I'm judging my daughter's work.

meanings.definition: not influenced by personal beliefs or feelings; fair or real:
examples: an objective opinion

meanings.definition: having or relating to the case (= form) of a noun, pronoun, or adjective used to show that a word is the object of a verb
something that you aim to do or achieve:
examples: long-term objectives
His main objective this semester is to improve his grades.

meanings.definition: something that you are planning to do or achieve:
examples: Management must set clear objectives that everyone subscribes to.
Investing globally enhances the fund's ability to meet its primary objective.
The primary investment objective of the account is to maximize after-tax returns.
The company failed to meet its short-term objective of expanding into Asia.
business/company/performance objectives
financial/investment/strategic objectives

meanings.definition: not influenced by personal feelings or beliefs:
examples: One of the biggest problems in a celebrity case is being able to select jurors who can be objective about it.
Analysts produced objective evidence that the world was heading for a global recession.
an objective account/assessment/report

meanings.definition: in European employment law, a legal reason that allows an employer to treat someone in a different way to other employees, especially relating to reasons of age, physical ability, etc.
in a way that is based on facts and not influenced by personal beliefs or feelings:
examples: Judges must weigh the evidence logically and objectively.
Try to look at the situation objectively.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not influenced by personal beliefs or feelings; fairly:
examples: Jurors must weigh the evidence in the case objectively.

meanings.definition: in a fair way that is not influenced by personal feelings or beliefs:
examples: All the evidence will need to be considered objectively.

meanings.definition: the fact of being based on facts and not influenced by personal beliefs or feelings:
examples: Surely true objectivity in a critic is impossible?
We should not lose our objectivity as we respond to the attack.

meanings.definition: the state or quality of being objective and fair:
examples: The newspaper has a reputation for objectivity and fairness.

meanings.definition: the quality of being able to make a decision or judgment in a fair way that is not influenced by personal feelings or beliefs:
examples: He questioned his manager's objectivity.
An auditor must always give the appearance of objectivity and impartiality.

meanings.definition: someone who objects to something or someone:
examples: 200 objectors were present at the inquiry.
a conscientious objector

meanings.definition: a person who disagrees with or disapproves of something, and tries to prevent it or refuses to take part in it:
examples: Environmentalists are calling for a better system for objectors to respond to new developments.

meanings.definition: a part of a company's memorandum of association (= a legal document describing a new company) that states the aims of the company and the powers of the company directors:
examples: The amendment of any provision in the objects clause requires our prior written consent.

meanings.definition: an object, usually a small object, considered to have some worth or value as art

plural of 
        
         objet d'art

abbreviation for 
        
         ocean bill of lading
something that is offered as a religious sacrifice:
examples: Incense was used for purification and as an oblation to ancestors.

meanings.definition: the giving of bread and wine to God in the Christian ceremony of the Eucharist
to force someone to do something, or to make it necessary for someone to do something:
examples: The law obligates financial institutions to make monthly reports on large transactions.
The contract obligated them to pay hundreds of pounds monthly to a private recruiting firm.
Our financial advice service is free, impartial, and does not obligate you in any way.

meanings.definition: needing to do something or to have particular conditions in order to live:
examples: Horses are obligate nasal breathers during exercise.
As obligate parasites, viruses are dependent on their hosts.

meanings.definition: certain to have something, such as a gene (= a part of the DNA in a cell that controls the physical development, behaviour, etc. of an individual plant or animal and is passed on from its parents):
examples: She is an obligate carrier, absolutely certain to carry the gene.

meanings.definition: to make someone feel morally or legally forced to do something:
examples: I’m in favor of obligating welfare recipients to do more.

meanings.definition: to force someone to do something:
examples: The company was obligated to make compensation for damages.
The law doesn't obligate districts to enroll older students.
Employers are legally obligated to inform employees about benefits.

meanings.definition: to officially state that money will be used to pay for something:
examples: The centre is authorized to obligate funds.
The agency has obligated $388 million for specific recovery projects in the area.

meanings.definition: feeling that you owe someone something because you are grateful for what they have done for you:
examples: She felt obligated to him for all the help he had given her with her career.

meanings.definition: the fact that you are obliged to do something:
examples: If you have not signed a contract, you are under no obligation to (= it is not necessary to) pay them any money.
You have a legal obligation to (= the law says you must) ensure your child receives an education.

meanings.definition: something that you must do:
examples: I don't have time to do his work for him - I have too many obligations as it is.

meanings.definition: something that a person feels morally or legally forced to do:
examples: The government has an obligation to assist relief efforts.
You can just look – you’re under no obligation to buy.

meanings.definition: a legal or moral duty to do something:
examples: a legal/moral obligation
There is a legal obligation to publish accounts.
We have an obligation to generate value for our shareholders.
Under bankruptcy law, the company has an obligation to creditors.
You are under no obligation to accept damaged goods.

meanings.definition: in a way that means that something must be done because of a rule or law:
examples: This kind of information is obligatorily recorded and kept in the public records for at least 50 years.
In standard English, a plural verb must obligatorily have a plural subject.

meanings.definition: in a way that is expected because it usually happens:
examples: These murder mystery TV series always feature an obligatorily grumpy detective.
The politicians issued an obligatorily polite statement about the news, but behind the scenes they were extremely annoyed.

meanings.definition: If something is obligatory, you must do it because of a rule or law, etc.:
examples: The medical examination before you start work is obligatory.
The statute made it obligatory for all healthy males between 14 and 60 to work.

meanings.definition: expected because it usually happens:
examples: Several Secret Service agents surrounded the President, all wearing the obligatory raincoat and hat.

meanings.definition: (of an action) expected, esp. because it is what most people do:
examples: Everybody who goes to England makes the obligatory trip to Stonehenge.

meanings.definition: if something is obligatory, you must do it because of a rule or law:
examples: It is obligatory for members in practice to hold insurance.
The obligatory retirement age is 65.

meanings.definition: to force someone to do something, or to make it necessary for someone to do something:
examples: The law obliges companies to pay decent wages to their employees.
The law does not obligate sellers to accept the highest offer.

meanings.definition: to please or help someone, especially by doing something they have asked you to do:
examples: We only went to the party to oblige some old friends who asked us to be there.
We needed a guide and he was only too happy to oblige.

meanings.definition: to force or make it expected for someone to do something:
examples: Circumstances obliged him to leave town.

meanings.definition: to please or help someone, esp. by doing something the person has asked you to do:
examples: We needed a guide and he was only too happy to oblige.

meanings.definition: to force someone to do something, or to make it necessary for someone to do something:
examples: Employers are obliged to pay employees sick pay.
Sellers are not legally obliged to accept the highest offer.
Companies are obliged by law to carry out regular safety checks.
The law obliges full disclosure of political contributions.

meanings.definition: to please or help someone, especially by doing something they have asked you to do:
examples: He went to the conference to oblige his boss.
We needed some help with our accounts and she was only too happy to oblige.

meanings.definition: to help someone by giving them something:
examples: Could you oblige me with a pen and a piece of paper, please?

meanings.definition: the person or group who must receive something such as a payment or benefit from someone, according to a law or legal agreement:
examples: In child support matters, the obligee or custodial parent is the parent to whom payment should be directed.

meanings.definition: willing or eager to help:
examples: He found an obliging doctor who gave him the drugs he needed.

meanings.definition: willing or eager to help:
examples: An obliging neighbor helped her shovel the snow.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows that you are willing or eager to help:
examples: Her dad obligingly drove her to the party.
He laughed obligingly at nearly all my jokes.

meanings.definition: a person or group who must give something such as a payment or benefit to someone, according to a law or legal agreement:
examples: On a bail bond, the accused and the sureties are the obligors, and the government is the obligee.

meanings.definition: having a sloping direction, angle, or position:
examples: Through the window came the last few oblique rays of evening sunshine.
He gave her an oblique glance.

meanings.definition: (of an angle) either more or less than 90°
Oblique remarks are not direct, so that the real meaning is not immediately clear:
examples: She made several oblique references to the current financial situation.

meanings.definition: one of the muscles that lies in a sloping direction from the middle of the body :

meanings.definition: not clear or direct:

meanings.definition: having a sloping direction, angle, or position:

meanings.definition: said in a way that is not direct, so that the real meaning is not immediately clear:

to remove all signs of something, either by destroying it or by covering it so that it cannot be seen:
examples: The missile strike was devastating - the target was totally obliterated.
All of a sudden the view was obliterated by the fog.

meanings.definition: to make an idea or feeling disappear completely:
examples: Maybe she gets drunk to obliterate painful memories.

meanings.definition: to remove all signs of something; destroy:
examples: The hurricane virtually obliterated this small coastal town.

meanings.definition: An obliterative disease or treatment is one in which a part of the body becomes blocked, has disappeared, or is removed:
examples: Obliterative bronchiolitis is a rare disease in which the airways of the lungs become blocked.
They performed obliterative surgery on the patient.

meanings.definition: the state of being completely forgotten:
examples: He was another minor poet who was consigned to oblivion.
These toys will be around for a year or two, then fade/slide/sink into oblivion.

meanings.definition: the state of being completely destroyed:
examples: The planes bombed the city into oblivion.

meanings.definition: the state of being unconscious:
examples: He sought oblivion in a bottle of whisky.

meanings.definition: the state of being unconscious or lacking awareness of what is happening around you
the state of being completely forgotten by the public:
examples: He wrote one extraordinary book and then faded into oblivion.

meanings.definition: not conscious of something, especially what is happening around you:
examples: Absorbed in her work, she was totally oblivious of her surroundings.
The mayor seems oblivious to the likely effects of the new legislation.

meanings.definition: not aware of or not noticing something, esp. what is happening around you:
examples: She was often oblivious to the potential consequences of her actions.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows that you are not aware of something, especially what is happening around you:
examples: Distracted drivers chatting obliviously on a phone risk everyone's lives.
He wandered out of the bar and obliviously walked the streets.

meanings.definition: the quality of not being aware of something, especially what is happening around you:
examples: My uncle sat there with a look of blissful obliviousness.
His first wife left him because of his obliviousness to her.

an object or shape that is longer than it is wide
having a flat shape with four sides and four angles of 90° and opposite sides of equal length:
examples: an oblong box
Violet sat down at the oblong oak table that was against the wall.

meanings.definition: having a shape that is longer than it is wide:
examples: oblong loaves of bread
It's a shrub with narrow, oblong leaves.

meanings.definition: a shape that is longer than it is wide, esp. a rectangle that is not a square

meanings.definition: in a very unpleasant or rude way:

meanings.definition: the quality of being very unpleasant or rude:
examples: They defended her against charges of obnoxiousness.
Most people ignored his obnoxiousness.

examples: Exercise bike for sale - $40 obo.

meanings.definition: written abbreviation for or best offer: used in advertisements for used goods to say that the seller will accept slightly less than the price stated:

offensive, rude, or shocking, usually because of being too obviously related to sex or showing sex:
examples: In the raid, police found several boxes of obscene DVDs.
He was jailed for making obscene phone calls (= ones in which unwanted sexual suggestions were made to the listener).
obscene language/graffiti

meanings.definition: morally wrong, often describing something that is wrong because it is too large:
examples: to make obscene profits
The salaries some bankers earn are obscene.
He eats obscene amounts of food.

meanings.definition: offensive, rude, or disgusting according to accepted moral standards
in a way that is offensive, rude, or shocking, usually because of being too obviously related to sex or showing sex:
examples: He used vulgar language and gestured obscenely.
She cursed obscenely in exasperation.

meanings.definition: to a degree that makes you feel dislike or moral disapproval:
examples: He's obscenely rich/fat/cruel.
obscenely expensive handbags

meanings.definition: the fact that something is obscene:
examples: The people who made that movie could be prosecuted for obscenity.
Such deliberate destruction of the environment is an obscenity (= offensive and shocking).
obscenity laws

meanings.definition: a very offensive or sexually shocking word or sentence:
examples: He was shouting and screaming obscenities.

meanings.definition: behavior or language that is offensive, rude, or disgusting
the act of preventing something from being seen or heard, or something that prevents something else from being seen or heard:
examples: Obscuration can be obtained by the use of blackout curtains.
They observed the courses of the stars, and their obscurations.

meanings.definition: the act of making something difficult to discover and understand, or something that makes something else difficult to discover and understand:
examples: an obscuration of the truth
The word “obscuration” occurs frequently in Buddhist texts to mean whatever distorts, blocks, or biases our perception.

meanings.definition: not known to many people:
examples: an obscure island in the Pacific
an obscure 12th-century mystic

meanings.definition: not clear and difficult to understand or see:
examples: Official policy has changed, for reasons that remain obscure.
His answers were obscure and confusing.

meanings.definition: to prevent something from being seen or heard:
examples: Two new skyscrapers had sprung up, obscuring the view from her window.
The sun was obscured by clouds.

meanings.definition: to make something difficult to discover and understand:
examples: Managers deliberately obscured the real situation from federal investigators.

meanings.definition: the state of not being known to many people:

meanings.definition: the state of being not clear and difficult to understand or see:

meanings.definition: the state of not being known to many people:

meanings.definition: the state or quality of being unclear and difficult to understand or see:

meanings.definition: things that are formally said and done at a funeral:
examples: A vast congregation filled the cathedral for the final obsequies.

meanings.definition: too eager to praise or obey someone:
examples: She is embarrassingly obsequious to anyone in authority.

meanings.definition: too eager to serve or obey someone:
examples: She is embarrassingly obsequious to anyone in authority.

meanings.definition: in a way that is too eager to praise or obey someone:
examples: "Yes, my Lord, of course, your wish is my command", said the servant obsequiously.
He was a huge fan of the singer, grinning obsequiously when in her presence.

meanings.definition: that can be noticed or seen:
examples: There's no observable connection between the two events.
Large new buildings often have readily observable impacts on wildlife habitats.

meanings.definition: able to be noticed:
examples: There’s no observable connection between the two events.

meanings.definition: in a way that can be noticed or seen:
examples: The days are becoming observably longer.
Their reactions were observably different.

meanings.definition: the act of obeying a law or following a religious custom:
examples: religious observances such as fasting

meanings.definition: a ceremony or action to celebrate a holiday or a religious or other important event:
examples: Memorial Day observances
Financial markets will be closed Monday in observance of Labor Day.

meanings.definition: good or quick at noticing things:
examples: "That's a new dress, isn't it?" "Yes, you are observant!"

meanings.definition: obeying religious rules or customs:
examples: As an observant Muslim, she wore a headscarf.

meanings.definition: quick to notice things:
examples: Carrie has a clear, observant eye.

meanings.definition: careful in obeying laws, rules, or customs:
examples: observant of cultural traditions

meanings.definition: If you do something observantly, you are good or quick at noticing things:
examples: In this poem, she comments observantly on lost love.
He very observantly pointed out some habits that I didn't even realize I had.

meanings.definition: in a way that obeys religious rules or customs:
examples: I choose to dress observantly, but do not feel any pressure to do so.
He is an observantly teetotal Muslim friend of mine.

meanings.definition: the act of observing something or someone:
examples: close observation of nature/human nature/animal behaviour
The police are keeping the suspect under observation.
She was admitted to hospital for observation (= so that doctors could watch her and see if anything was wrong with her).

meanings.definition: the fact that you notice or see something:
examples: She has remarkable powers of observation (= is very good at noticing things).

meanings.definition: a remark about something that you have noticed:
examples: The book is full of interesting observations on/about the nature of musical composition.
May I make an observation?

meanings.definition: a remark made about something you have noticed:
examples: She made an interesting observation about the poet’s intentions.

meanings.definition: the recorded information that results from studying a scientific event
the act of watching something or someone carefully:
examples: He was admitted to the hospital for observation after complaining of chest pains.

meanings.definition: the ability to notice something or someone:
examples: He has remarkable powers of observation.

meanings.definition: a part of a train for passengers, with glass or open areas intended to give a good view of the country the train is travelling through:
examples: At Banff, you can transfer to the Rocky Mountaineer train for a sensational journey through the glaciers and mountains in glass-topped observation cars.
The open-sided observation car allows you to watch water buffalo grazing by the tracks.

meanings.definition: a place on a building or boat from where you can see or watch something:
examples: The city's tallest skyscraper reopened its observation deck yesterday.
We're on an observation platform that overlooks the heart of the Everglades.

meanings.definition: a room in a building or ship from where you can see or watch something:
examples: There's an observation lounge that looks out over the lovely sweep of Broadford Bay.
The observation lounge - 150ft above the water at the ship's stern - is reached by a remarkable moving walkway.

meanings.definition: a place or building from which you can watch someone, especially an enemy
a tower from where you can see or watch something:
examples: Most visitors watch from either the jetty or the observation tower.
Policemen in observation towers and hundreds of cameras monitored the traffic of pilgrims.

meanings.definition: involving watching someone or something carefully and closely, in order to learn something:
examples: Observational research uses data collected during routine clinical care.

meanings.definition: in a way that involves watching someone or something carefully and closely, in order to learn something:
examples: These two theories have been observationally confirmed.
Observationally and experimentally we have demonstrated this.

meanings.definition: a building from which scientists can watch the planets, the stars, the weather, etc.
a building equipped for studying the planets and the stars
to watch carefully the way something happens or the way someone does something, especially in order to learn more about it:
examples: The role of scientists is to observe and describe the world, not to try to control it.
He spent a year in the jungle, observing how deforestation is affecting local tribes.
Children learn by observing adults.

meanings.definition: to notice or see:
examples: Jack observed a look of anxiety on his brother's face.

A teacher observed her climb over the gate.

meanings.definition: to make a remark about something:
examples: "I've always found German cars very reliable," he observed.

meanings.definition: to obey a law, rule, or custom:
examples: People must observe the law. Nobody should be an exception.
The old people in the village still observe the local traditions.
Do you observe Passover?

meanings.definition: to watch something or someone carefully:

meanings.definition: to notice something or someone:

to remark about something:
examples: "It’s raining again," he observed.

meanings.definition: If something or someone obsesses you, or if you obsess about something or someone, you think about it, him, or her all the time:
examples: The whole relationship obsessed me for years.
She used to obsess about her weight.

meanings.definition: unable to stop thinking about something; too interested in or worried about something:
examples: Why are people so obsessed with money?
As a society we're obsessed by sex.

meanings.definition: unable to stop thinking about something:
examples: The kids are obsessed with video games.

meanings.definition: something or someone that you think about all the time:
examples: an unhealthy obsession with death
her chocolate obsession
He's always wanted to find his birth mother but recently it's become an obsession.

meanings.definition: the control of one’s thoughts by a continuous, powerful idea or feeling, or the idea or feeling itself:
examples: His interest in detective stories has turned to obsession.
They have an obsession with making money.

meanings.definition: thinking about something or someone, or doing something, too much or all the time:
examples: He's obsessive about punctuality.

meanings.definition: like, typical of, or caused by an obsession:
examples: obsessive secrecy
obsessional behaviour

meanings.definition: an obsessive person
related to or typical of a mental health condition in which a person has frequent, unwanted thoughts or feelings that make them feel that they have to repeat particular actions:
examples: his obsessive-compulsive repetition of certain phrases

meanings.definition: an offensive word that is used to describe someone who worries a lot about small details and has a strong dislike of anything that is not perfect, or to describe the behaviour of someone like this
a mental health condition in which a person has frequent, unwanted thoughts or feelings that make them feel that they have to repeat particular actions:
examples: He said that symptoms of obsessive-compulsive disorder include continual washing and cleaning, checking of themselves or others to avoid harm, repeating a sequence or phrase and hoarding useless items.

meanings.definition: in a way that involves thinking about something or someone, or doing something, too much or all the time:
examples: I was exercising obsessively but I was hardly eating and my body just couldn't cope.

the quality of being obsolete:
examples: Mobile phone technology is developing so quickly that many customers are concerned about obsolescence.

meanings.definition: the process of becoming no longer useful or needed:
examples: Older versions had passed into obsolescence and a new version was already on the market.

meanings.definition: the process or fact of becoming old-fashioned and no longer useful:
examples: Depreciation refers to the loss of value of an asset due to age, wear and tear, and obsolescence.
Unless it changes, the industry faces the risk of technological obsolescence.

meanings.definition: becoming obsolete:
examples: Much of our existing military hardware is obsolescent.

meanings.definition: not in use any more, having been replaced by something newer and better or more fashionable:
examples: Gas lamps became obsolete when electric lighting was invented.

meanings.definition: no longer used or needed, usually because something newer and better has replaced it:
examples: Typewriters have been rendered obsolete by computers.

meanings.definition: not in general use any more, having been replaced by something newer and better or more fashionable:
examples: Payment by cheque will soon be obsolete.
Traditional retailing is in danger of being rendered obsolete by the internet.
We need to replace some obsolete equipment.

meanings.definition: something that blocks you so that movement, going forward, or action is prevented or made more difficult:
examples: The biggest obstacle in our way was a tree trunk in the road.
This decision has removed the last obstacle to the hostages' release.

meanings.definition: something that blocks your way so that movement or progress is prevented or made more difficult:
examples: We suddenly encountered an obstacle along the trail.
Money seems to be no obstacle.

a series of problems that you have to solve in order to achieve something

the quality of being unreasonably determined, especially to act in a particular way and not to change at all, despite what anyone else says:
examples: I stayed until the end out of sheer obstinacy.
the obstinacy of the human spirit

meanings.definition: unreasonably determined, especially to act in a particular way and not to change at all, despite what anyone else says:
examples: He can be very obstinate at times.
her obstinate refusal to compromise

meanings.definition: used to describe a problem, situation, or thing that is difficult to deal with, remove, change, or defeat:
examples: obstinate weeds

meanings.definition: unwilling to change your opinion or action despite argument or persuasion; stubborn:
examples: an obstinate two-year-old

meanings.definition: An obstinate thing or problem is difficult to deal with, remove, or defeat.
in a way that is unreasonably determined, especially by acting in a particular way and not changing at all, despite what anyone else says:
examples: They remained obstinately silent.

meanings.definition: in a way that is difficult to deal with, change, or solve:
examples: The engine obstinately refused to start.

meanings.definition: difficult to deal with and noisy:
examples: obstreperous customers

meanings.definition: in a way that is difficult to deal with and noisy:
examples: You shouldn't use this situation as an excuse to behave obstreperously.

meanings.definition: the quality of being difficult to deal with and noisy:
examples: It is easy to look back and condemn her for her obstreperousness.

meanings.definition: to block a road, passage, entrance, etc. so that nothing can go along it, or to prevent something from happening correctly by putting difficulties in its way:
examples: After the earthquake many roads were obstructed by collapsed buildings.
Her view of the stage was obstructed by a pillar.
An accident is obstructing traffic on the M11.

meanings.definition: to try to stop something from happening or developing:
examples: to obstruct a police investigation
He got five years in prison for withholding evidence and obstructing the course of justice.
He was charged with obstructing justice.

meanings.definition: to block or get in the way of something or someone, or to prevent something from happening or progressing by causing difficulties:
examples: Demonstrators obstructed the entrance to the building.

intentionally trying to stop or slow down an official process:
examples: obstructionist policies/tactics
They have accused the other party of being obstructionist.

meanings.definition: trying to stop someone from doing something by causing problems for them:
examples: We'd have made a decision by now if Jean hadn't been so obstructive.

meanings.definition: a type of sleep apnea (= a condition where breathing stops for a short time during sleep) caused by a physical closing of the airways:
examples: Obstructive sleep apnea is often found in people who are very overweight.

meanings.definition: a type of sleep apnoea (= a condition where breathing stops for a short time during sleep) caused by a physical closing of the airways:
examples: Obstructive sleep apnoea is often found in people who are very overweight.

meanings.definition: in a way that tries to stop someone from doing something by causing problems for them:
examples: Their attituide was often obstructively critical.

meanings.definition: the quality of trying to stop someone from doing something by causing problems for them:
examples: She met the usual obstructiveness whenever she asked for anything.

meanings.definition: to get something, especially by asking for it, buying it, working for it, or producing it from something else:
examples: to obtain permission

meanings.definition: (especially of a situation) to exist:
examples: Conditions of extreme poverty now obtain in many parts of the country.

meanings.definition: to get something, esp. by a planned effort:

examples: Information on the subject is easily obtainable on the internet.
