meanings.definition: small jobs of different types, especially those that involve repairing or cleaning things:
examples: He’s been doing odd jobs this summer to earn a little extra money.

meanings.definition: small jobs of different types, esp. those that involve repairing or cleaning things:
examples: He’s been doing odd jobs this summer to earn a little extra money.

meanings.definition: a man who is paid to do different types of jobs, especially in the house or garden
a person whose behaviour is unusual and strange
(of behaviour ) unusual and strange:
examples: The oddball superstar's habits include watching TV with his chimpanzee.
She has made a successful career out of her oddball humour .

meanings.definition: a person whose behavior is unusual and strange
someone or something that is strange and unusual:
examples: Even today a man who stays at home to take care of the children is regarded as something of an oddity.

meanings.definition: someone or something that is strange and unusual:
examples: As one of the few women in engineering in the 1950s, she was considered an oddity.

meanings.definition: in a strange or surprising way:
examples: Didn't you think she was behaving very oddly at the party yesterday?
Oddly enough (= this is strange/surprising), she didn't mention anything about the fact that she was getting married.

meanings.definition: strangely and unusually:
examples: an oddly shaped house
Oddly enough, despite the sizzling heat, scientists suspect there could be water frozen on Mercury.

meanings.definition: small pieces, usually of cloth, that have been cut from larger pieces:
examples: a few oddments of fabric

meanings.definition: small things, objects, or pieces of something, usually of many different types:
examples: The magazine has reviews and news plus letters and other oddments.
Only small oddments of fabric are needed.

meanings.definition: the quality of being strange or unexpected
the probability (= how likely it is) that a particular thing will or will not happen:
examples: If you drive a car all your life, the odds are that you'll have an accident at some point.
There are heavy odds against people succeeding in such a bad economic climate.
What are the odds on him being (= do you think he will be) re-elected?
The overall odds of winning a lottery prize are 1 in 13.
The odds are stacked against a woman succeeding (= it is not likely that a woman will succeed) in the business.

meanings.definition: in gambling (= the activity of risking money guessing the result of something), a probability expressed as a number:
examples: The odds against my horse winning (= that it will not win)/on my horse winning (= that it will win) are a hundred to one.
The odds that the US entrant will win the race are ten to one.

meanings.definition: the likelihood that a particular thing will or will not happen:
examples: She was sick yesterday, so the odds are she won’t be in today.

meanings.definition: the odds of something happening are how probable it is that it will happen:
examples: At the moment it seems the odds are against a deal.
They are so evenly matched, the odds are on a draw.
The odds are good that the country's transformation will proceed smoothly.
People retiring today have better odds than ever of living a long healthy life.
Given the poor economic climate, the odds of success are slim.

meanings.definition: how probable something is, expressed as a pair of numbers or a percentage, for example when betting :
examples: We think 6 to 2 are good odds.
The odds are 100-1 against him getting the job.
For taxpayers with incomes above $100,000 the odds of being audited in 2006 were 1 in 59.

meanings.definition: various things of different types, usually small and not important, or of little value:
examples: I took most of the big things to the new house, but there are a few odds and ends left to pick up.

meanings.definition: various items of different types, usually small and unimportant or of little value:
examples: We’ve moved most of the furniture to the new house, but there are still a few odds and ends to bring over.

meanings.definition: very probable:
examples: The odds-on favourite to win in the 3.30 race is Killjoy.
It's odds-on she'll be late and I've rushed for no reason!

meanings.definition: thought most likely to happen, succeed, or do a particular thing:
examples: He is odds-on to serve another term as president of the Commission.
Next month looks odds-on for a further rise in interest rates.
Mr Kerry won the state, where he was the odds-on favourite.

meanings.definition: a poem expressing the writer's thoughts and feelings about a particular person or subject, usually written to that person or subject:
examples: It reminded me of A. E. Housman's poem "A Shropshire Lad", an ode to an athlete who dies young.
"Ode on a Grecian Urn" is a poem by Keats.

meanings.definition: a poem that deals with thoughts and feelings about an idea or subject and that is written in lines and stanzas (= groups of lines) varying in length
abbreviation for one-day international: in cricket, a game between countries that takes place in a single day:
examples: She is the record holder for the most appearances in ODIs for Australia.
The tour includes four Test matches and six ODIs.

meanings.definition: a language spoken in eastern India:
examples: Odia is mainly spoken in the Indian state of Orissa.
"Chhena poda" literally means "burnt cheese" in Odia.

meanings.definition: in or of the Odia language:
examples: The Odia word for “husband” is swami.
the Odia alphabet

meanings.definition:
another word for 
        
         odoriferous
in Norse mythology (= ancient stories from Scandinavia), the god of war and death:
examples: Norse mythology has it that Odin's horse was a giant, flying, eight-legged beast called Sleipnir.

meanings.definition: extremely unpleasant and causing or deserving hate:
examples: an odious crime
an odious little man

meanings.definition: extremely unpleasant; causing and deserving hate:
examples: an odious person/task

meanings.definition: in an extremely unpleasant way that causes or deserves hate:
examples: These crimes are some of the most odiously shocking that I have ever read about.
You behaved absolutely odiously when we visited my mother - I was so embarrassed.

meanings.definition: hate and strong disapproval
a device in a vehicle that measures and shows the distance it travels
a device in a vehicle that measures and shows the distance the vehicle travels
a group of insects that includes dragonflies and damselflies:
examples: Damselflies are a smaller, much more delicate version of true dragonflies, although both are in the same insect order, Odonata.
The Dragonfly (Odonata) is a familiar sight around the margins of lakes and rivers.

meanings.definition: any of the layer of cells on the outside of the pulp of a tooth (= the soft tissue inside a tooth) that produce dentine (= the hard substance that forms the main part of a tooth):
examples: Along the border between the dentine and the pulp are odontoblasts, which initiate the formation of dentine.
Nerves have been traced to the odontoblast layer at the base of the dentine.

meanings.definition: a tooth-like structure that points upwards on the back of the second vertebra (= one of the small bones in the spine) in the neck, and around which the other vertebrae turn:
examples: He may have fractured his atlas, or the odontoid process of his axis.
The odontoid process articulates with the anterior arch of the atlas bone, where they form a pivot joint.
The anterior arch contains a facet for articulation with the dens of the axis.

meanings.definition: a person who studies the structure and diseases of teeth, especially one who uses their knowledge to identify people and help solve crimes:
examples: The odontologist can help identify the victims by using dental evidence.

meanings.definition: the scientific study of the structure and diseases of teeth, especially in order to identify people and help solve crimes:
examples: The Armed Forces Institute of Pathology offers week-long dental courses in odontology and pathology.

meanings.definition:
US spelling of 
        
         odour UK formal
a particular smell, esp. a bad one:
examples: the musty odor of a damp cellar

meanings.definition: having a smell, especially an unpleasant one:
examples: Ammonia is a highly odoriferous and exceptionally volatile substance.
Lead is easily purified away from the odiferous sulfur.
As students, they spent most of their time playing pool in an odiferous college bar.

meanings.definition: without a smell:
examples: an odorless gas

meanings.definition: having no smell:
examples: an odorless gas

meanings.definition: having an unpleasant smell:
examples: The chlorine dioxide neutralizes the odorous sulphur compounds.

meanings.definition: a smell, often one that is unpleasant:
examples: Inside the room there was the unmistakable odour of sweaty feet.
Aroma preference is largely influenced by our body odour.

meanings.definition: a particular quality that can be noticed:
examples: The odour of hypocrisy hung about everything she said.
Lieberman said the article had an odour of anti-Semitism.

meanings.definition: without a smell:
examples: an odourless gas

meanings.definition: a long, exciting journey:
examples: The film follows one man's odyssey to find the mother from whom he was separated at birth.
a spiritual odyssey

meanings.definition: a long trip or period involving a lot of different and exciting activities, esp. while searching for something:
examples: The movie follows one man’s odyssey to find the mother he was separated from at birth.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development: an international organization whose members are countries with advanced economies and whose aim is to encourage economic growth around the world:
examples: The OECD expects the American economy to slow gradually.

meanings.definition: an unhealthy condition in which liquid collects in the body tissues between the cells
relating to an Oedipus complex:
examples: Freud argued that all people go through an Oedipal phase of sexual development.
Oedipal fantasies

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to an Oedipus complex (= in the study of the human mind, a child's sexual desire for their parent of the opposite sex, especially that of a boy for his mother):
examples: It's a fascinating, Oedipally influenced tale in which the main character kills his father and almost ends up marrying his mother.
She is always Oedipally trying to please her father.

meanings.definition: in psychology (= the study of the human mind), a child's sexual desire for their parent of the different gender, especially that of a boy for his mother
abbreviation for open-ended investment company: an investment fund in which you can buy shares. The OEIC then invests the money in other companies:
examples: With an OEIC there is only one price for both buyers and sellers, unlike unit trusts where there are two separate prices.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for original equipment manufacturer: a company that makes parts and products for other companies which sell them under their own name or use them in their own products:
examples: Many manufacturers are producing auto parts on an OEM basis.
OEM customer/manufacturer/partner

meanings.definition: a person who loves wine and knows a lot about it
relating to the oesophagus (= the tube that takes food from the mouth to the stomach):
examples: oesophageal cancer

meanings.definition:
plural of 
        
         oesophagus   UK specialized
inflammation of the oesophagus (= the tube that takes food from the mouth to the stomach):
examples: Pain on swallowing may be due to severe oesophagitis.

meanings.definition: the tube in the body that takes food from the mouth to the stomach

plural of 
        
         oesophagus   UK specialized
a naturally occurring female hormone that can be produced chemically and used as a drug
a female hormone that causes development and change in the reproductive organs (= organs involved in producing babies)

a UK spelling of 
        
         estrus
the complete works of a writer, painter, or other artist:
examples: I'm not familiar with his oeuvre.

meanings.definition: used to show possession, belonging, or origin:
examples: a friend of mine
the president of the United States
employees of the company
the colour of his hair
a habit of mine
that revolting dog of hers
the love of a good woman
the complete plays of (= written by) Lorca

meanings.definition: used after words or phrases expressing amount, number, or a particular unit:
examples: a kilo of apples
loads of food
hundreds of people
most of them
none of them
both of us
a third of all people
a speck of dust
a drop of rain

meanings.definition: containing:
examples: a bag of sweets
a bottle of beer
a book of short stories
a class of idiots

meanings.definition: used in expressions showing position:
examples: the top of his head
the back of your dress
on the corner of the street
the front of the queue
I've never been north of Philadelphia.

meanings.definition: typical or characteristic of:
examples: She has the face of an angel.
That guy's got the personality of a dead fish!

meanings.definition: used to refer to a particular date in a month:
examples: the eleventh of March
the first of the month

meanings.definition: made or consisting of; having:
examples: dresses of lace and silk
plates of gold and silver
a land of ice and snow
a woman of great charm
a subject of very little interest

meanings.definition: used to connect particular adjectives and verbs with nouns:
examples: fond of swimming
sick of his excuses
scared of spiders

meanings.definition: used after an adjective when judging someone's behaviour:
examples: It was mean of you to mention her weight.
Thank you so much for my present. How thoughtful of you.

meanings.definition: about; relating to:
examples: Speaking of Elizabeth, here she is.
One of the advantages of travelling by train is being able to read.
Let us consider the events of the last five months.
Of her childhood we know very little.
And what of (= tell me about) young Adrian? How is he?

meanings.definition: that is/are:
examples: the problem of homelessness
a rise of two percent in inflation
the skill of negotiating
the difficulty of bringing up twins
the pain of separation
At the age of six she could read a newspaper.

meanings.definition: done to:
examples: the massacre of hundreds of innocent people
the oppression of a nation
the destruction of the rain forest

meanings.definition: felt or experienced by:
examples: the suffering of millions
the anguish of the murdered child's parents

meanings.definition: through; having as the cause:
examples: He died of cancer.
I didn't have to go there - I did it of my own free will.
I want to know how it happened because it certainly didn't happen of itself.

meanings.definition: used when comparing related things:
examples: I liked the green one best of all .
Worst of all was the food!
He's the best looking of the three brothers.
I think that of all his books it's my favourite.

meanings.definition: used in saying what the time is:
examples: It's ten (minutes) of five (= ten minutes before five o'clock).

meanings.definition: used in expressions showing distance from something in place or time:
examples: We live within a mile of the school.
She came within two seconds of beating the world record.

meanings.definition: used in expressions showing loss:
examples: They were robbed of all their savings.
I feel I've been deprived of your company.

meanings.definition: during:
examples: I like to relax with a pipe of an evening.

meanings.definition: used to show possession, belonging, or origin:
examples: She is a friend of mine.
The color of his tie matches his suit.
Have you read the novels of John Updike?

meanings.definition: containing or consisting of:
examples: a bag of groceries
a book of short stories
a forest of pine trees
a bunch of grapes

meanings.definition: used after words or phrases expressing amount, number, or a particular unit:
examples: a drop of rain
two pounds of potatoes
hundreds of people

meanings.definition: used in expressions showing position:
examples: I left the book on top of my desk.
I’ve never been north of Montreal.

meanings.definition: resulting from or having to do with:
examples: the joy of family
the fear of failure

meanings.definition: about, or relating to:
examples: Speaking of Elizabeth, here she is.
There’s a chapter on the use of herbs for medicinal purposes.

meanings.definition: used to show the cause of something:
examples: He died of a heart attack.
Penny is frightened of spiders.
I’m tired of all this criticism.

meanings.definition: that is/are:
examples: Sales tax of 7% is included in the price.
She could read by the age of five.

meanings.definition: used when comparing related things:
examples: He’s the oldest of three brothers.
Of all his films, this one is my favorite.

meanings.definition: done to or involving:
examples: the destruction of the rain forests
the graduation of the class of 2001

meanings.definition: used in expressions showing distance from something in place or time:
examples: We live within a mile of the school.
She came within two seconds of beating the world record.

meanings.definition: used in saying what the time is:
examples: It’s ten (minutes) of five (= ten minutes before five o’clock).

meanings.definition: used to describe a particular day:
examples: the eleventh of March
the first of the month

meanings.definition: very important:
examples: a decision of great moment
Nothing of moment had happened on the journey.
He rarely had anything of moment to contribute to our discussions.
When there were matters of great moment to discuss, his opinion was frequently sought.
These are issues of great moment.
Nothing of great moment was said.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that exists but is not very good:
examples: The school had a swimming pool of a kind, but it was too small for most classes to use.

meanings.definition: used to show that you are especially surprised at a particular person's behaviour because it does not seem typical of them:
examples: I thought that you, of all people, would believe me!

meanings.definition: especially:
examples: I thought that you, of all people, would believe me!

meanings.definition: used to express the idea that a particular person/thing/place is unlikely or surprising:
examples: Donna, of all people, is the last one I'd expect to see at the gym.
And why did you choose Iceland for a holiday, of all places?

meanings.definition: that has ever lived or existed:
examples: She's been called the greatest singer of all time.
He's the greatest Olympian of all time.
This must be one of the best rock albums of all time.
He was the most successful British golfer of all time.
She's the club's second highest scorer of all time.
He's surely one of the greatest guitarists of all time.
He's considered by many to be the best hockey player of all time.

meanings.definition: Your thing or person of choice is the one that you usually choose in a particular situation:
examples: Botox is now the drug of choice in Hollywood.
Champagne is their drink of choice (= the one they most often drink).

meanings.definition: used to say yes or to give someone permission to do something: used to show that what you are saying is obvious or already known: used to show that a situation or a piece of information is not surprising:
examples: "Can you help me?" "Of course."
"May I look at your newspaper?" "Of course you can."
"Have you written your English essay yet?" "Of course, I finished it last week."
The Second World War ended, of course, in 1945.
We arrived at the restaurant 30 minutes late so, of course, our reservation had been cancelled.

meanings.definition: yes, certainly:
examples: "May I use your telephone?" "Of course, go right ahead."

meanings.definition: used to emphasize that you disagree or that something is not true:
examples: "Where did you get the money? Did you steal it?" "Of course not. I borrowed it from Carol."

meanings.definition: definitely no or definitely not:
examples: "The pie is delicious! Do you mind if I have a second helping? " "Of course not, I’m glad you like it."

meanings.definition: having a very high quality:
examples: The city has produced very few writers of distinction.
As she approaches retirement, she can look back on a career of distinction with many high points.

meanings.definition: used to say that something is perfect or excellent:
examples: With gorgeous colours and sumptuously soft velvet, this really is the sofa of dreams.
The house has five bedrooms, six bathrooms, and the kitchen of dreams.
Shoppers flocked to buy this summer's dress of dreams.
He told reporters that his new venture was his "job of dreams".
The perfect setting, weather, and company all added up to a weekend of dreams.

meanings.definition: used to say that something is what someone has always wanted or the best that they can imagine:
examples: Win the house of your dreams in our fantastic competition!
We promise you'll find the wedding dress of your dreams in our boutique.
Twenty-five years ago, I married the man of my dreams.
I'm lucky enough to have landed the job of my dreams.
Eventually, he made enough money to buy the car of his dreams.

meanings.definition: of all types:
examples: Boats of every description were entering the harbour.
Toys of every description lined the shelves.
You can find electrical appliances, furniture, clothes - goods of every description - at the department store.
Vehicles of every description make their way north, out of the city.
Vegetables of every description are piled up on the tables.

meanings.definition: of all types:
examples: Governments of every stripe (= of all political opinions) have a bad habit of interfering in state broadcasting.

meanings.definition: recently:
examples: We haven't spoken of late.

meanings.definition: not important:
examples: The money was of little consequence to Tony.
In the grand scheme of things, these problems are of little consequence.
She made it clear that our opinions were of little consequence to her.
For healthy people, a little too much salt or sugar is of no consequence.
At the time, the information had seemed of no consequence, but now she wished she had listened more carefully.
He wanted to audition for the play, but since they had already cast all the parts, his performance wasn't of much consequence.

meanings.definition: of interest to only a few people:
examples: articles about subjects of marginal interest
The documentary was probably of marginal interest to anyone who doesn't work in the media.
Exactly how food is produced is a matter of marginal interest to most consumers.
Stories of marginal interest may be included in the day's news simply in order to fill the schedule.
Diversity seems to be a topic of marginal interest to the party leader.

meanings.definition: in or from the past: for a very long time:
examples: in days of old
I know him of old.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that is not a typical or good example of something:
examples: He managed to make a curtain of sorts out of an old sheet.

meanings.definition: of that name; usually used when someone's family name has been mentioned:
examples: It was young McBride, Brian of that ilk (= Brian McBride).
She often referred to her friend Miss Rubens, Bernice of that ilk (= her friend was Bernice Rubens).
He brandished a MacInnes axe, designed by Hamish of that ilk.
The team currently has not one Rae but two, with Gavin of that ilk now playing in midfield.
The horse was ridden by J P Magnier, son of owner John of that ilk.

meanings.definition: to a very great degree or of an extremely good kind:
examples: It is a diplomatic scandal of the first order.
Austen is a writer of the first order.
The whole event was a debacle of the first order.
In a world dominated by men, Catherine was a political operator of the first order.
The new major, with his muscled torso and broken nose, was a thug of the first order.
As for his mother, she was a bore of the first water.

meanings.definition: like or similar to what has been said:
examples: "You said I was fat." "I didn't say anything of the kind!"

meanings.definition: the person or thing that is the most important and successful at a particular time:
examples: Jack was man of the moment during the crisis.

meanings.definition: traditional and old-fashioned
A thing or person of the week is one that has been chosen as the best in a particular week:
examples: Book of the Week: Dog Breeds by Andrew and Helen Barker.

meanings.definition: A thing or person of the year is one that has been chosen as the best in a particular year, especially in a competition:
examples: Young Musician of the Year

meanings.definition: unable to make a decision:
examples: I was of two minds about whether to invite him to the wedding.

meanings.definition: If you do something of your own accord, you do it without being asked to do it:
examples: She came of her own accord. No one asked her to come.
All the demonstrators took part of their own accord.
Did you sign the contract of your own accord?

meanings.definition: your own fault:
examples: Any problems she has with that child are of her own making.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs: a US government department that checks that companies doing business with the government obey laws on equal opportunities (= fair treatment for women and men, people of different races, religions, etc.):
examples: The OFCCP is to receive a 25% budget increase and more than 200 additional compliance officers in 2012.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Office of Communications: an official UK organization that checks that telephone and broadcasting companies obey government rules:
examples: Ofcom's research showed that many television programmes watched by children are not aimed specifically at them.

meanings.definition: a UK stock exchange for shares in small companies:
examples: The company plans to join OFEX next year.

meanings.definition: a UK stock exchange for shares in small companies:
examples: Ofex-listed health clubs operator Fit Stop was 4p higher at the end of this week's trading.

meanings.definition: away from a place or position, especially the present place, position, or time:
examples: He drove off at the most incredible speed.
Keep the dog on the lead or he'll just run off.
Someone ran off with (= took) my pen.
She's off to Canada next week.
I saw her off (= said goodbye) at the station.
Finals are so far off that I'm not even thinking about them yet.
I'm off now - see you tomorrow.
If we can get off (= leave) early tomorrow morning we'll avoid most of the traffic.

meanings.definition: used with actions in which something is removed or removes itself from another thing:
examples: Take your jacket off.
One of my buttons has come off.
She had all her hair cut off.

meanings.definition: (especially of machines, electrical devices, lights, etc.) not operating because of not being switched on:
examples: Make sure the computers are all off before you go home.
Turn/Switch the light/engine/television off.

meanings.definition: (of money) taken away from the original price:
examples: You can get some money off if you pay cash.
There's 40 percent off this week on all winter coats.
There was $40 or $50 off most jackets in the store.

meanings.definition: not at work; at home or on holiday:
examples: I'm going to take/have some time off to work on my house.
She was off sick last week.
He's off at the moment - can I get him to call you back?

meanings.definition: in such a way as to be separated:
examples: The police have shut/closed off all streets leading to the city.
The area in the park where the kids play is fenced off for safety reasons.

meanings.definition: in such a way as to be completely absent, especially because of having been used or killed:
examples: It says on the bottle that it kills off all known germs.
It'll take some time before she manages to pay off all her debts.
The good thing about exercise is that it burns off calories.
Between us we managed to finish off several bottles of wine.

meanings.definition: in such a way as to get rid of something:
examples: We went out for a while to walk off some of our dinner.
He's gone to sleep off a headache.
There's no point in getting upset about what he said - you just have to laugh it off.

meanings.definition: used to form nouns referring to a situation in which two or more people or teams compete against each other to see who is the winner:
examples: the BBC series, the Great British Bake Off
Audience applause determines the winner of each dance-off.

meanings.definition: down or away from a place, position, or time, especially the present place, position, or time:
examples: There was a "Keep off the grass" sign.
All the berries had dropped off the tree.
He fell off his bike.
We're still a long way off our target of $30,000.
I hope she knows where to get off (= leave) the bus/train.
How far off finishing the project are we? (= How much more is there to do?)
We've been working on the flat for six months now but we're still a long way off finishing.
We're not far off (= we are quite near) London now.

meanings.definition: used with actions in which something is removed or removes itself from another thing:
examples: I can't get the lid off this jar.
Has anyone taken a book off my desk?
Could you cut me a small piece off that big white cheese?
Take your feet off that seat, young man!
I don't like taking money off you (= asking you for money)!
Get off me! (= Stop touching me!)
I got the knife off of him before he ran away.

meanings.definition: not liking or taking something or someone:
examples: He's been off his food ever since he had the stomach upset.
She's well enough to be off the medicine now.
She's been off drugs for a year now.
The doctor says he can come off the tablets.
I used to love coffee but I've gone off it (= stopped liking it) recently.

meanings.definition: near to:
examples: He lives just off the main road.
It's an island off the east coast of Spain.

meanings.definition: (of an arranged event) stopped or given up:
examples: The wedding's off - she's decided she's too young to settle down.
It's all off (= the relationship is over) between Kim and Mike.

meanings.definition: having a particular amount or number, especially of money:
examples: Andrew must be so well-off (= rich) by now.
I think they're fairly badly-off (= poor) now that David has lost his job.
I'm quite well off for (= have a lot of) sweaters.
How are you off for money? (= do you have enough?)

meanings.definition: below the usual standard or rate:
examples: I'm having an off day today - I just can't seem to do anything right!

meanings.definition: (of food and drink) no longer fresh or good to eat or drink because of being too old:
examples: This milk smells off.
I'd better eat this cheese before it goes off.

meanings.definition: (of food in a restaurant) not available at that particular time:
examples: I'm sorry, sir, the salmon is off.

meanings.definition: not thinking or worrying about other people's feelings; rude:
examples: He didn't even call her on her birthday - I thought that was a bit off.

meanings.definition: in cricket, the right side of the field for a right-handed batter or the left-side of the field for a left-handed batter:
examples: The captain moved the fielder from off to on.
She tapped the ball in front of square on the off side and ran through for a single.

meanings.definition: to kill someone:
examples: They offed him and dumped his body in the swamp.

meanings.definition: (esp. of a machine, electrical device, light, etc.) not operating because it is not switched on:
examples: Was the computer on or off when you left?
Turn the engine off.

meanings.definition: not at work or school, esp. being at home or on vacation:
examples: I’m going to take a week off to work on my house.
I’m off next week.
The kids get off early from school today.

meanings.definition: below the usual standard or rate:
examples: Sales have been off this month.
He’s a good tennis player but had an off day and lost in straight sets.
They took 10% off (= below the usual price) because I paid in cash.

meanings.definition: (of an arranged event) stopped or given up in advance:
examples: Last night’s baseball game was called off because of rain.

meanings.definition: away from a place or position, esp. the present place or position:
examples: He drove off at high speed.
She’s off to Canada next week.
The sign says, "Keep off the grass."

meanings.definition: used with actions in which something is removed or removes itself from another thing:
examples: I think I’ll take my jacket off.
I can’t get the lid off this jar.
He fell off his bike.
Did you leave the phone off the hook (= not put back in such a way that a call is ended)?

meanings.definition: far away in time or space:
examples: Graduation is still a long way off.
That’s not the right answer, but you’re not far off.

meanings.definition: near to:
examples: The island is just off the coast of Florida.

meanings.definition: in such a way as to be taken away or removed, esp. because of having been used or killed:
examples: to pay off debts
Exercise burns off fat.
They were all killed off by disease.

meanings.definition: in such a way as to be separated:
examples: to mark off 10 feet
The children’s play area is fenced off for safety reasons.

meanings.definition: happening or existing only some of the time:
examples: He worked off and on as a bicycle messenger, but he never found permanent work.

meanings.definition: If someone or something is off balance, that person or thing is in a position where they are likely to fall or be knocked down:
examples: A gust of wind knocked/threw her off balance and she fell.

meanings.definition: confused or uncertain about what to do next:
examples: Many Republicans were thrown off balance by the Democrats' landslide at the polls.

meanings.definition: wrong:
examples: You're (way) off base there.

meanings.definition: wrong:
examples: You're (way) off beam there.

meanings.definition: in cricket, an occasion where the ball is bowled (= thrown to the batter) slowly and after it hits the ground it moves from the right side to the left for a right-handed batter or from the left side to the right for a left-handed batter:
examples: Although mainly a batter, she has been practising her off breaks.
He misjudged a viciously spinning off-break and was clean bowled.

meanings.definition: in cricket, an occasion when the ball is bowled (= thrown to the batter) fairly fast and after it hits the ground it moves from the right to the left side for a right-handed batter or from the left to the right side for a left-handed batter:
examples: He nicked an off cutter and was well caught by the wicketkeeper.
She has picked up over 60 wickets this season bowling a mix of off cutters and leg cutters.

meanings.definition: in cricket, a shot that the batter hits in front of them along the ground and towards the right side for a right-handed batter or the left side for a left-handed batter:
examples: The off drive is a classic cricket shot.
He produced a series of elegant off drives.

meanings.definition: If a goalkeeper is off his or her line, he or she is not standing along the goal line:
examples: Neymar caught the keeper off his line with a brilliant 45-yard lob.

meanings.definition: (of a politician) saying things in public that are different from the official ideas of his or her political party:
examples: He was criticized severely by party leaders for going off message during the debate.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that someone says in public that is different from the official ideas of their organization, political party, etc.:
examples: The new defence secretary had just unhelpfully gone off-message.
off-message comments/remarks

meanings.definition: saying words that are different to those written on a script (= the words for a speech, broadcast, play, or film ):
examples: During his State of the State address, he went off-script to ask that legislators "show respect".
The news reader veered off script while delivering her report.
He's the best off-script improviser in the business.

meanings.definition: not behaving or happening as expected or planned:
examples: Everyone enjoys it when a public figure unexpectedly goes off script and shows genuine emotion.
Too many players went off-script in the heat of the game, losing discipline.
The controversy was a rare off-script moment on a meticulously organized royal tour.

meanings.definition: If someone or something is off your radar, you are not aware of, or have not thought about, them or it:
examples: At that time, boyfriends were completely off my radar.
We recycle our waste, but what happens to it afterwards is completely off our radar.

meanings.definition: in cricket, a type of slow bowling (= throwing the ball to the batter) in which, after the ball hits the ground, it moves from the right side to the left side for a right-handed batter or from the left side to the right side for a left-handed batter:
examples: They only bowled five overs of off spin during the innings.
I started off bowling off spin but then switched to seam.

meanings.definition: In sports such asfootball, rugby, basketball and hockey, if something happens off the ball, it takes place away from where the player with the ball is:
examples: The player was injured in an incident off the ball that the referee failed to see.
His running off the ball was impressive, creating space for teammates as he drew defenders away.
His defence off the ball has improved a lot this season.

meanings.definition: not known or popular with many people:
examples: We wanted to find a camping site that was a little bit off the beaten path.

meanings.definition: in a place where few people go, far from any main roads and towns:
examples: The farmhouse we stayed in was completely off the beaten track.

meanings.definition: used to describe a payment that is not officially recorded, so that no tax is paid on it:
examples: Off-the-books payment of wages in cash still happens in some small businesses.

meanings.definition: extremely good:
examples: I made it with extra cheese and it was off the chain.
We're going to show them this town is off the chain.

meanings.definition: at a very high level: extremely popular or successful:
examples: His blood pressure was off the charts
The new restaurant is totally off the charts.

meanings.definition: in the sea close to the land:
examples: The accident happened three miles off the coast.
It's a tiny island off the coast of western Ireland.

meanings.definition: If you speak off the cuff, you say something without having prepared or thought about your words first:
examples: I hadn't prepared a speech so I just said a few words off the cuff.
an off-the-cuff remark

meanings.definition: said without the intention of being published or officially noted:
examples: An aide told reporters, off the record, that the senator had been lying.
My off-the-record remarks were printed in the paper the next day.

meanings.definition: extremely large in amount or degree :
examples: Revenues are off the scale and global domination is on the agenda.
His control and cruelty was off the scale .

meanings.definition: used to describe a product that is available immediately and does not need to be specially made to suit a particular purpose:
examples: You can purchase off-the-shelf software or have it customized to suit your needs.

off-the-top-of-head.name: off the top of your head

meanings.definition: from the knowledge you have in your memory:
examples: "What's the capital of Mauritania?" "I don't know off the top of my head, but I could go and look it up."

meanings.definition: strange or very different, often intentionally:
examples: Teenagers love his off-the-wall comedy.

meanings.definition: not making good progress and possibly in danger of failing: talking about something that is not part of what you should be talking about: not at or on a track where a race is being held, or not found or happening there:
examples: When it comes to taking medication, if you're not in a stable living environment it's easy to get off track.
She felt that her life was going off track, that she'd made the wrong choices.
The film is a portrait of a society that has gone off-track.
We went off the track when we started focusing on low-fat foods, and loaded up on starch and sugar.
I think we're getting off track here - we're supposed to be discussing our advertising campaign.
Some lecturers have a tendency to veer off the track.
I know I'm going off the track a little, but I just want to mention the role of social media.
Racetracks have to get approval from local city or county lawmakers before locating their casinos off track.
The Bill allows off-track betting on dog races.
Of the $3.2 billion bet at company-owned tracks and off-track sites, only about one-third was bet at the track.

meanings.definition: a white colour with a little grey or yellow in it:
examples: The walls were painted off white.

meanings.definition: of a white colour with a little grey or yellow in it:
examples: She was wearing a dark blue miniskirt with an off-white cotton blouse.
Wall colours should be neutral – off-white or cream.

meanings.definition: used as a way of ordering someone to remove something:
examples: Off with his head!
Off with your jacket!

meanings.definition: If you say that someone is off their rocker, you mean that that person is behaving in a very strange or silly way.
behaving in an extremely unusual way or doing something very silly:
examples: Anyone who saw us doing this would think we were off our trolleys.
Have you gone completely off your trolley? You'll never get away with it!

meanings.definition: used to describe assets or debts that a company does not need to show on its balance sheet (= financial statement for a particular period):
examples: The company had $4 billion in off-balance-sheet debt that was hidden from investors.
The airline used off-balance-sheet financing to buy planes.

meanings.definition: the activity of buying and selling shares that are normally traded on the New York Stock Exchange, directly with others rather than using the exchange:
examples: While NYSE volume has been flat, the growth of off-board trading has boosted the total number of trades.

meanings.definition: not having a well-known brand name (= the name given to a product by the company that makes it):
examples: Many teenagers wouldn't consider off-brand sneakers.
Your basic computer operating system is compatible with almost any piece of off-brand software you download.

meanings.definition: not helping a company present the image of itself and its products that it wants to present:
examples: One of the likely times to be off-brand is when customers voice complaints.
They will help your staff develop a better sense of what it means to be on-brand or off-brand.

meanings.definition: situated or performed outside Broadway, the street in New York where most theatres are:
examples: an off-Broadway hit/show/production
The play debuted off-Broadway.

meanings.definition: almost, but not quite, in a central position
nearly, but not quite, in a central position
Off-color remarks or jokes are about sex and are slightly shocking.
slightly sick:
examples: I'm feeling a little off-color today.

meanings.definition: (of remarks, jokes, etc.) rude or offensive to some people
slightly ill:
examples: I'm feeling a bit off-colour today.

meanings.definition: Off-colour remarks or jokes about sex are about sex and are slightly shocking.
When police officers, doctors, guards, etc. are off-duty, they are not working:
examples: He looks completely different when he's off-duty and in his normal clothes.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         off-the-grid

→ 
        
         off-the-grid
someone who lives in a home not connected to any of the main utilities (= electricity, water, etc.) :
examples: Every off-gridder automatically reduces their energy and water consumption by up to 90% compared with a typical household.
Most British off-gridders have tucked themselves away in deeply rural areas.

meanings.definition: the time when someone is not at work:
examples: She spends many of her off-hours at the mall.
I don't believe in blurring the line between employer and employee with off-hours friendship.

meanings.definition: the time that is not the busiest time for a business or service:
examples: Avoid crowds and traffic by shopping during off-hours.
The gym has special off-hour rates during the day.

meanings.definition: the time when a business is closed:
examples: If your child has a tooth knocked out, bring them and the tooth to the dentist or, if it's off-hours, the emergency room.

meanings.definition: If you sing or play music off-key, you produce notes that are slightly higher or lower than they should be:
examples: He sang painfully off-key.
Almost every song was pitched uncomfortably high, and she often fell off-key.

meanings.definition: If a note is off-key, it is played or sung slightly higher or lower than it should be:
examples: She was whistling an off-key tune.
They were ridiculed for their off-key singing throughout the show.

meanings.definition: singing the wrong notes:
examples: He was singing off-key, and it was painful to hear.

meanings.definition: relating to the use of medical drugs in a way that is not officially approved, or for a different purpose than the one they were originally intended for:
examples: A number of off-label uses are probably safe and effective.
Off-label prescribing is a legal practice for physicians.

meanings.definition: (of the use of medical drugs) in a way that is not officially approved, or for a different purpose than the one that the drugs were originally intended for:
examples: It is common — and perfectly legal — for doctors to use their own discretion when prescribing drugs off-label.
Asthma medications are often used off-label but caution should be exercised when giving these to young children.

meanings.definition: used to describe a medical drug that is used for a different purpose than the one it was originally intended for:
examples: Off-label uses may include giving a drug for a disease other than the disease it is approved for, or for treating a child when the product is approved to treat adults.

meanings.definition: a shop that sells mainly alcoholic drinks to be taken away and drunk at home
If an area of land is off-limits, you are not allowed to enter it.
used to describe situations in which shares, etc. are bought and sold in a way that does not involve using a stock market:
examples: The company repurchased its shares in an off-market agreement.

meanings.definition: not at the most popular and expensive time:
examples: off-peak phone calls

meanings.definition: not at the most popular and expensive time, when many people are doing or using a particular thing:
examples: off-peak phone calls
off-peak train times
off-peak hours
Off-peak fares are cheaper prices for travelling on trains that are less busy.

meanings.definition: used to refer to skiing that is done on areas of snow that have not been specially prepared for skiing on:
examples: It is important that skiers take precautions, especially if they go off-piste.

meanings.definition: If you buy a house, apartment, etc. off-plan, you buy it before it is built, when only the plans for it exist:
examples: An estimated 85 per cent of UK investors bought properties in the area off-plan.
The firm claimed to have sold hundreds of the 800 apartments off-plan.

meanings.definition: (of a house, apartment, etc.) bought before it is built, when only the plans for it exist:
examples: If you are going to buy an off-plan apartment, you need to conduct your own market research.
I spent a week in Bulgaria looking at off-plan developments.

meanings.definition: buying houses, apartments, etc. before they are built, when only the plans exist, or relating to this way of buying:
examples: Off-plan buyers who get in early can have a say on interior design.
A lot of new-builds depend on off-plan sales.

meanings.definition: used to describe a store that sells goods for a lower price than at other stores:
examples: an off-price store/shop/retailer

meanings.definition: slightly unpleasant or worrying so that you do not want to get involved in any way:
examples: He's slightly aggressive, which a lot of people find off-putting when they first meet him.
What I found off-putting was the amount of work that you were expected to do.

meanings.definition: in a slightly unpleasant or disturbing (= making you feel worried) way so that you do not want to get involved:
examples: The exhibition sounded off-puttingly pretentious, but in the end I really enjoyed it.
The average house price in this part of the country is off-puttingly high for first-time buyers.

meanings.definition: a short road on which vehicles leave a highway or other main road
relating to or using a vehicle or a bicycle that can be used on rough ground as well as on normal roads:
examples: an off-road mountain bike
an off-road driving experience

meanings.definition: on rough ground, away from normal roads:
examples: He enjoyed the thrill of driving off-road.
Hardly any 4x4s ever go off-road.

meanings.definition: to remove a student from a school roll (= official list of students), especially a difficult or under-achieving student, in order to make the school seem more successful:
examples: There are concerns that some schools may be off-rolling pupils.
Any schools that are off-rolling are likely to be judged inadequate for leadership and management by Ofsted.

meanings.definition: a practice in which a school removes students from its roll (= official list of students), especially difficult or under-achieving students, in order to make the school seem more successful:
examples: A quarter of teachers have seen off-rolling happening in their schools.
The government has made it clear that it considers off-rolling unacceptable.

meanings.definition: in a bar, sales of alcoholic drinks in bottles or other containers, so that you can take them away and drink them at home
(of a perfomer, actor, etc.)when not appearing in a film, on a TV show, etc. :
examples: The actor assumed the role of leader off-screen as well.
He is best known offscreen for spending time at the golf course.
Off screen, he has suffered a series of personal tragedies.

meanings.definition: off the screen, or above, below, or at the side of the screen, so that the people who are watching cannot see :
examples: My car is just off-screen at the bottom right corner of the video.
His first job was off screen as a "voice artist" dubbing films.

meanings.definition: used for describing a performer, actor, etc. when they are not appearing in a film, on a TV show, etc.:
examples: His off-screen exploits led to a complaint being made to the police.
It was Reeve's offscreen actions that made him a superhero in real life.

meanings.definition: off the screen, or happening above, below, or at the side of the screen, so the people watching cannot see:
examples: Seconds later, the cop's ear has been sliced off in an offscreen moment of suggested violence.

meanings.definition: a period of the year when there is less activity in business:
examples: We tend to go skiing during the off-season because it's cheaper.
Off-season rates for a double room are about $50 a night.

meanings.definition: (in sports) the period of the year during which games are not played, between the end of one season and the start of the next
happening in a period of the year when there is less activity in business:
examples: The tourist board has actively sought to attract off-season visitors.

meanings.definition: (in sports) happening in the period of the year during which games are not played, between the end of one season and the start of the next:
examples: off-season training

meanings.definition: in a period of the year when there is less activity in business:
examples: Prices are lowest off-season.

meanings.definition: (in sports) in the period of the year during which games are not played, between the end of one season and the start of the next:
examples: He trained intensively off-season.

meanings.definition: a period of the year when there is less activity in business:
examples: The ski resort closes completely in the off-season.

meanings.definition: away from the place where people are working or involved in a particular activity:
examples: It is more difficult to manage off-site employees.
The next time the meeting had to be held off site.
There is no secure way for data to be taken offsite.
Contaminated soil is excavated and either treated or shipped off-site.

meanings.definition: a meeting or other event that happens away from an office building, factory, etc.:
examples: Most business events are physical gatherings: off-sites at posh resorts, training seminars at conference centres.
I know a great place for an offsite.

meanings.definition: not working or happening in a particular office, factory, etc. but somewhere else:
examples: It is more difficult to manage off-site employees.

Some 75% of the fastfood chain's meals are eaten off-site.

meanings.definition: In baseball, an off-speed pitch is an occasion when the pitcher does not throw the ball as fast as they can:
examples: She was able to confuse the batters with a variety of off-speed pitches.
He struck out chasing an off-speed delivery.

meanings.definition: not on a public road or street:
examples: Businesses must have off-street parking, according to the zoning code.
They want restaurants, bars, and hotels to provide enough off-street spaces to serve 25 percent of the establishment's seating capacity.

meanings.definition: not connected to the main electricity grid (= system of connected wires and power stations):
examples: Solar power is useful in off-the-grid areas.

meanings.definition: not connected to any of the main utilities (= electricity, water, etc.) and having your own power and water supply:
examples: We're interested in independent self-sufficient living, off-the-grid.

meanings.definition: not connected to the public supply of electricity, gas, etc.:
examples: These are innovative green homes for an alternative off-the-grid lifestyle.

meanings.definition: Off-the-job training happens away from the place of work.
happening away from the usual place where someone works:
examples: off-the-job training.

meanings.definition: not made especially to fit a particular person or suit a situation:

unusual and strange and therefore surprising or noticeable:

It's the third time that he's been convicted of a drug offence.

meanings.definition: upset and hurt or annoyed feelings, often because someone has been rude or shown no respect:

meanings.definition: the part of a game such as American football that involves trying to score points, or the players who try to score points

meanings.definition: feelings of being upset and angry, often because someone has been rude:
examples: This advertisement may cause offence in some markets.

meanings.definition: to make someone upset or angry:

meanings.definition: to commit a crime:

meanings.definition: to make someone upset and angry by something you say or do:
examples: The store refused to stock the book in case it might offend customers.

meanings.definition: to break a rule or principle or not fit well with something that people consider to be correct:
examples: Would it be offending against good taste to wear a patterned tie with my striped shirt?

meanings.definition: upset and angry, often because someone has been rude:

meanings.definition: unpleasant:

meanings.definition: in a sports event, trying to score points, goals, etc.:

meanings.definition: a planned military attack:

meanings.definition: relating to or being a planned military attack:

meanings.definition: causing someone to be upset or to have hurt feelings:

meanings.definition: Offensive can be used more generally to mean unpleasant:

meanings.definition: causing someone to feel upset and angry, often because of being rude:
examples: His comments were highly offensive to women.

meanings.definition: the players on the offence on an American football team who stand behind the line of scrimmage (= the line on which the ball is positioned at the beginning of each piece of action) :
examples: The quarterback and the running back make up part of the offensive backfield.
Both players were starters in the team's offensive backfield.

meanings.definition: the area on an American football field behind the offence's line of scrimmage:
examples: Some teams use a fullback in the offensive backfield to block for the running back.
There was a hold committed by a player in the offensive backfield, which negated the play with a penalty.

meanings.definition: in basketball, a rebound (= a ball that misses the goal and is able to be taken by any player) that is caught by the team that attempted the shot:
examples: She has a knack for being in the right spot on the floor to grab an offensive rebound.
The team had 15 offensive rebounds in the first half, which gave them many extra chances to score.

meanings.definition: a player on the offence of an American football team who stands at the line of scrimmage (= the line on which the ball is positioned at the beginning of each piece of action) and blocks players from tackling the player who is carrying the ball :
examples: He was a standout offensive tackle on his college football team.
The offensive tackle was called for a holding penalty that cost his team ten yards.

meanings.definition: in a way that is likely to upset, annoy, or embarrass someone:
examples: His comments were offensively patronizing.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to getting points in a sport, rather than stopping the other player or team getting points:
examples: Joey's got more ability than both of those guys offensively.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to attacking someone or something:
examples: The weapon had been used offensively.

meanings.definition: the quality of causing offence:
examples: Reid has apologized for the offensiveness of his comments.
Racism, sexism and other offensiveness are not welcome.

meanings.definition: to ask someone if they would like to have something or if they would like you to do something:
examples: I feel bad that I didn't offer them any food/offer any food to them.
She was offered a job in Paris.
Can I offer you (= would you like) a drink?

"I'll do the cooking," he offered.

meanings.definition: to say a prayer or make a sacrifice (= an act of killing or giving up something) to a god:
examples: Dear Lord, we offer up our prayers...

meanings.definition: to provide or supply something:
examples: It's an organization that offers free legal advice to people on low incomes.
It says in the guide that this area offers some of the best walks in England.

infml someone who has lived a long time, or who has lived or worked in a place for a long time
used to describe things that make you think of a time long ago:
examples: The band played a couple of Cajun tunes and then some old-timey jazz and blues.
The chain of old-timey restaurants has been surprisingly successful.

meanings.definition: old in a very noticeable or artificial way, or made to look old in a way that seems false:
examples: The village is a bit too olde-worlde and more of a museum than a thriving community.

meanings.definition: from a long time ago:
examples: There weren't things like televisions and computers in the olden days.
In olden times, people rarely travelled.

meanings.definition: from a long time ago:
examples: olden times/days

meanings.definition: an old popular song:
examples: golden oldies from the 60s

meanings.definition: an old person
someone or something, esp. a song, movie, or joke, that was popular long ago:
examples: That radio station plays only golden oldies.

meanings.definition: quite old:
examples: "Is she old?" "Oldish - late sixties, maybe."

meanings.definition: an informal way of saying and writing "old":
examples: Who helped him? His good ole dad.

meanings.definition: extremely polite, kind, or helpful in a false way that is intended to bring some advantage to yourself
an evergreen Mediterranean tree or bush (= one that never loses its leaves) with strong leaves and white, red, or pink flowers
the end part of the ulna (= a long thin bone in the lower arm) at the elbow:
examples: The olecranon forms the point of the elbow.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for organic light-emitting diode: a type of diode (= a device that controls an electric current so that it can only flow in one direction) that contains an organic compound (= a chemical that combines two or more elements including carbon) and produces light. OLEDs are used in screens to produce very bright, clear pictures:
examples: The OLED consists of two charged electrodes sandwiched on top of some organic light-emitting material.
An OLED screen offers extraordinary contrast and very little motion blur.

meanings.definition: a type of margarine (= food used for cooking and spreading on bread, made with vegetable oil):
examples: A lot of older recipes call for Oleo - young folks don't know it's margarine.
Sauté the celery and onion in oleo.
He claimed that you couldn't tell oleomargarine from butter.

meanings.definition: a brand name for an artificially produced substance that replaces fat in some foods
a brand name for an artificially produced substance that replaces fat in some foods
the action of smelling, or the ability to smell
connected with the ability to smell:
examples: the olfactory nerve

meanings.definition: one of two small, rounded areas attached to the front of the brain on each side where the olfactory nerves end, that form part of the olfactory lobe and are involved in the ability to smell:
examples: Information about a smell goes from receptors in the nose to the olfactory bulb in the brain.
Sharks have very large olfactory bulbs, so we know that odour plays a major role in finding prey.

meanings.definition: either of two areas at the front of the brain on each side that are involved in the ability to smell:
examples: The olfactory lobe is the centre of the sense of smell, and this lobe is highly developed in animals such as foxes and dogs.
The olfactory lobe is situated under the inferior surface of the frontal lobe.

meanings.definition: either of a pair of cranial nerves that send signals from the nose to the olfactory bulb (= an area at the front of the brain involved in the ability to smell):
examples: Olfactory nerve cells are stimulated by odours.
The olfactory nerves are among the smallest known and are particularly sensitive to infection.

meanings.definition: someone who is extremely rich and powerful, especially a person from Russia who became rich after the end of the former Soviet Union:
examples: The Russian oligarchs spent money on London real estate.
The football club was bought by a Russian oligarch in 2003.

meanings.definition: one of the people in an oligarchy (= a government or society controlled by a small group of very powerful people):
examples: The government of the Corinthian State was an oligarchy, and the oligarchs had control over the State.

meanings.definition: one of a small group of powerful people who control a country or an industry:
examples: He tells the story of the new Russian oligarchs and how they amassed enormous fortunes when the Soviet Union broke up.

meanings.definition: relating to an oligarchy (= a small group of powerful people who control or rule a country or an organization):
examples: Oligarchic governments ruling over corrupt states are still too common.
One of the biggest problems with the movie industry is that it is fundamentally oligarchic.

meanings.definition: government by a small group of very powerful people:
examples: A lot of people in the country were seeing the dangers of oligarchy.
The country had to decide whether it wanted to continue on its path of transition or to follow the path of the rule of oligarchy.

meanings.definition: a small group of very powerful people that controls a government or society:
examples: The powerful socio-economic oligarchy tried to preserve its privileged status.
The country is run by a self-selecting oligarchy with little regard for the rules of law and natural justice.

meanings.definition: a country with a government that is an oligarchy:
examples: He denied that the country had become an oligarchy.

meanings.definition: a government in which power is held by a small group of people
the fact of a country being ruled or controlled by a small group of powerful people:
examples: The real difference between oligarchy and democracy is wealth.

meanings.definition: a country or industry that is controlled by a small group of powerful people, or these people considered as a group:
examples: The electricity industry has moved from being a state monopoly to being a de facto oligarchy.

meanings.definition: from or referring to the period of time between about 34 and 23 million years ago:
examples: Fossils of an especially rich array of Oligocene mammals have been unearthed here.
Fossilized leaves may provide information on elevation changes since the end of the Oligocene period.

meanings.definition: cells in the nervous system that produce myelin (= a substance that surrounds and protects nerves):
examples: During the early postnatal period, these axons are wrapped in the insulating substance myelin, produced by oligodendroglia.
Without the oligodendroglia cells forming myelin, nerve signals would become slowed or even completely blocked.

meanings.definition: relating to oligodendroglia (= cells in the nervous system that produce myelin to surround and protect nerves):
examples: Myelination is a process where oligodendroglial cells surround axons in an insulating material.
The myelin is defective, probably the consequence of oligodendroglial loss.

meanings.definition: a situation in which a small number of organizations or companies has control of an area of business, so that others have no share

a situation in which only a small number of companies are involved in producing a particular type of goods or in providing a particular type of service. The group of companies itself is also referred to as an oligopoly:
examples: Some say that Swedish banking is an oligopoly: the big four banks control 89% of total banking assets.

meanings.definition: a small bitter green or black fruit that is eaten or used to produce oil, or a Mediterranean tree on which this fruit grows:
examples: olive groves

meanings.definition: a small, oval fruit eaten raw or cooked or pressed to make oil, or the evergreen tree on which this fruit grows
Olive is also a dark, yellow-green color.
something that you say or do in order to show that you want to end a disagreement with someone:
examples: to hold out/offer/extend an olive branch
He held out an olive branch to the opposition by releasing 42 political prisoners.

meanings.definition: a greyish-green colour that is often used for military uniforms
the colour of green olives
of the colour of green olives:
examples: an olive-green uniform

meanings.definition: a yellow or green oil, made by pressing olives
the growing of olive trees (= trees that produce small bitter green or black fruit called olives ):
examples: Oliviculture is the predominant feature of the landscape and economy of the area.
He wrote a paper on pest control in organic oliviculture.

meanings.definition: used to form adjectives; belonging or relating to a particular type of scientific study:
examples: biological
technological

meanings.definition: used to form nouns; an expert in a particular area of scientific study:
examples: archaeologist

meanings.definition: a subject that is studied at school, college, or university and is thought to need a large amount of special knowledge:
examples: "What's his new girlfriend studying?" "Oh, some ology or other. Pharmacology, I think."

meanings.definition: the scientific study of a particular subject:
examples: geology
climatology

meanings.definition: an occasion on which the Olympic Games are held
having the qualities of a god:
examples: She has maintained an Olympian detachment from (= avoided being involved with and worried by) the everyday business of the office.

meanings.definition: a competitor in the Olympic Games
a competitor in the Olympics
of or relating to the Olympics:
examples: the International Olympic Committee
an Olympic gold medallist

meanings.definition: a national park (= a large area of land protected by the government because of its natural beauty or because it has a special history) in the US state of Washington:
examples: Olympic National Park became a World Heritage Site in 1981.
Port Angeles has numerous boating facilities and is the gateway to Olympic National Park.

meanings.definition: a country in Western Asia
belonging to or relating to Oman or its people
a person from Oman
abbreviation for Office of Management and Budget: in the US, a government organization that helps the president prepare and control the annual budget
having different shades (= strengths) of colour, gradually going from light to dark:
examples: a beautiful silk blouse in a stunning ombré pink print
Ombré hair extensions will add length, volume, and highlights to your hair.

meanings.definition: someone who works for a government or large organization and deals with the complaints made against it:
examples: Complaints to the Banking Ombudsman grew by 50 percent last year.

meanings.definition: someone who works for a government or large organization and deals with the complaints made against it
an official who deals with the complaints made by the public against the government, or against organizations such as banks or insurance companies:
examples: A long list of complaints was submitted to the financial ombudsman.
I was advised to send my complaint to the banking ombudsman.

meanings.definition: the 24th and last letter of the Greek alphabet
a substance in the oil from some fish such as tuna and salmon and in some seeds, thought to be good for your health
a dish made by mixing eggs together and frying them, often with small pieces of other food such as cheese or vegetables:
examples: a cheese/mushroom omelet

meanings.definition: eggs with their yellow and transparent parts mixed together, cooked in a pan, and usually folded over some other food:
examples: a cheese/mushroom omelet

meanings.definition: a dish made by mixing eggs together and frying them, often with small pieces of other food such as cheese or vegetables:
examples: a cheese/mushroom omelette

meanings.definition: something that is considered to be a sign of how a future event will take place:
examples: The team's final victory of the season is a good omen for the playoffs, which start next week.
a bad omen
Many people believe that a broken mirror is an omen of bad luck.

meanings.definition: an event that is thought to tell something about the future:
examples: Scoring that goal was an omen of things to come.

meanings.definition: relating to the omentum (= the layer of tissue around the stomach and intestines)
the layer of tissue around the stomach and intestines
abbreviation for Oh my God: used when someone is surprised or excited about something:
examples: And then, omg, I saw Johnny Depp in Starbucks!

meanings.definition: the 15th letter of the Greek alphabet
suggesting that something unpleasant is likely to happen:
examples: There was an ominous silence when I asked whether my contract was going to be renewed.
The engine had been making an ominous sound all the way from my parents' house.
ominous dark clouds

meanings.definition: suggesting something unpleasant will happen:
examples: an ominous silence

meanings.definition: in a way that suggests that something unpleasant is likely to happen:
examples: I went into the kitchen and found him lying ominously still on the floor.
"I'm waiting," Evelyn said ominously.

meanings.definition: the act of not including something or someone that should have been included, or something or someone that has not been included that should have been:
examples: Measures to control child employment are a glaring (= very obvious) omission from new legislation to protect children.
There are some serious errors and omissions in the book.
The fans believed that the omission of Heacock from the team was a serious mistake.

meanings.definition: the fact of not including something that should have been included, or the thing that is not included:
examples: We are not responsible for the omission of information from this website.
The document contained a lot of errors, omissions, and exaggerations.

meanings.definition: to fail to include or do something:
examples: She was omitted from the list of contributors to the report.
The Prince's tour conveniently omitted the most deprived areas of the city.
She omitted to mention that she would be away next week.

meanings.definition: to fail to include or do something:
examples: I’d be upset if my name were omitted from the list of contributors.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         omit

present participle of 
        
         omit
everywhere or everything:
examples: omnipresent
omniscient

meanings.definition: a book consisting of two or more parts that have already been published separately
a programme consisting of two or more parts that have already been broadcast separately:
examples: the omnibus edition of a soap opera

meanings.definition: a bus
used to refer to a way of selling products that is the same and equally good for the customer whether they are buying from a computer, a mobile phone app, etc., or in a physical shop:
examples: Omni-channel retailing is a new concept in which all sales and interaction channels are considered together.
Customers interacting with an omni-channel experience spent 4% more in-store and 10% more online.

meanings.definition: used to describe an antenna (= a piece of electronic equipment that connects radio or computer networks) that can receive or send signals in all directions
unlimited power and the ability to do anything:
examples: God's omnipotence
He doesn't believe in the omnipotence of science.

meanings.definition: having unlimited power and able to do anything:
examples: How can a loving, omnipotent God permit disease, war and suffering?

meanings.definition: having the power to do anything:
examples: The people overthrew the once omnipotent dictator.

meanings.definition: in a way that is omnipotent (= having unlimited power and able to do anything):
examples: Christians believe that God omnipotently created Man from the elements of the earth.
In this video game, you play the role of an emperor who can omnipotently control his lands and people.

meanings.definition: the fact of being present or having an effect everywhere at the same time:
examples: the omnipresence of the secret police
The world has grown accustomed to the omnipresence of global brands.

meanings.definition: present or having an effect everywhere at the same time:
examples: The singer became an omnipresent icon of style and beauty.

meanings.definition: the quality of having or seeming to have unlimited knowledge:
examples: I do not claim omniscience, nor am I incapable of making mistakes.
The biographer lacks the novelist's omniscience.

meanings.definition: having or seeming to have unlimited knowledge:
examples: God is omniscient.

meanings.definition: having or seeming to have unlimited knowledge:
examples: They give the impression that the magazine is omniscient.

meanings.definition: the voice in which a story is written that is outside the story and knows everything about the characters and events in the story
the voice in which a story is written that is outside the story and that knows everything about the characters and events in the story
in a way that is omniscient (= having or seeming to have unlimited knowledge):
examples: She believed that God omnisciently watched all her actions and thoughts.
This story is narrated omnisciently so that we hear the thoughts of both of the main characters.

meanings.definition: a situation that is bad in many different ways, because things have been organized badly and serious mistakes have been made:
examples: The implementation of the new policy was branded an "omnishambles" by the Opposition spokesperson on education.

meanings.definition: a bicycle racing event consisting of several races of different distances and types, done over several days in a velodrome (= a track for bicycle racing with steeply sloping sides)
an animal that is naturally able to eat both plants and meat
an organism that eats both plant and animal matter
naturally able to eat both plants and meat:
examples: Pigs are omnivorous animals.

meanings.definition: enthusiastic and interested in many different areas of a subject:
examples: an omnivorous reader

meanings.definition: eating both plants and meat:
examples: Bears are omnivorous.

meanings.definition: in a way that is enthusiastic and interested in many different areas of a subject:
examples: She has been reading omnivorously since the age of 12.
His collection of old postcards is omnivorously eclectic.

meanings.definition: relating to the shoulder and the hyoid bone (= a bone in the front of the neck)
used to show that something is in a position above something else and touching it, or that something is moving into such a position:
examples: Look at all the books on your desk!
Ow, you're standing on my foot!
Your suitcase is on top of the wardrobe.
They live in that old house on the hill.
I got on my bike and left.

meanings.definition: covering the surface of, being held by, or connected to something:
examples: There's blood on your shirt.
Which finger do you wear your ring on?
Can you stand on your head?
We could hang this picture on the wall next to the door.
Dogs should be kept on their leashes at all times.
We've just moved house and we're not on the phone (= not connected to the phone service) yet.

meanings.definition: used to show when something happens:
examples: Hair salons don't usually open on Sundays.
What are you doing on Friday?
My birthday's on 30 May.
Would you mind telling me what you were doing on the afternoon of Friday the 13th of March?
The bells in the clock tower ring every hour on the hour (= at exactly one o'clock, two o'clock, etc.).
On a clear day you can see the mountains from here.
She was dead on arrival (= dead when she arrived) at the hospital.
Please leave your key at the reception desk on your departure from (= when you leave) the hotel.

meanings.definition: used to show where something has been written, printed, or drawn:
examples: Which page is that curry recipe on?
His initials were engraved on the back of his watch.
What's on the menu tonight? (= What food is available?)

meanings.definition: used for showing some methods of travelling:
examples: I love travelling on trains.
She's coming in on the 5.30 bus.
We went to France on the ferry.
It'd be quicker to get there on foot.
two figures on horseback
