meanings.definition: used to show that a condition or process is being experienced:
examples: He accidentally set his bed on fire.
Max's on holiday (US vacation) this week.
I often get carsick when I'm on a long journey.
Crime is on the increase (= is increasing) again.
Their flights to Paris are on special offer at the moment.
I'll be away on a training course next week.

meanings.definition: used to show the form in which something is recorded or performed:
examples: How much data can you store on the flash drive?
When's the movie coming out on DVD?
I was really embarrassed the first time I saw myself on film.
What's on TV tonight?
I wish there was more jazz on the radio.

meanings.definition: used to show what causes pain or injury as a result of being touched:
examples: I hit my head on the shelf as I was standing up.
Be careful not to cut yourself on that knife.

meanings.definition: to or towards:
examples: Our house is the first on the left after the post office.
The attack on the village lasted all night.
I wish you wouldn't sneak up on me like that!

meanings.definition: relating to:
examples: a book on pregnancy
Her talk is on Italian women's literature.
The minister has refused to comment on the allegations.
Criticism has no effect on him.
Do the police have anything on you (= do they have any information about you that can be used against you)?

meanings.definition: used to show something for which a payment is made:
examples: He spent €180 on a hat.
I've wasted a lot of money on this car.
We made a big profit on that deal.
How much interest are you paying on the loan?

meanings.definition: used to show a person or thing that is necessary for something to happen or that is the origin of something:
examples: We're relying on you.
I might come - it depends on Andrew.
Most children remain dependent on their parents while they are at university.
His latest movie is based on a fairy tale.

meanings.definition: used to show when someone is involved or taking part in something:
examples: I'm working on a new book.
"Where had we got up to?" "We were on page 42."

meanings.definition: used to show what is providing financial support or an income:
examples: I only have $70 a week to live on at the moment.
He retired on a generous pension from the company.
She's on (= earning) £25,000 a year.

meanings.definition: used to show something that is used as food, fuel, or a drug:
examples: What do mice live on?
Does this radio run on batteries?
Is he on drugs?

meanings.definition: next to or along the side of:
examples: It's a small town on the Mississippi River.
Our house was on Sturton Street.
Strasbourg is on the border of France and Germany.

meanings.definition: used to show when someone is a member of a group or organization:
examples: Have you ever served on a jury?
There are no women on the committee.
How many people are on your staff?
She's a researcher on a women's magazine.

meanings.definition: used when referring to a tool, instrument, or system that is used to do something:
examples: I do all my household accounts on the computer.
Chris is on drums and Mike's on bass guitar.
I'm on (= talking on) the phone.

meanings.definition: used to show when something is repeated one or more times:
examples: The government suffered defeat on defeat in the local elections.
Wave on wave of refugees has crossed the border to escape the fighting.

meanings.definition: used when making a comparison:
examples: That's my final offer, and I can't improve on it.
The manufacturer has never improved on the earliest model of the car.
The productivity figures are down/up on last week's.

meanings.definition: used to show when someone has something in a pocket or in a bag that they are carrying:
examples: Do you have a spare pen on you?
I don't have my driving licence on me.

meanings.definition: happening after and usually because of:
examples: Acting on information given to them anonymously, the police arrested him.
He inherited a quarter of a million pounds on his mother's death.
On their return they discovered that their house had been broken into.

meanings.definition: used to show who is paying for something:
examples: Dinner meal is on me.
She had her operation done on the National Health Service.

meanings.definition: used to show who suffers when something does not operate as it should:
examples: The phone suddenly went dead on me.
Their car broke down on them on the way home.

meanings.definition: used to show the number of points a person or team has in a competition:
examples: Clive's team is on five points while Joan's is on seven.

meanings.definition: on your body or someone's body:
examples: It's very cold so put a coat on.
She wanders around the house with nothing on.
Can you remember what he had on (= was wearing)?
I tried on a few jackets, but none of them looked nice.

meanings.definition: covering the surface of something or connected to something:
examples: Screw the lid on tightly.
Surgeons managed to sew the finger back on.

meanings.definition: used to show when something is operating or starting to operate:
examples: Could you switch on the radio?
Would you turn the TV on?
You left the bedroom light on.

meanings.definition: continuing or not stopping:
examples: The referee waved at the player to play on.
Read on to discover the amazing properties of coconut water.
The police officers shook their heads and drove on.
When Jenny walks the dog, she ignores his hunting behaviour and just walks on till he comes back.

meanings.definition: into a bus, train, plane, etc., or in the correct position to start using some other method of travelling:
examples: The train suddenly started moving as I was getting on.
Her horse galloped off as soon as she was on.

meanings.definition: performing:
examples: Hurry up with the make-up - I'm on in ten minutes.
The audience cheered as the band came on (= came onto the stage).

meanings.definition: continuing forward in time or space:
examples: They never spoke to each other from that day on (= after that day).
What are you doing later on?
When you're done with it, would you pass it on to Paul?
Move on, please, and let the ambulance through.
You cycle on and I'll meet you there.

meanings.definition: happening or planned:
examples: Is the party still on for tomorrow?
I'm busy tomorrow, but I've got nothing on the day after.
I've got a lot on at the moment.
Food had to be rationed when the war was on.
Are there any good movies on (= being shown) this week?

meanings.definition: used when talking about the position of one thing compared with the position of another:
examples: It's amazing nobody was injured because the two buses crashed head on (= the front parts of the buses hit each other).
The bike hit our car side on (= hit the side of the car rather than the front or back).
It would be easier to get the bookcase through the doorway if we turned it sideways on (= turned it so that one of its sides is at the front).

meanings.definition: in cricket, the left side of the field for a right-handed batter or the right side of the field for a left-handed batter:
examples: The captain moved the fielder from off to on.
She tapped the ball into the on side and ran through for a single.

meanings.definition: supported by or resting at the top of another thing:
examples: There is snow on the ground.
You put pudding in the pie crust and then put whipped cream on.

meanings.definition: attached to or forming a part of another thing:
examples: Read the instructions on the bag.
Hang your coat on that hook.
Don’t screw the lid on so tight.

meanings.definition: covering or wrapping another thing:
examples: The child had no shoes on her feet.
You should put a coat on.
The baby’s got nothing on (= is not wearing anything).

meanings.definition: being broadcast:
examples: What’s on TV tonight?
I wish there were more jazz on the radio.

meanings.definition: used to show a method of travel; via:
examples: It’s easy to get to the beach on foot.
Two people rode by on horseback.

meanings.definition: On is also sometimes used to show you are getting in a vehicle:
examples: It’s time to get on the bus.

meanings.definition: at, near, or next to a particular place, thing, or person:
examples: They live on Carlisle Street.
Which page is that cheesecake recipe on?
El Paso is on the Mexican border.
Princess Caroline was seated on my left.

meanings.definition: used to show the form in which information is stored or recorded for use with an electronic device:
examples: How much data can you store on your hard disk?
That movie just came out on video.

meanings.definition: showing what tool, instrument, system, etc., is used to do or achieve something:
examples: I made this chart on my computer.
I’m on the telephone.
You’ll cut yourself on that knife if you’re not careful.

meanings.definition: showing that a drug is taken or used:
examples: My doctor put me on antibiotics.

meanings.definition: used after some verbs and adjectives to show that help is needed from a person or thing:
examples: We’re counting on you to drive us to the airport.

meanings.definition: used to show that a condition or process exists or is being experienced:
examples: The musicians are on strike.
Are winter coats on sale?

meanings.definition: involved in or doing a particular thing:
examples: I’m working on a new book.
She’s on a diet.

meanings.definition: On is also used to show that someone is doing something he or she was chosen to do:
examples: There was a guard on duty.

meanings.definition: connected with or part of a group or process:
examples: Have you ever served on a jury?
There are two women on the committee.

meanings.definition: about or having something as a subject:
examples: Did you see that documentary on volcanoes last night?
Sarita’s thesis is on George Crumb.

meanings.definition: showing that something is paid for or how something is paid for:
examples: I’ve wasted a lot of money on this car.
Lunch is on me.

meanings.definition: used to show when something happens:
examples: What are you doing on Friday?
My birthday’s on May 30th.
The flight arrived on time (= at the time it was expected).

meanings.definition: used to make a comparison:
examples: This week’s sales figures are down on last week’s.
He’s got two inches on me (= is two inches taller).

meanings.definition: used to show that something has happened to someone:
examples: Marty is always playing jokes on people.
My car broke down on me this morning.

meanings.definition: possessing, carrying, or having something with you now:
examples: Do you have any money on you?
I don’t have my driver’s license on me.

meanings.definition: continuing or not stopping:
examples: If her line’s busy, keep on trying.

meanings.definition: toward or to something or someone:
examples: You go on and I’ll meet you at the lake.
Pass the newsletter on to Emily.

meanings.definition: operating or made to start operating:
examples: Would you turn the TV on?
The electricity hasn’t been turned back on yet.

meanings.definition: infml Someone who is on is either performing very well or is in a situation where the person must be aware of everything that is happening and be ready to act:
examples: Andy was really on last night – I haven’t heard him sing like that in months.

meanings.definition: happening or planned:
examples: I have nothing on for tomorrow.
Is the party still on?

meanings.definition: because you suddenly want to, although you haven't planned to:
examples: "I didn't know you were looking for some new shoes." "Oh, I wasn't - I just bought them on impulse."
She decided, on an impulse, to get in touch with some of her old classmates.
On an impulse, he went into the florist's and bought a huge bunch of roses.
He called Judy on impulse and invited her to lunch.
Acting on impulse, she grabbed her camera and ran after the man.

meanings.definition: If goods in a shop are on (special) offer, they are being sold at a lower price than usual:
examples: Strawberries were on special offer today so I bought loads of them.
Try not to buy stuff you don't need just because it's on offer.
I usually wait till they're on special offer and then stock up.
I notice champagne is on offer this week.
It has some really good wines on offer at the moment.

meanings.definition: only if:
examples: I'll come to the party on the condition that you don't wear those ridiculous trousers!
They offered me a job on the condition that I did some further training.
The World Bank reduced the country's loan payments on condition that they spent the savings on healthcare and education.
We were invited to the meeting on the condition that we agreed to keep the proceedings confidential.
He agreed to speak to the newspaper on condition that they didn't use his name.

meanings.definition: usually or often between Friday evening and Sunday night, or on Saturdays and Sundays:
examples: They go windsurfing on weekends.
What do you usually do on weekends?
This place gets really crowded on the weekends.
I rarely eat a full breakfast except on weekends.
She usually stays with her dad on the weekends and is with her mom during the week.
On weekends, I'm often the only one here.

meanings.definition: careful and aware because a situation might be dangerous:
examples: Passengers on public transportation were warned to be on their guard against pickpockets.

meanings.definition: on a day without clouds, mist, or fog in the sky, so that you can see for a long way:
examples: The coast of France is not that far away and you can make it out on a clear day.
On a clear day, you get a fantastic view of the mountains.

meanings.definition: having very different aims or opinions and therefore likely to strongly disagree or fight:
examples: The governor put himself on a collision course with state lawmakers over energy policy.

meanings.definition: doing a set of classes or a plan of study on a particular subject, often in order to take an exam or obtain a qualification:
examples: We had a student teacher because our regular teacher was on a course.
I was sent on a course by my company, to learn how to become better at public speaking.

meanings.definition: If two people are on a date, they are meeting as part of a romantic relationship or to possibly start a romantic relationship:
examples: He asked her out on a date.
We went out on a date to the cinema.

meanings.definition: eating less food, or only particular types of food, because you want to become thinner or for medical reasons:
examples: I always crave chocolate when I'm on a diet.
Her bones have been weakened by the chemo, so it is important to keep her on a diet high in calcium.

meanings.definition: If a vehicle, etc. can turn, stop, etc. on a dime, it can turn, etc. in a very small space:
examples: The high-tech steering means that even huge tractors can turn on a dime.

meanings.definition: friendly or familiar enough with someone to call that person by their first name:
examples: Staff and pupils at the school were on a first-name basis.
She was on a first-name basis with most of her customers.
Her family connections put her on a first-name basis with most of the royalty in Europe.
I ordered food from there so often that I was on a first-name basis with the woman who answered the phone.
Very soon, everyone was on a first-name basis.

meanings.definition: having recently eaten:
examples: Never go swimming on a full stomach.
The tablets are not to be taken on a full stomach.
In any case, strenuous exercise on a full stomach is a bad idea.
I don't like going to bed on a full stomach.
I would never go running on a full stomach.
He says you shouldn't meditate on a full stomach.

meanings.definition: If you tell people something on a need-to-know basis, you only tell them the facts they need to know at the time they need to know them, and nothing more.
the same as or equal to someone or something:
examples: The regeneration of the city's downtown dock front will put it on a par with Nice or Cannes.
Property in this bustling city is valued even higher, almost on a par with London.
Her writing at its best is considered to be on a par with Charles Dickens.
At this rate, they'll have 600,000 visitors to the exhibition, which will put it on a par with the Van Gogh exhibition.
The country has over 500 resorts, placing it on a par with France.

meanings.definition: in a very uncertain and dangerous situation:
examples: Allegations of fraud have put the politician's career on a razor edge.

meanings.definition: infml experiencing a period of success or good luck:
examples: They’ve won nine games in a row, so they’re obviously on a roll.

meanings.definition: If you do something on a shoestring, you do it with a very small amount of money:
examples: The film was made on a shoestring.

meanings.definition: having a period of success:
examples: The Sox finished the season on a tear, winning 70% of their last 66 games.
The markets took off on a tear and rarely looked back for another nine years.
Sales of electric bicycles are suddenly on a tear.
The industry has been on a tear, building new plants all over the country.
I knew I had to get on a tear to have any chance of beating him.

on-a-wing-and-a-prayer.name: on a wing and a prayer

meanings.definition: If you do something on a wing and a prayer, you do it hoping that you will succeed, although you are not prepared enough for it:
examples: With hardly any funding and a staff of six, they were operating on a wing and a prayer.

meanings.definition: because of something:
examples: He doesn't drink alcohol on account of his poor health.
Organizers were forced to cancel the event on account of the extremely hot weather.
She was chosen as commencement speaker on account of the fact that she was an alumna of the school.
Dinner was somewhat delayed on account of David's rather tardy arrival.

meanings.definition: fighting in a war:
examples: He was the first member of his regiment to die while on active service.
He was killed on active service in the Second World War.
Later that year he was posted abroad on active service.
She was injured while in active service.
At the time, her father was away on active service in Belgium.
He was informed that he would be going on active service overseas.

meanings.definition: If one team beats another on aggregate, it wins after adding together the goals in two or more matches:
examples: Arsenal lost the second game, but got through to the final on aggregate.
They lost one-nil at Barcelona last night, but qualify three-one on aggregate.
Millwall lost the game 3-1 and went out on aggregate.
The penalty was missed and his team lost on aggregate.
After 90 minutes it was 2-2 on aggregate.

meanings.definition: in every aspect or in every part of a discussion or argument:
examples: I'm afraid I disagree with you on all counts.
The opening match should please the organizers of the tournament on all counts.

meanings.definition: referring to all of the crimes that a person is accused of:
examples: The jury found the defendant guilty on all counts.
If convicted on all counts, she could face a jail sentence of five years.

meanings.definition: with your hands and knees on the ground:
examples: You'll have to get down on all fours to clean behind the toilet.

meanings.definition: having both knees and hands on the ground:
examples: Shirelle was on all fours, looking for her contact lens.

meanings.definition: If you do something on an ad hoc basis, you do it only when you need to and in a way that is not planned before it happens:
examples: We deal with problems on an ad hoc basis.
Our finance committee is a standing committee, but we only convene our conference committee on an ad hoc basis.

meanings.definition: without eating anything:
examples: You should never go to work on an empty stomach.

meanings.definition: when you have not eaten anything:
examples: Never take this medicine on an empty stomach.

meanings.definition: regular and well-balanced and not likely to change suddenly:
examples: The new manager succeeded in putting the business back on an even keel.

meanings.definition: If something happens on and off during a period of time, it happens sometimes:
examples: I've had toothache on and off for a couple of months.

meanings.definition: continuing for a long time:
examples: The noise just went on and on.

meanings.definition: If you buy something on approval, you can return it without payment if it is not satisfactory:
examples: The new manager introduced the practice of shipping items on approval.
They went into town and got two digital radios on approval.
Librarians often want to see books before they order them, so the system of obtaining copies on approval is common.
There are specific tax rules for goods supplied on approval.
There is an element of trust involved when retailers send out goods on approval.

meanings.definition: Someone who is on assignment is doing a particular job or piece of work, usually in a particular place where they have been sent for a period of time:
examples: Both journalists were killed while on assignment in the region.
He was on assignment for the New Yorker, where he was a photographer.
Her husband, a helicopter pilot, had been on assignment in Iraq for over seven months.
She told people she was in the area on assignment.
He was suffering from a disease he contracted while on assignment in Panama.

meanings.definition: doing something without thinking about it or without making an effort:
examples: I worked the last hour of my shift on autopilot.

meanings.definition: usually:
examples: On average, a person’s income is highest when they are in their mid-50s.
The city's police chief says they arrest, on average, 300 people each day.

meanings.definition: requested for a future time when it or they will be available to buy:
examples: "We have dozens of copies on back order", said the bookshop manager.
She said the masks are on back order and may not arrive for some time.
We have lots more copies of the book on back order, so it's best to reserve a copy.
Fifty of the aircraft are in service, with over two thousand more on back order.
The manager told us that their coal stoves are on back order until June.

meanings.definition: If someone who has been accused of a crime is on bail, they have been released until their trial because they have paid an amount of money to a law court. The payment is a way of making certain that the person will return to court for trial:
examples: He was out on bail awaiting trial.
He was free on bail awaiting trial when he committed the offences.

meanings.definition: after considering the power or influence of both sides of a question:
examples: The job offer had some advantages, but on balance he thought he was better off where he was.

meanings.definition: done for another person’s benefit or support, or because you are representing the interests of that person:
examples: I’d like to say on behalf of the whole group that we wish you well in your new job.

meanings.definition: in a position in which the knee of one leg is touching the floor:
examples: He went down on bended knee to ask her to marry him.
He expects politicians to go to him on bended knee for approval.
She prayed on bended knee for forgiveness.
They got down on bended knee and begged him to withdraw his candidacy.
John proposed to me on bended knee in the middle of Central Park.

meanings.definition: used to refer to things that are carried by a vehicle and form part of it:
examples: The car comes with an on-board satellite navigation device.

meanings.definition: existing among the parts that make up or come with a vehicle:
examples: an on-board computer

meanings.definition: doing something connected with your job:
examples: I'm in Baltimore on business.
I sometimes fly business class when travelling on business, but not if it's just for a holiday.

meanings.definition: used to describe workers who are available to make official visits at any time when they are needed:
examples: an on-call specialist/firefighter/judge

meanings.definition: relating to the work of someone who is available at any time when needed:
examples: My new job is 20 hours per week, with no on-call work.

meanings.definition: appearing on a section of video:
examples: They were caught on camera as they brutally attacked a man.
The whole scene was captured on camera.
Motorists caught on camera running red lights can expect to pay even higher fines.
He had apologized after being caught swearing on camera.
She didn't want her face to appear on camera.
Will I be on camera during the interview?

meanings.definition: If something is on charge, you are putting an amount of electricity into it:
examples: Is it all right to leave/put the battery on charge overnight?
She asked me to put her battery on charge for her.
You shouldn't leave appliances on charge unnecessarily.
She went into her bedroom to put her phone on charge.
I used a manual toothbrush because my electric one was on charge.

meanings.definition: If someone who sells goods is paid on commission, the amount of money that they are paid is directly related to the amount or the price of the goods that they sell:
examples: The sales team here works on commission.
Is she paid a regular wage or is she on commission only?

meanings.definition: If goods are on consignment, the person or company that receives them will only pay for them after they have been sold:
examples: He refuses to ship goods on consignment.
The store will only resell dresses on consignment.
He traded over $1 million worth of art on consignment from two collectors whom he then failed to pay.
His violins are made for particular players so he never sells them on consignment.
The store takes items on consignment for a 30% commission.

meanings.definition: likely to happen, or likely to succeed as planned:
examples: Because of the recession, we're on course for record unemployment levels.
This latest victory means they are now back on course to win the championship in five games.
They struggled to keep the company on course in the face of the challenges of a highly competitive industry.
He hopes to use the televised debate to put his campaign back on course.
The government is on course to create 75,000 new jobs.

meanings.definition: If you buy something on credit, you pay for it at a later time, usually paying interest as well as the original cost:
examples: Some people buy too much on credit.
He made the mistake of always allowing his customers to buy on credit.

meanings.definition: If something happens on cue, it happens just after someone has said or thought it would happen:
examples: I was just wondering where Sarah was, when, right on cue, she came in.
I was talking to Betty about our first aid course when, as if on cue, a man in front of us fainted.
She mentioned her many admirers and right on cue, a handsome young man appeared at the door.
I had just sat down for lunch when, right on cue, the fire alarm went off.
"It's too dangerous" she insisted, and almost on cue, the sound of an explosion could be heard.

meanings.definition: In baseball, if a player is on deck, they have the next turn to bat (= try to hit the ball) after the player who is batting now:
examples: Williams was at bat with Rodriguez on deck.
I badly wanted to get this guy out because there was a dangerous hitter on deck.

meanings.definition: when a product, letter, package, etc. arrives at someone's home or office :
examples: You can pay for the carpet on delivery.
Typically, the advance is paid on delivery of the completed manuscript.
We use a courier service where a signature is required on delivery.

meanings.definition: available when a customer wants or asks for something:
examples: They will sell a voice recognition product as an add-on, on-demand service for their users.
In the library's warehouse, robots would manage stock and fetch books on an on-demand basis.

meanings.definition: involved in or relating to providing services when a customer wants or asks for them:
examples: The on-demand economy works by taking a service, such as meal delivery or taxis, and using technology to connect suppliers with consumers.
HBO says that its on-demand business is not dominated by its hit shows but by the niche interests of its audience.

meanings.definition: able to be watched at any time:
examples: Most people in this region do not even have television, let alone on-demand movies.

meanings.definition: a service for watching films or TV programmes at any time:
examples: Cable customers pay an extra $6.95 a month for on-demand.

meanings.definition: Money that is on deposit is saved in a bank or something similar:
examples: I've got £5,000 on deposit in the bank.

meanings.definition: in cricket, a shot that the batter hits in front of them along the ground and towards the left side for a right-handed batter or the right side for a left-handed batter:
examples: The on drive is widely agreed to be one of the hardest shots in cricket.
He produced a series of elegant on drives.

meanings.definition: infml in any conditions; of all possible things:
examples: How on earth did this happen?
What on earth is that awful noise?

meanings.definition: rich
If you buy something on easy terms, you pay for it over a period of time:
examples: Loans were given on easy terms, with very low interest charges and up to 50 years to repay.
Huge numbers of modest-sized houses were quickly built and offered for sale on easy terms.
At the time, debt was readily available on easy terms.
These homes were sold on easy terms.
Oil was provided to these countries on easy terms.

meanings.definition: nervous and not relaxed:
examples: Is something wrong? You seem a bit on edge this morning.
Everyone present was on edge, waiting to hear what the judge would say.
The announcement of job cuts means all the workers are on edge.
The government is cracking down on dissent and everyone is on edge.
She is very argumentative and I always feel on edge when she's around.

meanings.definition: continuously:
examples: She practices the violin for hours on end.

meanings.definition: having the same rights, treatment, etc.:
examples: All companies will compete for the government contract on equal terms.
It's a sport in which men, women, the young, and the old all compete on equal terms.
Dealers are permitted to participate on equal terms.
Regrettably, countries do not trade on the same terms.
This is a place where everyone can meet on equal terms.
This gives shareholders the chance to compete on the same terms.

meanings.definition: being talked about by a lot of people:
examples: The question now on everyone's lips is "Will he resign?"

meanings.definition: If something is on fire, it is burning when it should not be: (of a part of the body) feeling very hot and painful: playing, working, etc. extremely well:
examples: If your home was on fire and you could save only one thing, what would it be?
The field behind the house was on fire.
Bombs were falling and the city was on fire.
There were reports of cars on fire in many of the streets.
He ran to tell us that the barn was on fire.
I had a horrible cough and my throat was on fire.
My back was on fire: it felt as if a thousand pins were being repeatedly pressed into my skin.
He didn't just make the team; he was on fire.
Wow, Luke, you are on fire today!

meanings.definition: friendly or familiar enough with someone to call that person by their first name:
examples: Staff and pupils at the school were on first-name terms.
She was on first-name terms with most of her customers.
Her family connections put her on first-name terms with most of the royalty in Europe.
I ordered food from there so often that I was on first-name terms with the woman who answered the phone.
Very soon, everyone was on first-name terms.

meanings.definition: walking:
examples: Are you going by bicycle or on foot?
He got out of his car and fled on foot.
It's a small town with limited parking, so best explored on foot.
A police officer patrolling on foot witnessed the incident.
The two men climbed over the wall and escaped on foot.
She had to make the long trek on foot.

meanings.definition: when you know someone better:
examples: I wasn't sure about Darryl when I first met her, but on further acquaintance I rather like her.
Maybe his manners will improve on further acquaintance.

meanings.definition: if money, resources, etc. are on-hand, they are available immediately:
examples: Banks are required to have certain levels of cash on-hand at any time.

meanings.definition: An animal that is in heat is in a state of sexual excitement and ready to breed:
examples: It is essential to know when the goat is on heat.
Our labrador is on heat at the moment.
The fox could scent that the vixen was on heat.
We usually keep our boxer indoors when she's on heat.
The ewes were on heat and making a terrible noise.

meanings.definition: in heaven: If an order comes from on high, it comes from someone in a position of authority:
examples: God looked down from on high.
Instructions came from on high to reduce our travel expenses.

meanings.definition: If you are on hold when using the phone, you are waiting to speak to someone:
examples: Mr Briggs is on hold.
He's on the phone at the moment- can I put you on hold?
The operator left me on hold for almost twenty minutes.
They make you listen to awful music while you're on hold.
I'm going to put you on hold for a moment.
I'm still on hold to the insurance company.

meanings.definition: If an activity is on hold, it has been intentionally delayed:
examples: Everything's on hold again because of the bad weather.
The movie has been put on hold until the financial situation improves.
The celebration was put on hold until Lenny recovered.
I was so excited about doing the course, I put everything else on hold.
Hundreds of people put their lives on hold to help with the relief effort.
Her career has been on hold since she sustained a knee injury.

meanings.definition: riding a horse:
examples: police on horseback
They led us on horseback along an overgrown path to an old farmhouse.
She rode 30 miles on horseback through the Finnish forests.
We made the first part of the journey on horseback.
He travelled the country on horseback delivering medicines to remote villages.

meanings.definition: (of drink or food) in a container of ice to get cold: If a plan is on ice, a decision has been made to delay it for a period of time:
examples: I've put a couple of bottles of champagne on ice.
The shrimp cocktail is on ice, the chicken is in the oven.
Both projects are on ice until the question of funding is resolved.
The company plans have been put on ice until it decided what its next move might be.

meanings.definition: doing something that needs to be done, or trying to solve a problem:
examples: "We need help with web design." "Don't worry, I'm on it."

meanings.definition: based only on a person's or thing's qualities and not on what other people say about that person or thing:
examples: Judge the product on its own merits, and not on what the ads say.

meanings.definition: Something that is on its last legs is in such bad condition that it will soon be unable to work as it should:
examples: I've had this laptop for five years now, and it's really on its last legs.

meanings.definition: weak or in very bad condition:
examples: My car is on its last legs, but I'll drive it until it won't go any farther.

meanings.definition: happening or arriving soon: If you are on your way you are leaving:
examples: They have three kids, and another on the way.
My school is well on its way to a championship.
We’re on our way from Logan, and should be there soon.
Give me a kiss and I'll be on my way.

meanings.definition: If a football player is on loan, they are playing for a different club for a limited period of time:
examples: He spent a month on loan at Newcastle.
He scored an amazing goal against Barnet while he was on loan at Portsmouth.
At the time, he was on loan from Marseille.
He was recalled from Southampton, where he was on loan.
He began his goalscoring career when he was on loan from Arsenal back in the 1990s.

meanings.definition: (of a politician) saying things in public that support the official ideas of his or her political party:
examples: The candidate is clearly on message with the party leadership.

meanings.definition: someone who is on-message says things in public that show they agree with the ideas and decisions of their political party, the government, etc.:
examples: The Labour leader urged MPs to stay on-message throughout the election campaign.

meanings.definition: saying things in public that show you agree with the ideas and decisions of your political party, the government, etc.:
examples: They hire whichever "on-message" journalists and editors they wish.

meanings.definition: If something must on no account/not on any account be done, it must not be done at any time or for any reason:
examples: Employees must on no account make personal phone calls from the office.
These records must not on any account be changed.

meanings.definition: sometimes but not often:
examples: He has, on occasion, told a small lie.

meanings.definition: available to be bought or used:
examples: We were amazed at the range of products on offer.
I'll take a look at their website and see what's on offer.
There are so many vegan meat substitutes now on offer.
They have a leaflet telling you about the range of services on offer.
Do shop around to see what's on offer before you make any decisions?

meanings.definition: something that you say when you are speaking about two opposite ways of thinking about or reacting to a situation:
examples: On one level I quite like the attention but on another level, I suppose I find it a little disturbing.

meanings.definition: judging something by how it has been planned rather than how it really works in practice:
examples: The design certainly looks good on paper.
Several candidates seemed suitable on paper but failed the interview.

meanings.definition: according to a theory or idea as opposed to something that has been tried:
examples: On paper it looks like it could work, but I won't believe it until I see it in operation.

meanings.definition: When soldiers are on parade, they march and practise military movements in front of important officials or as part of a public celebration or ceremony:
examples: The entire regiment was on parade.
Dress uniforms like these are worn when soldiers are on parade.
To celebrate the conclusion of their initial training program, the cadets were on parade.
They walked in step, looking straight ahead, almost like soldiers on parade.
The book cover shows soldiers on parade.

meanings.definition: worried or excited about something that is going to happen:
examples: Don’t keep Margaret on pins and needles – give her a call.

meanings.definition: worried or excited about something that is going to happen:
examples: Don’t keep Margaret on pins and needles – give her a call.

meanings.definition: as good as it could be; perfect:
examples: My hair was on point.

meanings.definition: If you do something on purpose, you do it intentionally, not by accident:
examples: I didn't do it on purpose - it was an accident.
Sometimes I suspect she arrives late on purpose just to annoy me.
I'm convinced he knocked my drink over on purpose.
Some of these species were introduced to the area on purpose to keep the rodent population down.
Their coach instructed them to lose the game on purpose.

meanings.definition: in prison until a court trial begins:
examples: He was held on remand in prison for 18 months.
She had already spent six months in custody on remand.
He had been held on remand for eight months.
Morris was arrested on suspicion of murder and detained on remand at Winsom Green Prison.
She will be free in four months because of time served on remand.
The minister has called for a reduction in the number of prisoners on remand.

meanings.definition: not early or late:
examples: Managers need to know whether work is proceeding on schedule.
Is everything on schedule? We need to make sure we deliver in May as planned.
It's critical to the success of this project that we stay on schedule.
All three projects were completed on schedule and within budget.
Fears were raised when her yacht failed to arrive on schedule.

meanings.definition: saying the words that are on a script (= the words for a speech, broadcast, play, or film ):
examples: No improvisation is allowed – all presenters have to stay on script.
Media commentators praised his continuous on-script speech.

meanings.definition: behaving as expected or planned:
examples: She stayed on message and on script.
There was no one there to keep them on script.
We spent the two previous weeks playing knockout rugby, two weeks in which we were on-script and accurate.

meanings.definition: likely to fail:
examples: At least one factory is on shaky ground, and the town expects more to shut down.

meanings.definition: on the land and not in a ship:
examples: We waited until we were on shore before repairing the sails.
We were on shore for almost two weeks.
I'd been on shore for several weeks and was starting to miss the sea.
At once they went on shore to procure supplies of food and water.
The chefs went on shore to prepare meals for the next day.
Once we were safely on shore, we were able to raise the alarm.

meanings.definition: only a short time before something happens:
examples: I can't cancel my plans on such short notice.

meanings.definition: Something that is on show has been made available for the public to look at:
examples: Her sculptures will be on show at the museum until the end of the month.
His works are currently on show at the Studio Gallery.
Fifty of her black-and-white photographs are on show.
All of these images are on show at the Natural History Museum in London.
Both paintings will be on show throughout March and the first half of April.
The portrait was on show at the Louvre in Paris.

meanings.definition: poor, without a job or a place to live, and often drinking too much alcohol
If something is said to be on someone's or something's account, it is because of that person or thing:
examples: I'm not very hungry, so please don't cook on my account (= don't cook just for me).
They were tired, but not any less enthusiastic on that account.

meanings.definition: only for or because of one person
just before someone's death:
examples: He told her he loved her on his deathbed.

meanings.definition: very close to where someone is or lives:
examples: There's a lovely park right on our doorstep.

meanings.definition: If someone or something is on your radar, you are aware of, or have thought about, them or it. :
examples: She has been on my radar since her first novel came out, but I haven't read any of her books yet.
Five years ago, having a child wasn't even on my radar.

meanings.definition: at a time when someone is in charge of a particular situation and responsible for what happens:
examples: This happened on my watch. And I intend to resolve it.
The President exaggerated the number of jobs that were created on his watch.
You need to make sure that nobody gets hurt on your watch.
A lot of difficult problems occurred on Sarah's watch.
People at the top often seemed to be excused from responsibility for things that happened on their watch.

meanings.definition: friendly enough to talk:
examples: We had an argument, but we’re back on speaking terms now.

meanings.definition: taking a chance, without being sure that you will get what you want:
examples: We just turned up at the airport on spec, hoping that we'd be able to get tickets.
You could always send your CV to a few companies on spec.
The houses were built on spec and remained empty for years.
I submitted the screenplay on spec and the studio loved it.
If you turn up on spec, you might get a discount on your hotel room.

meanings.definition: When a person or a thing is on standby, they are or it is ready to be used if necessary:
examples: Hospitals are on standby ready to deal with casualties from the crash.
They had a team of lawyers on standby in case they were sued.
Troops were on standby to deal with any trouble after the election.
The hospital has dealt with a shortage of nurses by paying them to be on standby.
An ambulance was on standby in case any of the injuries needed hospital treatment.

meanings.definition: When an electrical device such as a television is on standby, the power is on but the device will not work until a switch, etc. is pressed. :
examples: Not leaving your TV on standby at night will save you money.
A video recorder on standby uses almost as much electricity as one playing a tape.
Keeping the reactor on standby is costing millions of dollars a year.
The system allowed us to keep our phones on standby and thus extend battery life.
Switch off all the equipment rather than leaving it on standby.

meanings.definition: When someone is on standby, they are waiting for a seat that might become available just before a flight or performance:
examples: I was too late for my flight but I managed get on standby for a later one.
I didn't get to the theatre in time to snag a ticket, so I'm waiting on standby to see if they release any tickets right before the show.
She was on standby for a ticket to see Madonna.
The airline has oversold its seats and is now telling me I'm on standby for a ticket I've already paid for.
The flight was oversold, and some passengers were put on standby.

meanings.definition: used for saying that something is an extreme example or version of something:
examples: He described the new edifices as "architecture on steroids".
People flocked to West Berlin in search of an alternative life in a liberal society. It was like Amsterdam on steroids.

meanings.definition: Something in industry or business that is on stream is being produced or is available for use:
examples: The company's increased sales were primarily a result of new stores coming on stream.

meanings.definition: taking part in a strike:
examples: The city's bus drivers have been on strike for three weeks.
It was difficult to travel because the train drivers were on strike.
Our staff will not be on strike, so classes will continue as usual.
Their pilots have been on strike since October.
Most of the chefs are working, but the waiters are out on strike.

meanings.definition: In cricket, the batter who is on strike is the one who the ball is being bowled (= thrown) to:
examples: He takes the single to put Edwards back on strike.
Warne is bowling and Strauss is on strike.

meanings.definition: used to describe beer that is served from a barrel through a tap:
examples: Our favorite pub kept kegs of Guinness on tap.
They don't have the beer I like on tap.
This is one of the few student unions that serves beer on tap.
We knew how long the outage had lasted from the increasing temperature of the beer on tap.
They have a large selection of beers in bottles and on tap.

meanings.definition: available for use at any time:
examples: Working in a library as I do, I have all this information on tap.
They had a group of volunteers on tap to make sure the conference went smoothly.
We have an army of interpreters on tap.
The infantry division is on tap for deployment to the Middle East.
There could be hundreds of new apartments on tap by next year.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         OTE
If you are on target with a piece of work, you are making good progress and likely to achieve what you planned.
If you do something on the advice of someone or something, you do it because they or it advise you to. :
examples: I signed up for the course on the advice of a friend, who said it was easy.
On the advice of my counsel, I refused search of my home without a warrant.
On Sarah's advice we decided to go to Toronto instead.
On police advice, we stayed clear of the area.

meanings.definition: to act in a strong, determined way to defeat someone or something, often in a game or competition:
examples: In the second half, the Panthers went on the attack and they scored after two minutes.
The Democrats have changed their campaign strategy, and are now on the attack against the Republicans.

meanings.definition: If something is on the back burner, it is temporarily not being dealt with or considered, especially because it is not urgent or important:
examples: We've all had to put our plans on the back burner for a while.

meanings.definition: not being done now, but left to be considered in the future:
examples: The company put the project on the back burner.
Their complaints have definitely been pushed to the back burner.

on-the-back-of-an-envelope.name: on the back of an envelope

meanings.definition: in a hurried way, without much detail:
examples: The prices were very roughly calculated - it looked as though he'd done them on the back of an envelope.

meanings.definition: soon after an earlier success, and as a result of it:
examples: The advertising agency secured the contract on the back of its previous successful campaigns.

meanings.definition: by using or taking advantage of someone or something else:
examples: They have carried on their business operations by riding on the back of established firms.

meanings.definition: If you are on the ball, you are be quick to understand and react to things: In football, American football, and basketball, if you are on the ball, you have control of it:
examples: I didn't sleep well last night and I'm not really on the ball today.
She looks so comfortable when she's on the ball.
Their strategy is to immediately press the player on the ball.
He's a good cornerback and can make plays on the ball.
The coaches teach both on the ball and off the ball defence.

meanings.definition: aware of any changes or developments and quick to react to them:
examples: We need someone who’s really on the ball to answer questions from the press.

meanings.definition: If you pay for something on the barrel, you pay the full amount for it at the time you get it. :
examples: She paid cash on the barrel.
I have enough to pay for a used guitar. On the barrel.
If you can't pay cash on the barrelhead, wait until you can.

meanings.definition: When a machine is on the blink, it is not working correctly.
not working correctly:
examples: The DVD player is on the blink again.

meanings.definition: officially employed by a company, or an official member of an organization, society, sports team, etc.: officially recorded, especially as a law:
examples: There are 256 people on the books at the cement works.
The nursery has 30 babies on the books and 13 on the waiting list.
A ban on texting while driving is on the books in most states.

meanings.definition: drinking a lot of alcohol:
examples: Every Friday night Rick would go out on the booze.

meanings.definition: one after another with nothing else between:
examples: The team has had five wins on the bounce.

meanings.definition: not certain to get a place in a team, keep your job, win an election, etc.:
examples: Those who had not gained their paramedic certification were "on the bubble" with regard to keeping their jobs.

meanings.definition: (of a politician who is trying to be elected) taking part in a series of planned events in different places:
examples: Both of the major party candidates for president are on the campaign trail today.
When they were on the campaign trail, she spoke at the building I worked at.

meanings.definition: If you get goods on the cheap, you get them for a low price:
examples: There's a big store near here where you can buy designer clothes on the cheap.
If you try to get things on the cheap, you will often be disappointed with their quality.
Employees who bought stock on the cheap made a substantial profit on their investment.
He bought some land on the cheap and built a house.
Is it right that Everest can be climbed on the cheap?

meanings.definition: talking to someone that you find sexually attractive in the hope of having sex with them:
examples: Look at him over there on the chirpse.
If you're on the chirpse, I'd recommend a smart shirt.
Sometimes, when you're on the chirpse with a guy or girl, you suddenly stop liking them.
Apparently they were on the chirpse by tweeting each other before they actually met.
That is definitely not the kind of vibe you want to be giving off when on the chirpse.

meanings.definition: next to or close to the sea:
examples: They have been staying at a wonderful hotel on the coast with breathtaking views.
Rimini is a thriving resort on the east coast of Italy.

meanings.definition: used to show that you think or feel the opposite of what has just been stated:
examples: "I thought you said the film was exciting?" "On the contrary, I nearly fell asleep half way through it!"
I'm not angry with you. On the contrary!
They do not reject modernity completely; on the contrary, they embrace the modern world.
"Did you expect them to help you?" "On the contrary, I hoped they would stay away."
I did not mean to imply that the city was an ugly or dangerous place. On the contrary, I think it is extremely pleasant.

meanings.definition: at a place where two streets meet:
examples: The taxi driver dropped her on the corner.
There's a postbox on the corner of Vine Street and Fourth Avenue.

meanings.definition: after counting to a particular number:
examples: On the count of three, run.

on-the-count-of-three-four-five-etc.name: on the count of three, four, five, etc.

meanings.definition: when a particular number is reached:
examples: On the count of three, I'd like you all to stand up.
On the count of three, they threw their grenades into the trench and ran.
We'll both start at the same time. On the count of three - one, two, three, go!
The stage manager told the actors to stay backstage and, on the count of five, he'd wave them back on.
Stay calm - we'll help you up on the count of three. Ready?

meanings.definition: If people are on the dance floor, they are dancing, especially in a nightclub, restaurant, etc.:
examples: Have you ever seen him on the dance floor?
These songs are so catchy that they are guaranteed to get people on the dance floor.

meanings.definition: ready to protect yourself because you are expecting to be criticized or attacked:
examples: The government has been put on the defensive, accused by critics of doing too little too late.
As always when forced on the defensive, she protected herself by criticizing others.
The harsh critique has put him on the defensive, and now he can't stand to hear any talk of his work.
Put on the defensive by mounting public anger, the president ordered an investigation into the matter.
In his new post, he was constantly on the defensive, explaining and justifying his every action.

meanings.definition: If you are on the dole, you are receiving money from the government because you are unemployed:
examples: Half of the town's residents were on the dole.
Young people on the dole are often bored and frustrated.

meanings.definition: on or near the step in front of an outside door:
examples: He left the package on the doorstep.
A dark-haired girl was standing on the doorstep.

meanings.definition: If something is on the doorstep of a place, it is very close to it:
examples: It is a charming village, and the historic town of Bath is right on the doorstep.
Frank should remember that we don't all live on the doorstep of the ocean.

meanings.definition: If a politician is on the doorstep, they are talking to ordinary people, often by going from one house to the next to discuss their ideas:
examples: He launched the review and now we are developing policies that we can sell on the doorstep.
They said they had encountered a lot of hostility towards the new tax on the doorstep.

meanings.definition: exactly at the stated or expected time:
examples: The plane landed at two o'clock on the dot.
She came promptly on the dot of eleven.

on-the-edge-of-seat.name: on the edge of your seat

meanings.definition: very excited, and giving all your attention to something, because you want to know what is going to happen:
examples: He could no longer keep his eyes open to watch any of the videos which, until quite recently, would have kept him on the edge of his seat.
The excitement of the finale had you on the edge of your seat.
They were both playing amazing tennis. Everyone was on the edge of their seats the entire time.

meanings.definition: during the day or period just before an important event:
examples: Mrs Clayton was speaking to Arab journalists in Paris on the eve of her visit to Egypt.
The report was released on the eve of the election.

meanings.definition: used when you are describing how a situation seems on the surface:
examples: On the face of it, it seems like a bargain, but I bet there are hidden costs.

meanings.definition: when first considered:
examples: The story seems simple on the face of it, but it’s really pretty complicated.

meanings.definition: involving ordinary workers rather than managers:
examples: That sort of decision should be taken on the factory floor.

meanings.definition: not able to decide something:
examples: Many consumers are still on the fence, waiting for a less expensive computer to come along.
Todd’s still sitting on the fence, trying to decide which school he wants to go to.

meanings.definition: in a situation that attracts criticism:
examples: The judge found himself in the firing line after his remarks about women staying home with their children.

meanings.definition: If you do something on the fly, you do it quickly, often while you are doing something else, without preparing and without thinking too much about how it should be done: without interrupting a computer program that is already running:
examples: This new rule seems to have been created on the fly.
He had written a program that could translate from Japanese on the fly.

meanings.definition: getting or needing immediate attention:
examples: A few important members of Congress are making an effort to keep human rights on the front burner.

meanings.definition: getting or needing immediate attention:
examples: A few important members of Congress are making an effort to keep human rights on the front burner.

meanings.definition: working as a prostitute:
examples: She went on the game to pay for her drug habit.
Was she on the game?

meanings.definition: involved in illegal activities:
examples: You know his whole family's on the game - they work with the mob!
She didn't want to know if her brother was on the game or not.
Not everyone is in on the game.

meanings.definition: busy and active: while travelling or not at home:
examples: Like most working mothers, she is always on the go.
With mobile banking, you can manage your money on the go.
These dishes can be created ready to serve at home or to eat on the go.

meanings.definition: very busy: in the process of being produced:
examples: I've been on the go all day, and I'm really tired.
Did you know that she's got a new book on the go (= being written)?

meanings.definition: very busy or active:
examples: Elise is always on the go.

meanings.definition: among the general public:
examples: Their political ideas have a lot of support on the ground.

meanings.definition: If you do something on the hoof, you do it while you are moving about or doing something else, often without giving it the attention it deserves:
examples: I've got a meeting downtown in 20 minutes so I'll have lunch on the hoof.

meanings.definition: likely to happen or exist soon:
examples: There is no new drug on the horizon that will make this disease easier to treat.

meanings.definition: If you have something on the house, it is given to you free by a business:
examples: All the drinks were on the house.

meanings.definition: given to you free by a business:
examples: Your meal is on the house tonight!

meanings.definition: increasing:
examples: Homelessness is on the increase in many cities.
Diseases like multiple sclerosis appear to be on the increase.
Single-occupant households are on the increase.
Although juvenile crime is going down, many people believe it to be on the increase.
Workplace injuries have been on the increase since regulations were removed.

meanings.definition: If someone is on the inside, they have a job or position in which they have special or secret information:
examples: Who do we know on the inside who can help us?

on-the-large-small-etc-side.name: on the large, small, etc. side

meanings.definition: too large, small, etc. for a particular purpose:
examples: This dress is on the large side for me.

meanings.definition: drinking a lot of alcoholic drinks, especially socially with friends:
examples: He was out on the lash with his mates.
He broke his foot during a night on the lash.
We like to go on the lash, have a few beers and enjoy ourselves.
Frank went on the lash for 24 hours.

meanings.definition: closed but not locked:
examples: Don't forget to leave the front door on the latch if you go to bed before I get back.
We'll keep the door on the latch and you can come in when you want.
She shouted to let him know the door was on the latch.
She searched in her pocket for a key, then remembered that the door was on the latch.
The main door is always on the latch during office hours.

meanings.definition: being honest or speaking truthfully:
examples: I know he’s lied to you before, but I really think he’s on the level this time.

meanings.definition: at risk of failing or being harmed: On the line also means speaking on the telephone:
examples: His job is on the line.
Firefighters regularly put their lives on the line.
My mom was on the line, but I could hear my dad talking in the background.

meanings.definition: If a dangerous person or animal is on the loose, that person or animal is free to move around a place and harm people:
examples: Brewer escaped from prison last year and has been on the loose ever since.

meanings.definition: trying hard to succeed, esp. in a way that is dishonest:
examples: The movie is about a businessman on the make, who steals company funds.

meanings.definition: If soldiers are on the march, they have started marching to a place:
examples: Soldiers on the march were permitted to break their fast.
By the time they got to Palestine, some of the Crusaders had been on the march for three years.
The rebels were on the march again, moving towards the capital city.
We are hearing reports that government troops are on the march to confront the rebels.
They were expected to spend days on the march, even sleeping in the saddle.

meanings.definition: If something is on the march, it is becoming successful or spreading through an area:
examples: In America, evangelical Christianity is on the march.
Cash dispensers which charge you to take out your own money are on the march across the country.

meanings.definition: available for sale:
examples: We put our house on the market as soon as house prices started to rise.
This is one of the best televisions on the market.
The pictures would sell for half a million on the open market (= if offered for sale without a fixed price).
The hotel has been on the market for over a year already.
The new drug has completed clinical testing and could be on the market by next year.

meanings.definition: becoming healthy after an illness:
examples: She's still in the hospital, but she's definitely on the mend.

meanings.definition: If a suggestion is approved on the nod, it is accepted without discussion:
examples: The new proposal went through on the nod.

meanings.definition: exactly right, often an exact amount of money or time:
examples: Her description of the play was right on the nose.

meanings.definition: exactly correct or the exact amount:
examples: He weighs 175 pounds on the nose.

on-the-one-hand-on-the-other-hand.name: on the one hand ... on the other hand

meanings.definition: used when you are comparing two different facts or two opposite ways of thinking about a situation:
examples: On the one hand I'd like a job that pays more, but on the other hand I enjoy the work I'm doing at the moment.

meanings.definition: the first thing to consider is this, but a second and different thing to consider is this:
examples: On the one hand, I’d like a job that pays more, but on the other hand I enjoy the work I’m doing now.

meanings.definition: in a way that is different from the first thing you mentioned:
examples: My husband likes classical music – I, on the other hand, like all kinds.

meanings.definition: People who are on the outs have argued and are not now friendly with each other:
examples: Lizzie and Tyler are on the outs again.
He'd reported that he was on the outs with the child's mother.
Later that year, she found herself on the outs with Taylor.
Currently on the outs with several members of her own party, she is unrepentant.
Harry is on the outs with his girlfriend again.

on-the-part-of-on-part.name: on the part of someone/on someone's part

meanings.definition: done or experienced by someone:
examples: This was a misjudgment on the part of the government.
A little humility on her part would be appreciated.

meanings.definition: speaking on the phone:
examples: She's on the phone at the moment but she can see you in a few minutes.
I'll put Dad on the phone (= give the phone to him so he can speak).
She was on the phone with her siblings trying to organize travel arrangements.
Please don't interrupt me when I'm on the phone.
I'll call home and get the babysitter to put my daughter on the phone.

meanings.definition: with a phone connected to your home by wires:
examples: Are the Middletons on the phone at their cottage, do you know?
In those days, we didn't know many people who were on the phone.
I had to go next door for help because we weren't on the phone.
He lives in the middle of nowhere and refuses to be on the phone.
It took days to get a message to her because she wasn't on the phone.

meanings.definition: drinking a lot of alcoholic drink, especially socially with friends:
examples: They've been on the piss all weekend.
He smashed the window after a night on the piss.
One night he went on the piss after work and didn't come home until 9am the following morning.

meanings.definition: moving around an area and looking for something or someone:
examples: On the way home I saw a raccoon on the prowl.

meanings.definition: secretly:
examples: His wife found out he'd been seeing someone on the quiet.

meanings.definition: unhappy and confused because a close, romantic relationship of yours has recently finished:
examples: Five months after Nick had left her, she married another man on the rebound.

on-the-receiving-end-of.name: on the receiving end of something

meanings.definition: suffering from something unpleasant when you have done nothing to deserve it:
examples: She was on the receiving end of a lawsuit.

meanings.definition: If you say something on the record, you state it publicly:
examples: None of the company directors were prepared to comment on the record yesterday.

meanings.definition: doing something correctly or well:
examples: You haven't quite got the answer yet, but you're on the right track.

on-the-right-wrong-side-of.name: on the right/wrong side of 40, 50, etc.

meanings.definition: looking younger/older than a particular age:
examples: She looks to me as if she's on the wrong side of 50.

on-the-right-wrong-side-of-the-law.name: on the right/wrong side of the law

meanings.definition: obeying/not obeying the law:
examples: After coming out of prison, he tried to stay on the right side of the law.

meanings.definition: increasing:
examples: Police say that youth crime is on the rise again.
Nationalism is once again on the rise.
Resignations are on the rise as the economy improves.
Bankruptcies too are on the rise.
The politician's favourability rating is once again on the rise after the rally.
Scientists have been trying to discover why food allergies seem to be on the rise in recent decades.

meanings.definition: If a vehicle is on the road, it is working as it should and can be legally used:
examples: My car was in the garage for a week, but it's now back on the road.
I'm hoping to have my car on the road in a couple of days.
It's not worth the money that would be needed just to get the vehicle on the road.

meanings.definition: When you are on the road, you are driving or travelling, usually over a long distance:
examples: After two days on the road, they reached the coast.
He's on the road for twenty hours or so a week with this job.
We'd already been on the road for six hours and were quite tired.
We'll be on the road for mostof next week.
When she's not on the road, she works from home.
We had a cup of coffee and a sandwich and then were back on the road again.

meanings.definition: If a group of actors or musicians are on the road, they are travelling to different places to perform:
examples: Most rock groups spend two or three months a year on the road.
I know tour just ended, but when are you heading back out on the road?
The theatre company will take their show on the road later this year.
She'll be on the road performing her new stand-up comedy show in 35 cities.

meanings.definition: likely to achieve something:
examples: The doctors say she’s on the road to recovery.

meanings.definition: likely to fail soon: If you have an alcoholic drink on the rocks, you have it with pieces of ice:
examples: I think their marriage is on the rocks.
I'll have a whisky on the rocks, please.

meanings.definition: infmlfailing: If an alcoholic drink is on the rocks, it is served with ice.
examples: Their marriage is on the rocks.

meanings.definition: doing badly and likely to fail:
examples: I think the business is finally on the ropes.

meanings.definition: in serious trouble or likely to fail:
examples: For a while, our business was on the ropes.

meanings.definition: while hurrying to go somewhere:
examples: I eat breakfast on the run if I'm late for work.

meanings.definition: while busy doing something else: If criminals are on the run, they are trying to avoid being caught: Someone or something on the run is at a disadvantage in a competitive situation:
examples: He ate on the run, downing an apple in his car.
The two men were on the run for three weeks before being caught by police.
Competition from Internet retailers has some big department stores on the run.

meanings.definition: thinking in the same way as someone else:
examples: Luckily, my husband and I are on the same wavelength about how to raise our kids.

meanings.definition: close to discovering:
examples: "We're on the scent of something big," said the police chief.

meanings.definition: Someone who is on the scrounge is asking people for things or for money:
examples: At college he was always broke and on the scrounge.
A word of warning - Jake's here and he's on the scrounge again.
Is your sister on the scrounge again?
I'm on the scrounge for any good quality secondhand clothes I can sell on my stall next week.
If anyone's got a spare ticket for the concert this Saturday, I'm on the scrounge.

meanings.definition: not noticed or not used: If someone, usually a woman, is on the shelf, she is not married and is considered too old for anyone to want to marry her:
examples: It's important to apply research in a practical way and not leave it on the shelf.
In those days, if you hadn't married by the time you were 30, you were definitely on the shelf.

meanings.definition: delayed:
examples: Plans to start a free film series have been put on the shelf.

meanings.definition: in addition to your main job: secretly: (of food in a restaurant) served on another plate, or on the side of the plate :
examples: He makes a little money on the side by cleaning windows in his spare time.
I think he has another woman on the side (= a relationship with a woman who is not his wife).
I'd like a salad with the dressing on the side (= with the dressing served separately from the salad), please.
I'll have a omelette with fries on the side, please.

meanings.definition: in addition: Food that is served on the side is served separate from other food:
examples: He drives a bus, but he’s a tour guide on the side.
I’ll have the salad with the dressing on the side.

meanings.definition: not taking part in an activity:
examples: Several countries chose to remain on the sidelines during the war.

meanings.definition: failing:
examples: Both of the government programs were on the skids.

meanings.definition: (of the price of food or drink that a regular customer buys) recorded so that they can pay for it at another time:
examples: Could you put these drinks on the slate?

meanings.definition: If you do something on the sly, you do it secretly because you should not be doing it:
examples: He drives his mother's car on the sly while she's at work.
She does a bit of work on the sly.
Dating is frowned on so is usually done on the sly.
Although the product is officially banned, some restaurants still serve it on the sly.
They started meeting up on the sly.
She visited them on the sly.

meanings.definition: affected by autism (= a brain condition that affects the development of social and communication skills in ways that can be severe or slight, and that can make someone's behaviour and interests different from people without the condition ) to some degree:
examples: The article describes a mother's experience of living with a child on the spectrum.
Children on the spectrum may have trouble communicating and socializing.
"Every child that is on the spectrum has more gifts than challenges," he said. "It's just trying to find those gifts."

meanings.definition: one after another with nothing else between:
examples: The team has now lost four games on the spin.
They have been playing well recently with five wins on the spin.

meanings.definition: at the place where an event is happening or has recently happened:
examples: The police were called and they were on the spot within three minutes.
The animals form groups to hunt prey, which they eat on the spot.
Interviewees may have to debug a program on the spot.
It can be difficult to come up with a good answer on the spot.
The lyrics sounded as though the singer was making them up on the spot.

meanings.definition: immediately:
examples: You can be sacked on the spot for stealing.
The directors met with him and offered him the role on the spot.
They threatened to shoot her on the spot.
The head teacher was so impressed with him that she offered him a scholarship on the spot.
The offer of free flying lessons closed the deal on the spot.

meanings.definition: (of running or jumping) in one place, without moving forward or backward at all:
examples: Do a bit of running on the spot to warm up your leg muscles.
I hopped up and down on the spot, beside myself with excitement.
They were jogging on the spot, waiting to cross the road.
Jump up and down twenty times on the spot.
Run on the spot for five minutes and remember to lift your knees as high as you can.

on-the-spur-of-the-moment.name: on the spur of the moment

meanings.definition: used to say that a decision, action, etc. is sudden and done without any planning:
examples: We hadn't planned to go away - it was one of those spur-of-the-moment decisions.
We just jumped in a car on the spur of the moment and drove to the seaside.

meanings.definition: suddenly without any planning:
examples: On the spur of the moment, we decided to go to the beach.

meanings.definition: without a home:
examples: Some of these people have been living on the streets for years.

meanings.definition: If you do something on the strength of something such as advice, you do it because you have been influenced by it or believe it:
examples: I invested in the company on the strength of my brother's advice.

meanings.definition: because of something:
examples: I invested in the company on the strength of my brother’s advice.

meanings.definition: (of a politician) travelling around an area giving speeches and trying to get political support:
examples: On the stump, he was a master at turning his simple speaking style into a political virtue.
The issue comes up over and over on the stump.

meanings.definition: If a plan or suggestion has been put/laid on the table, it has been made available for people to hear, read, or discuss.
being discussed or considered:
examples: There are several important issues on the table.

meanings.definition: trying to profit in a personal and usually financial way from a situation:
examples: He's obviously on the take - where else did all that money come from?

meanings.definition: at the start of a new and important time or development:
examples: We are on the threshold of a new era in global relations.

on-the-tip-of-tongue.name: on the tip of your tongue

meanings.definition: about to be said if you can remember it:
examples: I know her - her name is on the tip of my tongue, but it won't come to me.

meanings.definition: enjoying yourself by going to places of entertainment in a town or city:
examples: I was out on the town/I had a night on the town last night, and I'm exhausted!

meanings.definition: going to places of entertainment in a town or city for fun:
examples: I was out on the town last night.

meanings.definition: If you do things on the trot, you do them directly after each other without pausing:
examples: They won three games on the trot.
She worked 30 hours on the trot to get the job finished on time.

meanings.definition: If you do something on the understanding that something else can or will happen, you do it because someone else has promised that it can or will:
examples: We bought the sofa on the understanding that we could return it if it didn't fit in the room.
They funded the technology on the understanding that they would be able to use it themselves in future.
They gave him the money on the understanding that he would pass it on to Adiza's family.
He was released on the understanding that he would go to live in Canada.
They gave her the job on the understanding that she would be subject to quarterly reviews.

meanings.definition: according to someone's promise or statement:
examples: We purchased the computer on the understanding that it could be returned within ten days.

meanings.definition: Someone who is on the up (and up) is honest and can be trusted.improving all the time:
examples: Her career has been on the up and up since she moved into sales.

meanings.definition: honest and fair to everyone:
examples: There is skepticism among many voters that the election is going to be conducted on the up and up.

meanings.definition: If you are on the verge of something or come to the verge of something, you are very close to experiencing it:
examples: on the verge of collapse/success/tears/death/disaster/war
Her husband's violent and abusive behaviour drove her to the verge of despair.

meanings.definition: very near to doing or experiencing something:
examples: He was on the verge of saying something but stopped and shook his head.

meanings.definition: If you are on the wagon, you have decided not to drink any alcohol:
examples: He was on the wagon for ten years, when he was living in Connecticut.

meanings.definition: becoming less strong, powerful, popular, etc.:
examples: There are signs that support for the group is on the wane.
Wide-scale outbreaks of the illness have been on the wane for some years now.
Schools are improving and crime is on the wane.
Sadly, this type of lavish entertaining is on the wane.
