At that time, his career was on the wane and he was struggling financially.

meanings.definition: angry and ready to argue or fight:
examples: I told my friends to watch out because my mother was on the warpath.

meanings.definition: on Saturday or Sunday, or on both Saturday and Sunday:
examples: I wouldn't go to that restaurant on the weekend - they never have tables available.
On the weekend, we like to focus on the kids.
My dad only came home on the weekend so it was just Mom and me during the week.
I work two jobs Monday through Friday, so I try to have nothing happening on the weekend.
I catch up on my TV shows on the weekend.

meanings.definition: generally:
examples: We have our bad times but on the whole we're fairly happy.

meanings.definition: generally:
examples: On the whole, I prefer classical music.

meanings.definition: A bird that is on the wing is flying:
examples: When they are on the wing, you can really see their dramatic markings.
Geese make a very distinctive noise when they're on the wing.
Remarkably, these birds are on the wing at sea for weeks on end.
I like to watch them when they're on the wing.
They're on the wing now, flying to warmer climes.

meanings.definition: not correct about something:
examples: If you suspect my son was involved, you are on the wrong track.

meanings.definition: about the thing or subject that has just been mentioned:
examples: I'll let you have the money, so there's nothing to worry about on that score.
"The team has a lot of determination to win," declared the coach. "I have no doubts on that score."
There's definitely accommodation available so we're all sorted on that score.
He's certainly qualified for the job. I have no problem on that score.
She's blameless on this score, at any rate.

meanings.definition: If you buy something on tick, you pay for it later:
examples: It's tempting to buy all of this stuff on tick.
She'd bought everything on tick.
The number of new cars bought on tick has risen by eight percent.
If you don't have the money now, you can always get it on tick.
They'd let her have the clothes on tick.
Goods were often obtained on tick.

meanings.definition: on your toes with the heel of your foot lifted off the ground:
examples: The children stood on tiptoe in order to pick the apples from the tree.
They walked across the room on tiptoe so as not to wake the baby.
I got on my tiptoes so I could reach the top shelf of the cabinet.
She was so little, she had to stand on tiptoe to reach the microphone.
I crept into the bedroom on tiptoes.
Her heels were so high, she was teetering around on her tiptoes.

meanings.definition: feeling or doing things as well as possible:
examples: Paul's back on top form after his illness.
Imogen was on top form last night.
Both appeared on top form during their visit today.
He remarked that it was good to see the singer back on top form.
This was an orchestra on top form.
Taylor is certainly on top form this season.

meanings.definition: in the best or most successful position:
examples: She came out on top in every race.

meanings.definition: in addition to something, especially something unpleasant: in control of something or able to deal with it successfully, especially something that is often changing or increasing:
examples: We missed our flight, and on top of that we had to wait seven hours for the next one.
On top of everything else, I locked myself out of the house.
This all has to be paid for on top of the huge costs we already have going out each month.
On top of the disappointment was the fact that it was my good friend who had let me down.
He had thousands of dollars' worth of medical bills on top of having to pay for a house he couldn't live in.
As a manager I try to be on top of everything that is happening.
Getting on top of your finances takes effort, but it's worth it.
He was desperately trying to stay on top of the flood of data pouring in.
Since then she has received hundreds of requests but she has kept on top of the situation.
The radio presenter gets up early to read all the newspapers and make sure she's on top of the big issues of the day.

meanings.definition: in control of a situation and aware of changes: On top of is also used to mean in addition to, esp. something unpleasant:
examples: The stock market has been unpredictable, and you really have to stay on top of things.
We missed the bus, and on top of that it started raining.

meanings.definition: extremely happy:
examples: She was feeling on top of the world.

meanings.definition: very happy:
examples: She was feeling on top of the world after winning the tennis tournament.

meanings.definition: making progress and likely to succeed in doing something or in achieving a particular result: at or on a track where a race is being held, or found or happening there:
examples: They're on track to make record profits.
The theme park is on track for a record year with more than 4 million visitors.
With the help of her parents, she's finally back on track.
We are seeing on-track growth this financial year.
A motorsport commentator's role is to put what's happening on track into words.
If you bet on track, only do so with the official racecourse bookmakers.
Some tracks have prospered because they also have on-track casinos and slot machines.
The two companies have recently withdrawn on-track betting operations in Britain and Ireland.
With the help of crash data recorders the racing teams were able to study on-track incidents.

meanings.definition: developing as expected:
examples: We were behind schedule on this job, but we’re back on track now.

meanings.definition: If something is on view, it is arranged so that it can be seen by the public:
examples: The plans for the new road will soon be on view to the public in the library.
The paintings are on view in the city's museum.
The wedding gifts are currently on view in the great hall.
Examples of the paintings are also on view on the museum's website.
Yesterday, the gallery put its latest acquisition on view.

meanings.definition: receiving financial help from the state because you are poor or have not been employed for a long time:
examples: Over 53,000 families in the region are currently on welfare.
I met so many single parents on welfare.
The number of households on welfare is up 9 percent.
She was determined that she wouldn't stay on welfare for long.
At the time, she was pregnant and on welfare.
The fact is that most of these people on welfare are actually working.

meanings.definition: Something that is on wheels has wheels under it so that it can be pulled or pushed along:
examples: My suitcase is on wheels so that makes life a little easier.
I bought my niece one of those toy dogs on wheels.
He has a leaf blower that's on wheels and it's so much easier to use.
I hadn't noticed that the chair was on wheels.
We need some of those storage drawers on wheels.
It's described as a five-drawer storage cart on wheels.

meanings.definition: according to the qualities you have or have shown, without considering any other information or comparing you to someone else:
examples: The committee will consider each applicant on his or her own merits.
We will listen to all the arguments and judge them on their merits.
You will be treated fairly and evaluated on your merits.
Did they reach their positions on their own merits?
I am proud to be here on my own merits and not because of who my parents are.

meanings.definition: If you have someone on your arm at an event, they go to the event with you as your friend or romantic partner:
examples: Bill arrived at the party with his new partner on his arm.
My little brother turned up with a glamorous actress on his arm.
The tabloids were eager to see who would be on his arm at the film premiere.
There's the foundation's director, and, on his arm, the honoured guest for the evening.
Every time I see her around town, she's got a new man on her arm!

meanings.definition: a rude way of telling someone to go away:
examples: "Can you lend me some money?" "On your bike, mate!"

meanings.definition: A person who is on their last legs is very tired or near to death:
examples: We'd been out walking all day and I was on my last legs when we reached the hotel.
It looks as though her grandfather's on his last legs.

on-your-marks-get-set-go.name: on your marks, get set, go!

meanings.definition: something called out to competitors at the beginning of a running race
ready to do something as well as you can in a difficult situation:
examples: Both players were on their mettle in the final round.
Cooking for such important people really puts you on your mettle.

on-own-head-be-it.name: on your own head be it

meanings.definition: used to tell someone that they will have to take full responsibility for what they plan to do
alone: If you do something on your own, you do it without help from anyone else:
examples: I don’t mind going to the movies on my own.
Bridget learned to tie her shoes on her own when she was three.

meanings.definition: If you do something on your own initiative, you plan it and decide to do it yourself without anyone telling you what to do:
examples: Some states acted under threat of litigation, and others on their own initiative.
Some students, on their own initiative, have started a series of discussions on race.
A week later he went humbly, and on his own initiative, to apologize to Marcia.
Acting on her own initiative, she arranged for a firm of cleaners to come to the house.
To be successful in this job, you have to be capable of working on your own initiative.

meanings.definition: during the time when you are not officially working:
examples: You may only use company computers to access the Web on your own time.
If I have to make any personal calls, I do it on my own time.
He insisted that he'd written the piece on his own time, during breaks.
If she'd wanted to meet up with her friend, she should have done it on her own time and not when she was supposed to be working.
If you want to send a personal email or make a call, you can always do it on your own time or during a lunch break.

meanings.definition: to be using your mobile phone to send messages, play games, look at the internet, etc.:
examples: These kids are on their phones all day long.
How much time would you say you spend on your phone?
We're not allowed to be on our phones during class.
He tripped while was on his phone because he didn't see the broken sidewalk.
The band has asked all concertgoers to surrender their phones at the entrance - they're sick of people being on their phones and not paying attention to the show.

meanings.definition: to be out on a regular visit:
examples: The doctor's out on his rounds.

meanings.definition: Someone or something that keeps you on your toes forces you to continue directing all your attention and energy to what you are doing:
examples: I work with people who are half my age so that keeps me on my toes.

meanings.definition: aware and energetic as a result of being busy and challenged:
examples: Teaching four different subjects keeps you on your toes.

meanings.definition: that is not continuous; that stops and starts again:
examples: The two were in a six year on-again, off-again relationship.

meanings.definition: helping a company present the image of itself and its products that it wants to present:
examples: It is better to recruit people who are naturally on-brand, than spend time and energy realigning them with the brand goals.
We have an on-brand internal culture.

meanings.definition: typical of a person:
examples: Always late - that's so on-brand.
I came with a duffel bag and left with a big suitcase - very on-brand for me.

meanings.definition: a cost that an employer has when they employ someone, in addition to the cost of paying the person's salary or wages:
examples: On-costs include pension contributions and payroll tax.

meanings.definition: to borrow money and lend it to someone:
examples: The bank proposed to on-lend the money to other banks at a rate of 15%.

meanings.definition: that can be in two positions, either on or off:
examples: The basic model uses a simple on-off switch.

meanings.definition: that is not continuous; that stops and starts again:
examples: an on-off romance
I need to add that this was not our first break-up; our relationship was on-off for about a year.

meanings.definition: a short road on which vehicles drive on to a highway or other main road
(of a perfomer, actor, etc.) when appearing in a film, on a TV show, etc., rather than in real life :
examples: The two actors have amazing chemistry on-screen.
Onscreen, she is full of surprises.
I didn't want to have my first kiss on screen.

meanings.definition: on the screen, so that the people who are watching or looking at the screen can see :
examples: Children often copy what they see on-screen.
You can use the device to scan the image and reproduce it on screen in an electronic format.

meanings.definition: used for describing a performer, actor, etc. when they are appearing in a film, on a TV show, etc., rather than in their own life:
examples: Her on-screen husband is also her partner in real life.
Is the on-screen rivalry between the brothers real?

meanings.definition: appearing on the screen, so people watching or looking at the screen can see:
examples: Follow the on-screen instructions.
Some programmes have an onscreen sign language interpreter.

meanings.definition: on the screen of a television or computer:
examples: I easily adjusted the colors by using the on-screen menu.

meanings.definition: existing or happening in the place where people are working or involved in a particular activity:
examples: on-site facilities
We're meeting the contractor on-site tomorrow.

meanings.definition: on a public road or street, or found or happening on roads or streets:
examples: Houston has 277 miles of on-street bikeways.

The city's on-street recycling bins are surprisingly attractive.
It was feared that tables and chairs outside the restaurant would encourage on-street drinking.
One night, the rift boiled over into an on-street confrontation.

meanings.definition: happening while you are at work:
examples: on-the-job training/learning

meanings.definition: done or happening where someone works and while they do their job:
examples: Applicants for entry-level positions will receive on-the-job training.

on-the-job accidents/injuries

meanings.definition: used to describe something that arrives, happens, or is done when it should and is not late:
examples: The airline ranked last in on-time arrivals last month.
Lenders might offer a discount after a borrower has made continuous on-time payments for three or four years.

meanings.definition: very fashionable:
examples: the best place to buy cheap, on-trend party clothes

meanings.definition: in a pocket, bag, or something else that you are holding:
examples: Do you have about your person such a thing as a lighter?

meanings.definition: in many places along the streets of a town or city:
examples: After the game, police were stationed on every corner.

meanings.definition: If you are on the sidelines or do something from the sidelines, you are not actively involved in something:
examples: Women have been on the political sidelines for too long - we must now work towards getting into power.

meanings.definition: If you have to do something on/under pain of death, you will be killed if you do not do it.
to give new employees the knowledge and skills they need to become effective members of an organization:
examples: He gives some tips on how to onboard new employees remotely.
Before a company commits to onboarding new employees, all the departments involved should meet and come up with a realistic plan of action.

meanings.definition: the process in which new employees gain the knowledge and skills they need to become effective members of an organization:
examples: The right onboarding process can make a huge difference in the long-term performance of a new employee.

meanings.definition: one single time:
examples: I went sailing once, but I didn't like it.
We have lunch together once a month.

meanings.definition: in the past, but not now:
examples: This house once belonged to my grandfather.
Computers are much cheaper nowadays than they once were.

meanings.definition: as soon as, or from the moment when:
examples: Once I've found somewhere to live I'll send you my address.
Remember that you won't be able to cancel the contract once you've signed.

meanings.definition: on or at a single time:
examples: I went to Disney World once.
The book club meets once a month.
Going to the Olympics is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity (= a rare and valuable one).

meanings.definition: in the past, but not now:
examples: I lived in Milwaukee once.
Computers are much cheaper now than they once were.

meanings.definition: as soon as, or when:
examples: Once you’ve tried their ice cream, you’ll be back for more.

meanings.definition: If something happens once again, it has already happened several times before:
examples: You are reminded once again of the author's love of the sea.

meanings.definition: completely and finally:
examples: We have to decide, once and for all, whether we want to ask Dad for money.

meanings.definition: said when you are frightened to do something again because you had an unpleasant experience doing it the first time
not very often:
examples: My sister lives in Alaska, so I only see her once in a blue moon.

meanings.definition: rarely:
examples: Once in a blue moon he’d call, but for months at a time we heard nothing.

meanings.definition: another time:
examples: I’ll explain it once more, but listen this time.

meanings.definition: used at the beginning of children's stories to mean "a long time ago": used when referring to something that happened in the past, especially when showing that you feel sorry that it no longer happens:
examples: Once upon a time there was an ugly duckling.
Once upon a time people knew the difference between right and wrong, but nowadays nobody seems to care.

meanings.definition: A once-in-a-lifetime experience or opportunity is very special because you will probably only have it once:
examples: A tour of Australia is a once-in-a-lifetime experience.

meanings.definition: the act of quickly cleaning a place:
examples: Would you mind giving the carpet a once-over with the vacuum cleaner?

meanings.definition: a quick examination of someone or something:
examples: The security guards gave me the once-over.

meanings.definition: a gene that is present in every cell and causes a healthy cell to become cancerous under particular conditions
related to the study and treatment of tumours (= masses of cells, as in cancer) in the body:
examples: He specializes in oncological medicine.
oncological treatment

meanings.definition: a doctor who studies and treats tumours (= masses of cells, as in cancer) in the body:
examples: His oncologist suggested that he join the clinical trial.

meanings.definition: the study and treatment of tumours (= masses of cells) in the body
moving towards you or coming nearer:
examples: The car veered onto the wrong side of the road and hit an oncoming truck.
There seemed to be no way of averting the oncoming crisis.

meanings.definition: moving toward or approaching you:
examples: His car was struck by an oncoming vehicle.

meanings.definition: the number 1:
examples: He had two slices and I only had one.
She'll be one year old tomorrow.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a time in the future that is not yet decided:
examples: Why don't we meet for lunch one day next week?
I'd like to go skiing one Christmas.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a particular occasion while avoiding stating the exact moment:
examples: One night we stayed up talking till dawn.
He was attacked as he was walking home from work late one afternoon.
One moment he says he loves me, the next moment he's asking for a divorce.
She never seems to know what she's doing from one minute to the next.

meanings.definition: a single thing; not two or more:
examples: Eat them one at a time (= separately).
I think we should paint the bedroom all one (= in a single) colour.
Do you think five of us will manage to squeeze into the one car?

meanings.definition: used when saying there is no other person or thing:
examples: He's the one person you can rely on in an emergency.

My final guest on tonight's show needs no introduction. Please welcome the one and only Michael Jordan!

meanings.definition: used before the name of someone who is not known:
examples: Her solicitor is one John Wintersgill.

meanings.definition: used to emphasize an adjective:
examples: His mother is one (= a very) generous woman.
That's one (= a very) big ice cream cone you have there.
It was one hell of a (= a very great) shock to find out I'd lost my job.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a particular thing or person within a group or range of things or people that are possible or available:
examples: I have a few books on Chinese food. You can borrow one if you want.
Which one would you like?
Please make a copy for everybody in the office and a few extra ones for the visitors.
"Which cake would you like?" "The one in the front."
French croissants are so much better than the ones we get here.
There were lots of people watching, and not one of them offered to help.
I've received no replies to my job applications - not a single one (= none).
Chris is the one (= the person) with curly brown hair.

meanings.definition: used to talk about one person or thing compared with other similar or related people or things:
examples: They look so similar it's often difficult to distinguish one from the other.
You may have one or the other, but not both.
Crime and freedom are inseparable. You can't have one without the other.

meanings.definition: any person, but not a particular person:
examples: One has an obligation to one's friends.
One ought to make the effort to vote.

meanings.definition: the person speaking or writing:
examples: Of course, one (= I) would be delighted to dine with the Queen.
I have one brother and two sisters.
Paula rented a one-room studio apartment.

meanings.definition: One can also mean one o’clock.
not two or more:
examples: There are too many of us to fit in just one car.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a particular thing or person within a group or range of things or people:
examples: There are lots of flavors – which one would you like?
He advised workers around him, especially the younger ones, to be patient.
Kayla is the one with dark brown hair.
Make sure the ones that we've got there do what you want them to do.
She is one beautiful woman (= she is very beautiful).
Why don’t we meet for lunch one day next week?

meanings.definition: used when saying there is no other person or thing:
examples: He’s the one person you can rely on in an emergency.

meanings.definition: any person, but not a particular person:
examples: One ought to make the effort to vote.

meanings.definition: everyone:
examples: The news of his resignation came as a surprise to one and all.

meanings.definition: done, or doing something, only once and never again:
examples: This is not a one and done process.
Trying something new shouldn't be a one and done exercise.
She knows something about one-and-done governors, having worked for the last governor to be denied term No. 2.

meanings.definition: only:
examples: This may be your one and only opportunity to meet her.

meanings.definition: the only person or thing of this type:
examples: And now I'd like to introduce, the one and only Stevie Wonder!

meanings.definition: the same thing or person:
examples: I was amazed to discover that Mary's husband and Jane's son are one and the same (person).

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         each other
each other
separately, one after the other:
examples: One by one the old buildings in the city have been demolished and replaced with new high rises.
They entered the room one by one.

meanings.definition: one person or thing following another in order:
examples: The children filed out of the bus, one by one.

meanings.definition: at some time in the future:
examples: I'd like to go to Berlin again one day.

meanings.definition: at some time in the future:
examples: I’d like to go to Mexico again one day.

meanings.definition: a surprising or unexpected event:
examples: Well, that's one for the books - I never thought he'd get the job.

meanings.definition: an alcoholic drink just before leaving:
examples: Before I went home, she persuaded me to have one for the road.

meanings.definition: said when you do a helpful or kind act for someone who has done something good for you
completely; used for emphasizing what you are saying:
examples: I agree with you one hundred percent.
We won't do anything until we're a hundred percent certain.
It was hundred percent his fault.

one-hundred-two-hundred-etc-hours.name: one hundred, two hundred, etc. hours

meanings.definition: used to say the time using the 24-hour system, especially used in the military:
examples: Breakfast is at seven hundred hours.
The plane took off at eight hundred hours and returned six hours later.
The briefing is due to begin at zero six hundred hours.
The time is oh five hundred hours.
At zero four hundred hours they fixed bayonets and began the attack.

meanings.definition: extremely unlikely: a very special person:
examples: Don't worry - the chances of anything going wrong are one in a million.
Thanks again - you're one in a million!
Your daughter's a very special young girl - one in a million.

one-man-s-loss-is-another-man-s-gain.name: one man's loss is another man's gain

meanings.definition: said when someone gets an advantage from someone else's bad luck

one-man-s-meat-is-another-man-s-poison.name: one man's meat is another man's poison

meanings.definition: said to emphasize that people like different things
used to describe a product or service that is the only one of its type, or that is very unusual:
examples: The one-of-a-kind pieces are due to go to auction later this month.

meanings.definition: a typical male:
examples: He plays baseball, drinks a lot of beer and generally acts like one of the boys.
Despite being a father and holding down a responsible job, he remains one of the boys.
I think he wants to be seen as one of the boys.
To be honest, I always thought of him as just one of the boys.
I remember Ethan from my schooldays, when he was very much one of the boys.
I liked baseball and hated dresses, and they treated me like one of the boys.

meanings.definition: some time in the near future:
examples: You're going to get into serious trouble one of these days.

meanings.definition: a bad day, full of problems:
examples: It's just been one of those days.

meanings.definition: a bad day when things do not happen as you would like them to:
examples: I forgot to call her again - it's just been one of those days.

meanings.definition: a few:
examples: I'd like to make one or two suggestions.

meanings.definition: slowly and carefully, doing just a little at a time:
examples: He wanted to rush through the job, but I encouraged him to take it one step at a time.

one-step-forward-two-steps-back.name: one step forward, two steps back

meanings.definition: If you take one step forward, two steps back, you make progress but then experience events that cause you to be further behind than you were when you made the progress.

one-swallow-doesn-t-make-a-summer.name: one swallow doesn't make a summer

meanings.definition: used to say that because one good thing has happened, it is not therefore certain that a situation is going to improve
If one thing leads to another, there is a series of events in which each event was caused by the previous one:
examples: At first, we were just talking a little, but one thing led to another, and he asked me out.

meanings.definition: an event or activity results in another that you have usually not planned:
examples: I agreed to help him paint the house, and one thing led to another until I ended up helping him fix his kitchen.

meanings.definition: If you have had one too many, you have drunk too much alcohol.
in some way that is not known yet:
examples: We'll get out of this mess one way or another.
They are looking, one way or another, for ways to earn money.
One way or another, we have to find money for defendants who can't afford a lawyer.
One way or another, businesses need to take responsiblity for the safe disposal of their products.

meanings.definition: which of two possibilities will be chosen: whatever method is used:
examples: They've had two weeks to think about it, and now they have to decide one way or the other.
One way or the other, this project has to be finished by Tuesday.

one-two-etc-down-one-two-etc-to-go.name: one, two, etc. down, one, two etc. to go.

meanings.definition: an expression that is used to mean that you have done or dealt with the first, second, etc. of a series of things and have yet to do or deal with the rest:
examples: "How are your finals going?" "Two down, three to go."

meanings.definition: in basketball, an act in which a player is given a chance to make a free throw and then a second free throw if the first one is successful:
examples: His first attempt at the one-and-one rolled off the rim, and Marcus grabbed the rebound for the other team.
She went to the free-throw line for a one-and-one that could have tied the game, but her first shot missed the basket.

meanings.definition: a type of slot machine with a large metal pole on the side that you pull to make it work
having height or width or length, but not two or all of these
boring or showing few different qualities:

meanings.definition: a film or part of a film that has one continuous shot (= a short piece in which there is a single action or a short series of actions):

meanings.definition:
→

meanings.definition: If two people discuss something one-to-one, they discuss it directly, without involving anyone else:

meanings.definition: becoming more and more successful:

meanings.definition: If you move onwards, you continue to go forwards:
examples: We sailed onwards in a westerly direction.

meanings.definition: becoming more and more successful:
examples: Her publishing career started as an editorial assistant on a women's magazine and it was onwards and upwards from there.

meanings.definition: a valuable stone that is used in jewellery, with white, black, grey, and other coloured stripes
a cell in an ovary (= organs that produce eggs) which may form an ovum (= an egg cell):
examples: An in vitro experiment was conducted with fertilized mouse oocytes.
There are guidelines on the experimental use of human sperm, oocytes, and embryos.

meanings.definition: a dog with one parent that is a poodle (= a breed of dog with curly hair) and one parent that is another breed:
examples: Oodles are becoming more and more popular as family pets.
Oodle dog breeds are better for asthma sufferers.

meanings.definition: a very large amount of something pleasant:
examples: She inherited oodles of money from her uncle.

meanings.definition: very large amounts:
examples: She inherited oodles of money.

meanings.definition: an expression of surprise, pleasure, approval, disapproval, or pain:
examples: Ooh, what a gorgeous dress!
Ooh, yes, that would be nice!
Ooh, that's really mean!

meanings.definition: used to express surprise, pleasure, or approval:
examples: Ooh, I like that sauce they put on the fish.

meanings.definition: to express admiration:
examples: We watched the fireworks, oohing and aahing with everyone else.

meanings.definition: a phrase, originally from France, used for showing surprise, admiration, or excitement about something, especially when referring to something that is connected with France or French people, or when something of a sexual nature is involved:
examples: Someone actually said "ooh la la" when they saw his new barbecue.
Have the French experience at home. Ooh la la! Why not visit France from your PC?
Add a touch of ooh la la to your outfit with these thigh length leather boots.
The train juddered to a halt, and oh la la, we were in France!

meanings.definition: the study or collecting of eggs, especially birds' eggs
a type of Chinese tea with curly leaves:
examples: Brew oolong and black teas at 180 to 200 degrees.

meanings.definition: power, strength, or energetic activity:
examples: It's important to have a person with some oomph in charge of the department.
You want a car with a bit of oomph.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for out of office: a reply that can be automatically sent to an email that you have received when you are not in the office and cannot reply personally, or the system for sending such a reply:
examples: For fun OOO messages, they have created an Out of Office generator.
I've put my OOO on.

meanings.definition: an expression of surprise or feeling sorry about a mistake or slight accident:
examples: Oops! I typed two Ls by mistake.

meanings.definition: used to express surprise or regret about a mistake or slight accident
something said to young children when they fall over

abbreviation for occupational overuse syndrome: a painful medical condition that affects your hands, arms, back, etc. if you do a job that involves repeating the same action for long periods, for example computer work
to flow slowly out of something through a small opening, or to slowly produce a thick sticky liquid:
examples: Blood was still oozing out of the wound.
She removed the bandage to reveal a red swollen wound oozing pus.
The waiter brought her a massive pizza oozing (with) cheese.
He oozes (= has a lot of) charm/confidence.

meanings.definition: a thick brown liquid made of earth and water, found at the bottom of a river or lake:
examples: Many millions of years ago, our ancestors climbed out of the primeval ooze onto dry land.

meanings.definition: to flow slowly out through a small opening, or to slowly produce a liquid through such an opening:
examples: Sap oozed from the pine tree.
The wound oozed blood.
fig. The golfer was oozing confidence (= had a lot of confidence).

meanings.definition: a type of modern art that uses patterns that do not exist naturally in order to create images that appear to move or to be something that they are not
used to describe a piece of writing that expresses a personal opinion and is usually printed in a newspaper opposite the page on which the editorial is printed:
examples: an op-ed article/column/page

meanings.definition: a piece of writing that expresses a personal opinion and is usually printed in a newspaper opposite the page on which the editorial is printed:
examples: His rebuttal appeared in yesterday's op-ed.
He's written an op-ed that was published in yesterday's Los Angeles Times .

meanings.definition: a page or section of a newspaper with signed articles expressing personal opinions, usually opposite the page of editorials (= statements of the newspaper’s opinions)

informal for
        
         opportunity shop Australian English
used by writers to avoid repeating the details of a book or article that has already been referred to, when all the details other than the page number are the same:
examples: Johnson (op. cit., page 53) calls this phenomenon "the principle of minimal effort".

meanings.definition: the state of being opaque, or the degree to which something is opaque
the quality of being difficult to understand or know about, especially because things have been intentionally kept secret or made complicated :
examples: He believes the opacity of traditional property reporting has put off investors.

meanings.definition: a precious stone whose colour changes when the position of the person looking at it changes
the quality of reflecting light and changing colour like an opal:
examples: the milky opalescence of the northern sea
The hedge rose against the pale opalescence of the lower sky.

meanings.definition: Something that is opalescent reflects light and changes colour like an opal:
examples: the opalescent scales of a fish

meanings.definition: preventing light from travelling through, and therefore not transparent or translucent:
examples: opaque glass/tights

meanings.definition: Opaque writing or speech is difficult to understand:
examples: I find her poetry a little too opaque.

meanings.definition: (of a substance) preventing light from traveling through, and therefore not allowing you to see through it:
examples: opaque watercolors

meanings.definition: Opaque also means difficult to understand:
examples: The majority of readers found his poetry difficult, even opaque.

meanings.definition: difficult to understand or know about, especially because things have been intentionally kept secret or made complicated:
examples: Governments have been able to maintain opaque and discriminatory procurement practices.
Accounting firms have been notoriously opaque about their finances in the past.

meanings.definition: in a way that is difficult to understand:
examples: Her eyes were opaquely sad.
"I would be honoured," he said, while smiling opaquely.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for 
        
         operations process chart
abbreviation for Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries: a group of countries that produce oil and decide together how much to produce
abbreviation for Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries: a group of oil-producing countries who have an agreement to control the amount of oil that each country can produce and sell:
examples: Oil prices fell sharply after OPEC agreed to increase production.
Venezuela is able to sell three-quarters of its OPEC quota as refined products.
OPEC countries/members/leaders

meanings.definition: not closed or fastened:
examples: an open door/window
An open suitcase lay on her bed.
You left the container open.
Someone had left the window wide (= completely) open.
He had several nasty open wounds (= those which had not begun to heal).

meanings.definition: ready to be used or ready to provide a service:
examples: The supermarket is open till 8.00 p.m.
The road is open now, but it is often blocked by snow in the winter.
The new hospital was declared open by the mayor.

meanings.definition: not closed in or covered:
examples: It's not a good idea to camp in the middle of an open field (= one which is not covered with trees, bushes, etc.).
Suddenly we had left the city behind and were out in open country.
The survivors were adrift on the open sea (= far from land).

meanings.definition: If a computer document or program is open, it is ready to be read or used:
examples: Make sure you have both files open at the same time.

meanings.definition: available; not limited:
examples: There are still several possibilities open to you.
The competition is open to anyone over the age of 16.
Is the library open to the general public?
Their whole attitude to these negotiations is open to criticism (= can be criticized).
I'd like to think I'm open to (= willing to consider) any reasonable suggestion.
An accident would lay the whole issue of safety open (= cause it to be considered).

meanings.definition: not secret:
examples: There has been open hostility between them ever since they had that argument last summer.

meanings.definition: honest and not trying to keep things secret:
examples: He's very open about his weaknesses.
I wish you'd be more open with me, and tell me what you're feeling.
She has an honest, open face.

meanings.definition: not decided or certain:
examples: We don't have to make a firm decision yet. Let's leave it open.
We can leave our offer open for another week, but we have to have your decision by then.
I want to keep my options open, so I'm not committing myself yet.

meanings.definition: An open question can be answered in many different ways, and not with just "yes" or "no" or by choosing one of a number of fixed answers:
examples: Ask an open question along the lines of "What do you think/feel about this?"
The interviewer should ask open and probing questions.

meanings.definition: An open string on an instrument such as a guitar is does not have a finger or a capo (= a device fixed across the strings) pressing down on it:
examples: The lowest violin note available in first position in standard tuning is an open G.
He altered the cello's usual tuning on some tracks to let open strings resound.

meanings.definition: to (cause to) begin:
examples: I would like to open my talk by giving a brief background to the subject.
I'm going to open an account with another bank.
The Olympic Games open tomorrow.
A new radio station is due to open (up) next month.
The film opens (= will be shown for the first time) in New York and Los Angeles next week.

meanings.definition: to move something to a position that is not closed, or to make something change to a position that is not closed:
examples: Could you open the window, please?
You can open your eyes now - here's your present.
The flowers open (out) in the morning but close again in the afternoon.
From the kitchen there is a door that opens (out) into the garden.
That door opens (out) onto the patio.
"Open up (= open the door) - it's the police!" shouted the police officer, banging on the door.

meanings.definition: to remove or separate part of a container or parcel so that you can see or use what it contains:
examples: Don't open a new bottle just for me.
I couldn't wait to open the letter.

meanings.definition: If a shop or office opens at a particular time of day, it starts to do business at that time:
examples: The coffee shop opens at ten o'clock.
He opens (up) his coffee shop at ten o'clock.

meanings.definition: If someone, usually someone important, opens a building, event, etc., they officially say that it is ready to be used or to start operating:
examples: The new hospital will be officially opened by the mayor on Tuesday.

meanings.definition: to make something available:
examples: This research opens (up) the possibility of being able to find a cure for the disease.
The country is planning to open (up) its economy to foreign investment.

meanings.definition: If you open a computer document or program, you make it ready to read or use:
examples: To open a new document, click "File" and then click "New".
Click the desktop icon to open the Cambridge Advanced Learner's Dictionary.

meanings.definition: being in a position that allows things to pass through or that allows for immediate use; not closed or fastened:
examples: The window was wide open.
The trunk of his car had been pried open.

meanings.definition: ready to be used or to provide a service:
examples: The supermarket is open till 9 p.m.

meanings.definition: not decided or certain:
examples: I want to keep my options open until I have all the facts.
Whether we’ll go is still an open question.
You should keep an open mind about your new school (= not form any opinions) until you’ve been there.

meanings.definition: not secret:
examples: Open warfare had broken out in Yugoslavia.

meanings.definition: A person who is open is honest and not trying to hide something:
examples: He is quite open about his weaknesses.

meanings.definition: not enclosed or covered:
examples: The park is one of the city’s largest open spaces.

meanings.definition: available; not limited:
examples: Are there any positions open in the marketing department?
This library is open to the general public.
Their behavior at these negotiations is open to criticism (= can be criticized).
I’m open to (= willing to consider) any reasonable suggestion.

meanings.definition: to begin something or cause it to begin:
examples: I would like to open the meeting by asking each of you to introduce yourself.
They’re opening up a new restaurant in about a month.
The film opens (= will be shown for the first time) next week.

meanings.definition: to become or make something ready to provide a service:
examples: The cleaners opens (up) around seven.
They opened the exhibit to the public yesterday.

meanings.definition: if a shop, bank, office, etc. is open, its door are unlocked and it is doing business:
examples: Our offices are open from 9 to 5.
The club has a liquor license allowing it to remain open until 2 a.m.
The new airport terminal is now open for business.

meanings.definition: if a financial market is open, investors can trade shares, bonds, etc. on it:
examples: For the purposes of this agreement, a business day is any day that the New York Stock Exchange is open for business.

meanings.definition: willing to consider something:
examples: A spokesman for the organization said they were open to a deal at the right price.
open to offers/suggestions/negotiation

meanings.definition: available to be used, considered, etc. :
examples: Membership is open to all local businesses.
The appeals court left open the possibility that the computing giant could be forced to change its business practices.

meanings.definition: not secret or hidden from members, the public, etc.:
examples: After the economic crisis, consumers expect banks to be more open and transparent about their lending policies.

meanings.definition: allowing everyone to share their ideas and information:
examples: These are complicated questions, and we welcome an open discussion about them.
open communication

meanings.definition: if a computer file, document, or program is open, it is ready to be used:
examples: Make sure the file you're copying to is open before you click 'Paste'.

meanings.definition: to start doing business and dealing with customers :
examples: We open daily from 11 to 6.

meanings.definition: to start a new business:
examples: The Chicago-based coffee chain has opened branches in every major city in the UK.

meanings.definition: if shares, bonds, etc. open at a particular price or rate, that is the amount they are worth when trading starts that day:
examples: Share prices on the London Stock Exchange opened lower today.

meanings.definition: to start something:
examples: The Chief Executive opened the meeting with an announcement of big redundancies throughout the group.
The union had not yet decided when to open negotiations with management.

meanings.definition: if you open a computer file, document, or program you make it ready for you to start reading or working on:
examples: You can open the program from the menu or by double-clicking the icon.

meanings.definition: the time when a stock market begins trading:
examples: Bonds rose at the open after a cut in German interest rates.
Stocks fell heavily at the open of trading today.

meanings.definition: to open the lock on the door of a building:
examples: The caretaker opens up the school every morning at seven.

meanings.definition: to improve a situation by making it less limited:
examples: The government has announced plans to open up access to higher education.

meanings.definition: to show something that was hidden or not previously known:
examples: The debate could open up sharp differences between the countries.

meanings.definition: to do a medical operation on someone to see inside their body:
examples: When they opened her up, they couldn't find anything wrong with her.

meanings.definition: to start to talk more about yourself and your feelings:
examples: I've never opened up to anyone like I do to you.

meanings.definition: (used as an exclamation) let me in; open the door:
examples: "Open up!" Sam shouted, banging on the door.

meanings.definition: to talk about your personal thoughts or feelings:
examples: I felt I couldn’t open up to anybody.

meanings.definition: to make something available:
examples: Robinson, the first black player, opened up a wealth of opportunity for others.

meanings.definition: to make something larger or less enclosed:
examples: We’re going to open up the kitchen by knocking down that wall.

meanings.definition: if a new business, office, shop, etc. opens up, or someone opens it up, it starts doing business:
examples: Several branches of the bank have recently opened up across China.
Many people have opened up shops on the online auction site to sell their things.

meanings.definition: to start business at a particular time and be available to deal with customers:
examples: We open up at 7am daily.

meanings.definition: to make conditions easier for foreign companies to do business in a country:
examples: These measures are designed to open up the market to greater competition.
The country has enjoyed steady growth since it began opening up its economy.

meanings.definition: to create new opportunities:
examples: The internet has opened up new opportunities for cost-effective brand building.

meanings.definition: if a job opens up, it becomes available:
examples: Another vacancy has opened up on the Board.

meanings.definition: to create a situation that causes a lot of problems when it starts to be dealt with:
examples: She is afraid that she will open a can of worms if she speaks out about the problem.
Corruption is a serious problem, but nobody has yet been willing to open up that can of worms.

meanings.definition: an agreement with a business that allows a customer to pay for goods at a later date within an agreed period:
examples: Exporters selling on open account to unknown buyers should have insurance to cover any losses.

meanings.definition: a system that allows students to go to a college without having any special qualifications for it
an arrangement by which children are legally adopted by people who are not their natural parents, but still continue to communicate with their natural parents
to make an arrangement with a bank in which they look after your money and you add to it or take it out when you need to:
examples: I've opened an account with a building society .
You should open an online account with the provider of your choice.

meanings.definition: an offer to supply goods or services at a particular price that is not kept secret, so that other companies can offer to supply the goods, etc. at a lower price if they want to :
examples: Open bids for running water services are seen by companies as a way of increasing earnings and share price.

meanings.definition: a price that someone offers to pay for something that is not kept secret:
examples: The open bid of $1.5 million eclipsed our reserve of $1 million.

meanings.definition: a situation in which people offer to supply goods or services at a particular price or offer to pay a particular price to buy something, and the offers are not kept secret:
examples: The contract was awarded through a competitive, open bidding process.

meanings.definition: a management style that encourages employees to work for a company’s success by sharing information with them about all its operations and results:
examples: During his career at the company, he converted the firm to open book management.

meanings.definition: a situation in which goods and people can enter and leave a country easily:
examples: There should be an open border between the two countries.
an open borders agreement

meanings.definition: the act of carrying a gun in public in a way that people can see:
examples: We live in a state where open carry is still legal.

meanings.definition: a cheque which has been signed, but does not have the amount of money written on it
a situation in which there are no limits to the amount of money given to a person, project, etc.:
examples: The new manager was given an open cheque to sign new players.

meanings.definition: a city that cannot be controlled by either side in a war:
examples: It was declared an open city protected by the United Nations, and this did much to reduce the fighting.
The diplomats discussed a plan in which the capital would become a neutral open city until a government was established.

meanings.definition: in the US, a system for educating young children in which classes and activities are informal and changed to suit each child

a day when an organization such as a school, college, or factory allows members of the public to go in and see what happens there
to make things possible that were not possible before:
examples: You will graduate with a degree that will open doors for you across a broad range of occupations.
A broad-minded, more assertive approach opens new doors.

meanings.definition: an economy where goods and services are traded with other countries without rules or limits:
examples: Mexico maintained its push for an open economy and free trade.

meanings.definition: a fire that you light outside, for example to cook on:
examples: The campers roasted marshmallows over an open fire.
chestnuts roasting on an open fire

meanings.definition:
an 
        
         open fireplace  :
examples: Both rooms have an open fire.

meanings.definition: a space in a wall of a building in which a fire can be lit, with a chimney to take the smoke away
a day when an organization such as a school, college, or factory allows members of the public to go in and see what happens there
a time when a house or apartment that is being sold can be looked at by the public
a situation in which people welcome visitors at any time:
examples: We keep open house, so come and see us any time.

meanings.definition: a party at which visitors are welcome in your home:
examples: We’re having an open house on Sunday.

meanings.definition: a time when a house or apartment that is being sold or is available for rent can be looked at by the public
an occasion when an organization such as a school or college allows members of the public in to see what happens there
an insurance agreement that relates to all the goods sent by a producer, etc. during a period of time

the total number of futures contracts (= agreements to sell shares, etc. on a particular date in the future) or options contracts (= agreements to buy shares, etc. on a particular date in the future) that have not been finished or cancelled:
examples: At the beginning of the year, open interest totaled only 148,000 contracts.

meanings.definition: a way of studying that allows people to learn where and when they want, and to receive and send written work by mail or email:
examples: Distance learning is a form of open learning in which tutors and learners are separated by geographical distance.
open learning centres/programmes

meanings.definition: a letter intended to be read by a lot of people, not just the person it is written to:
examples: An open letter to the prime minister, signed by several MPs, appeared in today's papers.

meanings.definition: a situation in which companies can trade freely without limits, and prices are changed according to the number of goods and how many people are buying them:
examples: In the meantime, the stock will continue to trade on the open market.

meanings.definition: a trading situation in which anyone can be involved and prices are not controlled:
examples: New apartments will be built and sold on the open market to those who can afford them.

meanings.definition: an economic system where there are no rules about how much of something people can buy and sell:
examples: The EU is meant to be an open market, with no restrictions on purchases and sales within its borders.

meanings.definition: a situation in which a country's central bank buys and sells in a financial market to increase or reduce the money supply (= the amount of money in an economy):
examples: When a central bank conducts open market operations, conditions in the financial sector could be affected.

meanings.definition: a marriage in which both partners are free to have sexual relationships with other people
an event at which anyone is allowed to tell jokes, read poetry, sing, etc. on stage:
examples: There's live music with an open mic and a free pint for all performers.
It's a bit like open mic night at your local comedy club.

meanings.definition: an offer made by a company to its shareholders inviting them to buy new shares in the company at a fixed price, which is normally lower than the usual price:
examples: The company plans to raise cash for the acquisition through an open offer of 30 million new shares.

meanings.definition: a method of trading on a financial market in which people shout out their bids and offers, rather than trading using the phone or online:
examples: Dealers conduct their business via display screens linked to a central computer rather than by open outcry on a trading floor.
open-outcry dealing/trading
an open-outcry exchange/system/trader

meanings.definition: the area of floor in a financial market where people shout out their bids and offers, rather than trading over the telephone or online:
examples: The majority of trade is done through open outcry pits with dealers shouting orders across the floor.

meanings.definition: a situation in which someone could lose money because of changes in the value of shares, currencies, etc. that they have traded but for which the sale is not complete:
examples: The open position of each investor is then "marked to market" every day.

meanings.definition: a job that is available:
examples: Employers receive hundreds, even thousands, of applications for every open position.

meanings.definition: a primary in which everyone who is allowed to vote can choose either party's ballot (= list of candidates) in order to vote for a candidate to represent that party at a later election:
examples: In an open primary, you can vote for a candidate from either party.
Last year's ruling prevented the state from using an open primary.
She believes that open primaries encourage more candidates to run.
Some of the candidates wanted to prevent an open primary.
He won an open primary election in November.

meanings.definition: a prison where prisoners have more freedom than in other types of prisons because they are not considered dangerous and are trusted not to escape:
examples: He has been transferred from an open prison to a higher security jail.
Many inmates who would have been sent to open prisons are instead being let out on electronic tags.

meanings.definition: a single slice of bread with various types of food, such as cheese or cold meat, on the top
the period in the year when it is legal to hunt particular animals
a situation that allows or causes a particular group of people to be treated unfairly:
examples: To pass this legislation would be to declare open season on homosexuals.

meanings.definition: the period in the year when it is legal to hunt particular animals:
examples: If wolves are taken off the endangered list, does that mean it's open season for hunters?
fig. The mayor has declared open season on jaywalkers.

meanings.definition: a fact that should be a secret when in fact a lot of people know about it:
examples: It's an open secret around the office that they're having an affair.

meanings.definition: something that makes it very easy to achieve a particular thing:
examples: A science degree can be an open sesame to a job in almost any field.

meanings.definition: a channel for carrying away waste water and waste from the human body that is above the ground and is not covered:
examples: Next to the filthy alley is what appears to be an open sewer.
We carried on, walking by mounds of garbage and open sewers.
This is an area of dirt roads and open sewers.
The villagers warned her away from drinking from the river, which was little more than an open sewer.
These families live in one-room shacks next to open sewers.
Open sewers can spread disease, so we've requested funds to begin building pit latrines in our area.

meanings.definition: a company, factory, etc. at which employees do not have to join a union:
examples: In an open shop, union members pay dues, and those who choose not to join pay nothing.

meanings.definition: in rugby, the side of the scrum (= the group of players from each team who come together with their heads down and arms joined, and push against each other, trying to take control of the ball) that is furthest from the edge of the playing area:
examples: Jim was injured so they brought Gerald in on the open side.
England had four players lined up on the open-side.

meanings.definition: a rugby player who plays on the open side:
examples: The Wasps' coach says he is the best open side in the world.
The talented open-side got another yellow card.
The New Zealand squad has some quick opensides.

meanings.definition: in rugby, playing on, or relating to, the side of the scrum (= the group of players from each team who come together with their heads down and arms joined, and push against each other, trying to take control of the ball) that is furthest from the edge of the playing area:
examples: I was an open side flanker when I played rugby.
He was asked to play at open side flank.
Webster is regarded more as a blindside flanker than an openside wing forward.
The flanker was named man of the match after his last minute try finished a masterclass of open-side play.

meanings.definition: a situation in which governments of different countries allow companies from those countries to offer air passenger services between each other:
examples: The proposed alliance between the two airline companies could break the five-year deadlock on open skies.
an open skies accord/agreement/deal

meanings.definition: to make someone realize something surprising or shocking that they had not known about or understood before:
examples: She really opened my eyes to how stupid I'd been.

meanings.definition: to show someone something, esp. something surprising or shocking that the person had not known about or understood before:
examples: She opened my eyes to how stupid I’d been.

meanings.definition: to make a space larger or less closed in:
examples: We're going to open up our kitchen by taking out a couple of walls.

meanings.definition: Open source software or information can be obtained legally and for free from the internet, and can be used, shared or changed without paying or asking for special permission:
examples: The machine runs on free, open source software.
All of his data is open source.

meanings.definition: to choose not to be part of an activity, arrangement, etc.:
examples: New employees are automatically enrolled in the union, unless they opt out.

meanings.definition: a situation in which some members of a group have the right not to join or be involved in a process:
examples: The President of the European Union added: "I think it is better to have opt-outs for one or two countries".
There is an opt-out for these employees from the requirement to have health coverage.
The contract bans opt-out agreements for employees on probation.
Privacy groups criticized the opt-out feature, because it appears in a pop-up window for only a few seconds before disappearing.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         opt
to make a choice, especially of one thing or possibility instead of others:
examples: Mike opted for early retirement.
Most people opt to have the operation.

meanings.definition: relating to light or the eyes:
examples: a fibre optic cable

meanings.definition: a device attached to a bottle of spirits in a bar that measures the correct amount for one (= one small drink)
referring to the eyes:
examples: the optic nerve

meanings.definition: a cup-like structure found in an embryo (= a baby before it is born) that develops into parts of the eye:
examples: The outer layer of the optic cup forms the pigmented epithelium of the retina.
Eye pigmentation begins in the optic cup.

meanings.definition: a small area at the back of the eye where the optic nerve joins the back of the retina (= the area of the back of the eye that receives light and sends pictures to the brain):
examples: The optic disc is nonpigmented and insensitive to light, and is also known as the blind spot.
Glaucoma is a group of eye diseases in which rising inner-eye pressure causes damaging changes to the optic disc.

meanings.definition: either of two areas in the middle part of the brain of humans and animals that are involved in dealing with information from the eyes:
examples: The optic lobe is primarily involved in the processing of visual information.
Birds have a smooth cerebral surface and very large optic lobes.

meanings.definition: the group of nerve fibres (= structures like threads) that pass signals from the retina at the back of each eye to the brain
either of two structures on the surface of the brain of an embryo (= a baby before it is born) that develops into an optic cup, and later into part of the eye:
examples: The eyes first appear as a pair of optic vesicles.
By four weeks, major regions of the human brain can be recognized, including the forebrain, midbrain, hindbrain, and optic vesicles from which the eyes develop.

meanings.definition: relating to light or the ability to see:
examples: The glowing cloud was an optical effect.
Her eye tests revealed that she has no optical defects.

meanings.definition: used in order to see something better:
examples: There are specialized optical aids which can help visually impaired people.
cameras, binoculars and other optical instruments

meanings.definition: reading or storing information using light:
examples: Optical drives displaced floppy disks and magnetic tape.
optical disks

meanings.definition: connected with the eyes or sight, or connected with or using light:
examples: an optical telescope

meanings.definition: relating to light and the ability to see:
examples: optical equipment/goods/devices
They manufacture a variety of lenses, mirrors, prisms, and other optical components.

meanings.definition: relating to the ability of a piece of electronic equipment to recognize printed or written letters or numbers:
examples: an optical scanner/reader

meanings.definition: an electronic device that recognizes printed or written letters or numbers:
examples: Another growing use for scanners is as optical character readers.
The charity will start raising cash for optical character readers that speak the printed word for blind people.

meanings.definition: the process by which an electronic device recognizes printed or written letters or numbers
the process by which a piece of electronic equipment recognizes printed or written letters or numbers:
examples: The scanner uses optical character recognition to convert paper documents to electronic files.

meanings.word_type: noun[ U or C usually singular ]
meanings.definition: the degree to which an object or material reduces the intensity of light passing through it:
examples: The slower that light is able to travel through a given medium, the higher the optical density of the medium.
The area and average optical density of each fibre is measured.

meanings.definition: a computer disc that is read by a laser (= a narrow beam of light). It can store sound, video, or computer data and programs:
examples: The system is intended for use with next generation optical discs, such as Blu-ray and HD-DVDs.

meanings.definition: part of a computer, CD player, or other piece of equipment that can read optical discs using a laser (= a narrow beam of light):
examples: The laptop costs $1598 with an external optical drive.

meanings.definition:
US spelling of 
        
         optical fibre
a very thin glass or plastic thread through which light can travel to carry information, especially in phone, television, and computer systems
a very thin glass or plastic thread that can send information in the form of light signals:
examples: A strand of optical fibre as thin as a human hair can transmit the equivalent of millions of words in a single second.
They develop and manufacture optical fibers and fiber optic products.

meanings.definition: something that tricks your eyes and makes you think you see something that is not really there, or see it differently from how it really is
something that you think you see, but that is not really there:
examples: Some sort of optical illusion makes these things seem to travel faster than they really do.

meanings.definition: a computer mouse that uses light rather than a rolling ball to know when the mouse is being moved:
examples: The computers all come with an optical mouse and a keyboard.

meanings.definition: a device that takes a picture of visual information and changes it into a form that a computer can store and show on its screen:
examples: The optical reader scans number plates and compares them against stolen vehicles.
Optical data readers can be used to scan a document and make sense of the patterns it finds within the document.
Some devices, such as optical mark readers, enable data to be entered directly, without human intervention.

meanings.definition: the use of light to write and read information to and from a device such as a CD or DVD:
examples: Optical storage formats such as DVDs use light to read and store data.
The first optical data storage disk contained 60 times the capacity of a 5 ¼-inch floppy disk.

meanings.definition: a device in a camera that uses the camera's lens to make the thing being photographed appear nearer:
examples: The camera comes with 10X optical zoom.
Most digital cameras have both optical zoom, in which the lens moves, and digital zoom, which manipulates the image electronically.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to light or the ability to see, or to what someone sees:
examples: These lightbulbs are bad optically—they cause a lot of glare.
The substance is polished to give an optically smooth surface.

meanings.definition: If information is read or stored optically, it is read or stored using light:
examples: People vote on paper ballots that are optically scanned by a machine or counted by hand.
A machine reads the card optically.

meanings.definition: someone whose job is examining people's eyes and selling glasses or contact lenses to correct sight problems
a person whose job is fitting and selling glasses and contact lenses to correct sight problems, but who does not examine people's eyes
a person who makes lenses for eyeglasses or sells eyeglasses
the study of light and of instruments using light
the public's opinion and understanding of a situation after seeing it as the media shows it, and the possible political effects of this:
examples: The political optics of this are horrible for the GOP.

meanings.definition: the study of light
the study of light or the use of light in technical instruments:
examples: The phone uses advanced optics to provide a sharp display.

meanings.definition: best; most likely to bring success or advantage:
examples: Several treatment sessions are required in order to obtain optimal results.
Conditions in the chamber are optimal for diffusion, reaching very high temperatures.

meanings.definition: optimum
the best or most effective possible in a particular situation:
examples: Companies benefit from the optimal use of their resources and personnel.
We have found that our workers reach their optimal level of performance around 11 a.m.
Different outsourcing levels may be considered optimal at different times.

meanings.definition: in the way that is most likely to bring success or advantage:
examples: How do I know if my computer is performing optimally?
To be optimally effective, the drug should be taken with food.

meanings.definition: the quality of being full of hope and emphasizing the good parts of a situation, or a belief that something good will happen:
examples: There was a note of optimism in his voice as he spoke about the company's future.
They had cause/grounds/reason for cautious optimism about an improvement in her medical condition.

meanings.definition: the tendency to be hopeful and to emphasize or think of the good part in a situation rather than the bad part, or the feeling that in the future good things are more likely to happen than bad things:
examples: There was a note of optimism in his voice as he spoke about his recovery.

meanings.definition: the feeling that good things are more likely to happen than bad things:
examples: There was a wave of optimism about future earnings of software and internet companies.
Some analysts expressed cautious optimism that this could be a turning point.
consumer/investor/public optimism
reason/cause for optimism

meanings.definition: someone who always believes that good things will happen:
examples: She's a born optimist (= someone who has always been optimistic).

meanings.definition: someone who feels that good things are more likely to happen than bad things:
examples: He takes an optimist's view of the recession.

meanings.definition: hoping or believing that good things will happen in the future:
examples: She is optimistic about her chances of winning a gold medal.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows that you hope or believe that good things will happen in the future:
examples: He optimistically predicted success.
Amy decided to look at the world optimistically.

meanings.definition: the act of making something as good as possible:
examples: the optimization of chemical processes

meanings.definition: the process of making something as good or effective as possible:
examples: The airline's scheduling optimization program ensures that it serves the maximum number of passengers.

meanings.definition: to make something as good as possible:
examples: We need to optimize our use of the existing technology.

meanings.definition: to make something as good or effective as possible:
examples: If you optimize the production process you could speed up the assembly line dramatically.

meanings.definition: best; most likely to bring success or advantage:

meanings.definition: being the best or most likely to bring success or advantage:
examples: For optimum flavor, prepare just before serving.

meanings.definition: the best or most effective possible in a particular situation:

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         opt
to make a choice, especially of one thing or possibility instead of others:
examples: Mike opted for early retirement.
Most people opt to have the operation.

meanings.definition: one thing that can be chosen from a set of possibilities, or the freedom to make a choice:
examples: The best option would be to cancel the trip altogether.
There are various options open to someone who is willing to work hard.
They didn't leave him much option - either he paid or they'd beat him up.

meanings.definition: the right to buy something in the future:
examples: a share option
a stock option
The publishers decided not to take up their option on the paperback version.

meanings.definition: relating to a play (= period of action) in American football in which a player on the offence who is carrying the ball can choose to run with it or pass it :
examples: The quarterback took off on an option run and gained twelve yards.
They can run a lot of option plays because they have a versatile running back who can run and catch.

meanings.definition: one thing that can be chosen from a set of possibilities, or the freedom to make a choice:
examples: The program helps students explore career options.

meanings.definition: An option is also a part of a contract that allows for something to happen in the future:
examples: He decided to exercise an option to break the team’s lease on the stadium.

meanings.definition: one of a number of choices or decisions you can make, or the ability or freedom to choose what you do:
examples: You need to think very carefully about the various options.
Our options look fairly limited at the moment.
Insurance policyholders with the company have the option of waiving the excess altogether.
Customers have the option to cancel the contract within 21 days.

In order to compete, we have no option but to cut prices.

meanings.definition: an agreement that can be bought and sold, that gives the owner the right to decide whether to buy or sell shares, bonds, etc. for a fixed price within an agreed time period or on a particular date:
examples: I took the job because they were offering good health care and stock options.
We acquired the right to own a 100% interest in the company, and we expect to exercise that option.

She has options on about 448,000 shares.

meanings.definition: an agreement in which a company buys a product from another company and has the right to buy more of that product later, but does not have to do so:
examples: The airline also said it plans to take options on three of the 777-200 jets.

meanings.definition: something that is added, at extra cost, to a basic product or service to make it more attractive, efficient, etc.:
examples: Options such as metallic paint and leather seats increase the price of the car considerably.

meanings.definition: one in a list of possible actions that appears on a computer screen when you click on a button:

meanings.definition: one of a set of numbered choices that you are given on the phone when you call a company or organization, that allow you to choose which person, department, etc. you want to speak to:

meanings.definition: the price for an option (= the right to buy shares, etc. at a particular price)
a way of calculating whether the price of an option (= the right to buy shares, etc. at a particular price) is fair:
examples: The option pricing model takes various risk factors into account.

meanings.definition: an agreement that gives an investor the right to buy a particular number of shares, or other financial assets, at a fixed price and before a fixed date:

meanings.definition: an agreement in which a company buys a product from another company and has the right to buy more of that product later, but does not have to do so:

meanings.definition: a financial agreement that gives someone the right to buy property or land within an agreed time and for an agreed amount, especially after they have rented it for a particular amount of time:
examples: The city leased the building to Rescue Ministries in 2009 with an option to buy.

If something is optional, you can choose if you want to do it, pay it, buy it, etc.:
examples: English is compulsory for all students, but art and music are optional.

meanings.definition: not necessary or demanded but possible or available; depending on what you decide to do:
examples: I think military service should be completely optional.

meanings.definition: something that is optional is something that you can buy or do if you want to, but that you do not have to buy or do:

meanings.definition: as something that you choose to do, buy, etc., because you want to and not because you must:

meanings.definition: the written legal agreement that gives someone the right to buy something such as shares at a later date or within a period of time at a particular price:

meanings.definition:
→

the job of examining people's eyes and selling glasses or contact lenses to correct sight problems:

meanings.definition: the quality of being expensive and luxurious:

meanings.definition: expensive and luxurious:

meanings.definition: rich in appearance; showing great wealth:
