examples: Idon't have any cash - is there no other way of paying?
He likes travelling abroad and learning about other people's customs and traditions.

meanings.definition: the second of two things or people, or the thing or person that is left in a group or set of things:
examples: Hold the racquet in one hand and the ball in the other.
Some people prefer a vegetarian diet, while others prefer a meat-based diet.
She gave me one book last week and promised to bring the others on Wednesday.

meanings.definition: different to what is usual or expected, and sometimes not well understood:
examples: I guess it doesn’t fit with the historically expected monogamous model, therefore it’s considered other.
There was a fear that under the costume there is something foreign, something terrifying and essentially other.

meanings.definition: to treat someone as though they are not part of a group and are different in some way:
examples: A lot of people can relate to being othered or seeing it happen to someone else.
The book is often criticized for romanticizing and othering black Americans.

meanings.definition: the second of two things or people, or the item or person that is left from a group or set of things:
examples: Hold the racket in one hand and the ball in the other.
Some people like living in big cities, but others prefer the suburbs.

meanings.definition: more of the same kind as the item or person already mentioned:
examples: In addition to the microwave oven, the kitchen has several other modern appliances.
There is one other point I would like to discuss with you.
Are there any other people you want to invite?

meanings.definition: Other can be used at the end of a list to show that there are more items without being exact about what they are:
examples: milk, cheese, and other dairy products

meanings.definition: different from the item or person already mentioned:
examples: I’m going to have to take the car – there’s no other way to get there.
Ask me some other time, when I’m not so busy.

meanings.definition: The other end/side means the opposite end or side:
examples: Put this chair at the other end of the table.
Jeanne was waiting on the other side of the street.

meanings.definition: used to describe amounts of money, usually small amounts, that are added together and not listed under a separate name in financial records:
examples: These expenses are included under the headings 'utilities', 'taxes', and 'other'.

meanings.definition: a person's husband, wife, or usual partner:
examples: Bring your other half next time you come.

meanings.definition: except:
examples: The form cannot be signed by anyone other than you.

meanings.definition: a woman who is having a sexual relationship with someone who is married or in a serious relationship with someone else:
examples: She didn't want to just be the other woman, and believed he would leave his wife.

meanings.definition: the act of treating someone as though they are not part of a group and are different in some way:
examples: A large volume of literature has been written on stereotyping and othering.
So much of our criminal-justice policy is driven by othering — magnifying the differences between those people and us, their children and our children.

meanings.definition: to make a person or group of people seem different, or to consider them to be different :
examples: We should not otherize people of different backgrounds.

meanings.definition: being or feeling different in appearance or character from what is familiar, expected, or generally accepted:
examples: In the film, he is able to depict the sense of otherness and alienation that many teenagers feel.

meanings.definition: Others also refers to people in general, not the person you are talking to or about:
examples: You shouldn’t expect others to do your work for you.

meanings.definition: used after an order or suggestion to show what the result will be if you do not follow that order or suggestion:
examples: I'd better write it down, otherwise I'll forget it.
Call home, otherwise your parents will start to worry.

meanings.definition: differently, or in another way:
examples: The police believe he is the thief, but all the evidence suggests otherwise (= that he is not).
Under the Bill of Rights, a person is presumed innocent until proved otherwise (= guilty).
Protestors were executed, jailed or otherwise persecuted.
Marion Morrison, otherwise known as the film star John Wayne, was born in 1907.
I can't meet you on Tuesday - I'm otherwise engaged/occupied (= doing something else).

meanings.definition: except for what has just been referred to:
examples: The bike needs a new wheel, but otherwise it's in good condition.
The poor sound quality ruined an otherwise beautiful film.

meanings.definition: used to show that something is completely different from what you think it is or from what was previously stated:
examples: He might have told you he was a qualified electrician, but the truth is quite otherwise.

meanings.definition: differently, or in another way:
examples: Samuel Clemens, otherwise known as Mark Twain
Parts of the company will be sold or otherwise dismantled.

meanings.definition: Otherwise also means except for what was just referred to:
examples: I like working outside when it’s warm, but otherwise I stay indoors.

meanings.definition: if not; or else:
examples: Tell me if you want it, otherwise I’ll give it to Freya.

meanings.definition: more closely connected to spiritual things than to the ordinary things of life:
examples: The children in the picture look delicate and otherworldly, as though they had never run or played.

meanings.definition: used to describe a word or phrase, or sometimes an idea, that is unnecessary or has been used several times:
examples: The use of the word "recumbent" is otiose after the word "recline".

meanings.definition: a condition in which the inside of the ear becomes swollen and painful:
examples: It is important to have your pet seen for otitis as it can result in a burst eardrum and deafness if not treated.
Malignant otitis requires the use of systemic antibiotics for nearly two months.

meanings.definition: a condition in which the passage of the outer ear (= the part of the ear that can be seen on the side of the head) becomes swollen and painful:
examples: Otitis externa is common among swimmers and scuba divers.
Probably the most common of the ear complaints in adults is otitis externa.

meanings.definition: a condition in which the inner ear (= the part inside the ear that controls balance and the ability to hear, and contains the cochlea) becomes swollen and painful:
examples: Otitis interna is an inflammation that is located in your inner ear.
What are the symptoms and causes of otitis interna?

meanings.definition: a condition in which the middle ear (= the central part of the ear, behind the eardrum, through which sound travels) becomes swollen and painful:
examples: Some children are prone to middle ear infections, or otitis media.
Otitis media is caused by the build-up of fluid and air in the eustachian tubes.

meanings.definition: relating to the ears:
examples: The doctor peered into the boy's ear with her otoscope.
Otoacoustic emissions are echoes that the normal ear produces in response to an incoming sound.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for
        
         one-time-only  :
examples: The discount will be given OTO.

meanings.definition: written abbreviation for on the other hand, used in emails, etc.
abbreviation for on the other hand: used in emails and text messages before you refer to a different way of looking at a situation
a doctor who specializes in diseases of the ear and throat
the study of diseases of the ear and throat
any of the very small pieces of bone-like material found in the inner ear of people and animals that help them recognize movement of their body:
examples: The vestibular hair cells are located in the otolith organs, where they detect linear movements of the head.
Otoliths grow as fish grow, and a ring or band is added to the bone every year.

meanings.definition: relating to otoliths (= very small pieces of bone-like material in the inner ear of people and animals that help them recognize movement):
examples: The brain processes messages from about 8,000 of these hair cells in each otolithic organ to determine which way a person is moving.
Even a slight movement of the otolithic membrane is enough to bend hair cells and send sensory information to the brain.

meanings.definition: a doctor who specializes in diseases of the ear:
examples: The otologist tested me in a soundproof booth.
A male patient presented to the otologist because of pain in the left ear.

meanings.definition: the study of the ear and of diseases of the ear:
examples: He is a professor of otology at Northwestern University.
84 infants underwent audiological evaluation at the Otology and Cochlear Implant Centre of the University hospital of Pisa.

meanings.definition: a doctor who studies or treats diseases of the ear, nose, and throat:
examples: She is a consultant otorhinolaryngologist.
People with severe allergies may seek treatment from an otorhinolaryngologist.

meanings.definition: the area of medicine that deals with diseases of the ear, nose, and throat

abbreviation for one-time password or one-time passcode: a secret word, series of numbers, or combination of letters and numbers, which is used for communicating with a computer to prove who you are and which can be used only once; the system that uses such words or numbers :
examples: The OTP is delivered through SMS to a phone number provided by the user.
An OTP system is one way of helping secure your information.
Some applications use OTP to validate sensitive transactions.
Make sure that you are only using OTP technology from a trusted source.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for 
        
         Office of Thrift Supervision  :
examples: The OTS supervises a national thrift industry that is built on the American dream of homeownership.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for opportunity to see: a measure of the number of chances that a customer who may be interested in a particular product will have to see an advertisement for it during a particular period:
examples: If we advertise for a week on TV we'd expect a minimum OTS of 2, whereas a press campaign should score at least 5.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for
        
         over the top UK informal
the capital city of Canada, in the southeastern part of the country:
examples: He is a musician from Ottawa.
That year, in Ottawa, more than 100 nations signed a major treaty banning landmines.

meanings.definition: a mammal with four legs and short brown fur that swims well and eats fish
a water mammal with four legs and dark brown fur, which eats fish and is related to the weasel
a piece of furniture like a long box with a soft top, that you can use to store things in or to sit on
a soft, round or square seat with no back or sides, used for sitting on or resting your feet on
the capital city of Burkina Faso, in the central part of the country:
examples: This is happening at a hotel popular with diplomats and westerners, including Americans in the capital of Ouagadougou.
Since 2007, it has endeavoured to help disadvantaged women in the 10th district of Burkina Faso's capital, Ouagadougou, on land granted by the city council.

meanings.definition: used to express sudden physical pain:
examples: Ouch, you're hurting me!

meanings.definition: used in answer to something unkind that someone says:
examples: "I really think you're much too fat, Dorothy." "Ouch, that was mean."

meanings.definition: used to express sudden pain:
examples: Ouch, you’re hurting me!

meanings.definition: a musical instrument that has a pear-shaped body with a round back, a short neck, and strings that are played with the fingers, traditionally used in, for example, North African and Middle Eastern music
used to say that it is necessary or desirable to perform the action expressed in the verb:
examples: We ought to clean up before we go home.
She really ought to apologize.

meanings.definition: used to say that the action expressed in the verb is probable or expected:
examples: He ought to be home by seven o’clock.
The curtains ought to be ready on Monday.
At his age, he ought to have known better.

meanings.definition: used to show when it is necessary or would be a good thing to perform the activity referred to by the following verb:
examples: You ought to be kinder to him.
We ought not/oughtn't to have agreed without knowing what it would cost.
"We ought to be getting ready now." "Yes, I guess we ought (to)."

meanings.definition: used to express something that you expect will happen:
examples: He ought to be home by seven o'clock.
They ought to have arrived at lunchtime but the flight was delayed.
If you show the receipt, there ought not to be any difficulty getting your money back.

meanings.definition: short form of ought not:
examples: He oughtn't to do that.

meanings.definition: a brand name for a board, printed with letters of the alphabet and numbers, that people use in the belief that it will help them receive messages from people who are dead
a unit of weight equal to approximately 28 grams:
examples: There are 16 ounces in one pound.
a twelve-oz pack of bacon

meanings.definition: a very small amount:
examples: She can eat as much as she wants and she never puts on an ounce (= her weight does not increase).
If he has an ounce of common sense, he'll realize that this project is bound to fail.

meanings.definition: a unit of measurement of weight equal to 1/16 pound or 28 grams
An ounce is also a very small amount:
examples: If he’s got an ounce of common sense, he’ll realize that this project is bound to fail.

meanings.definition: a fluid ounce
a unit of weight equal to 28.35 grams:
examples: There are 16 ounces in one pound.
a 12-oz can of cola

meanings.definition: of or belonging to us:
examples: We bought our house several years ago.
He walked off and left us on our own.
Drugs are one of the greatest threats in our society.
There's no point in our buying a new car this year.

meanings.definition: belonging to or connected with us; the possessive form of we, used before a noun:
examples: These are our children.
Our plans have changed.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         the Lord's Prayer
(in some parts of the Christian religion) a name for Mary, the mother of Jesus
the one(s) belonging to or connected with the person who is speaking and one or more other people:
examples: Which table is ours?
He's a cousin of ours.
Ours is the red car parked over there.
Ours is a huge country.

meanings.definition: belonging to, or that which belongs to us:
examples: He’s a cousin of ours.
That’s their problem – not ours.
I think these seats are ours.

meanings.definition: used when the subject of the verb is "we" or the speaker and one or more others, and the object is the same group of people:
examples: We went to get ourselves something to eat.
John and I promised ourselves a good holiday this year.

meanings.definition: used to emphasize the subject "we":
examples: We ourselves realize that there are flaws in the plan.

meanings.definition: the person speaking and one or more others; the reflexive form of we:
examples: We promised ourselves a long vacation this year.
It’s a big garden, but we do the gardening by ourselves (= without help).
Everyone else is busy, so we’ll have to go all by ourselves (= without other people).
We had the swimming pool all to ourselves (= we did not have to share it).

meanings.definition: added to nouns to form adjectives that refer to a quality or condition:
examples: dangerous
ambitious

meanings.definition: to force someone to leave a position of power, job, place, or competition:
examples: The president was ousted (from power) in a military coup in January 1987.
Police are trying to oust drug dealers from the city .
Last year's NCAA winners have been ousted from the tournament.

meanings.definition: to force someone out of a job or position:
examples: The school board voted to oust the school superintendent.

meanings.definition: to force someone to leave a job, position of power, place, etc.:
examples: Shareholders successfully agitated to oust the company's chief executive last summer.
It is not the first time he has been ousted from a company.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         oust
to force someone to leave a position of power, job, place, or competition:
examples: The president was ousted (from power) in a military coup in January 1987.
Police are trying to oust drug dealers from the city .
Last year's NCAA winners have been ousted from the tournament.

meanings.definition: the process of removing someone from an important position or job:
examples: The committee's chairperson is facing a possible ouster.

meanings.definition: the act of removing someone from an important position or job:
examples: The board voted to call for the ouster of the company's president.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         oust
to force someone to leave a position of power, job, place, or competition:
examples: The president was ousted (from power) in a military coup in January 1987.
Police are trying to oust drug dealers from the city .
Last year's NCAA winners have been ousted from the tournament.

meanings.definition: used to show movement away from the inside of a place or container:
examples: She opened the window and stuck her head out.
The bag broke and the apples fell out.
I jumped out of bed and ran downstairs.
He leaned out the window.
He opened the drawer and took out a pair of socks.
Get out!
Out you go! (= Go out!)
My secretary will see you out (= go with you to the door).
Turn the trousers inside out (= put the inside on the outside).

meanings.definition: outside a building or room:
examples: If you wait out here, we will call you when the doctor is ready.
Danger! Keep out! (= Do not enter!)
It's bitterly cold out, today.

meanings.definition: absent for a short time from the place where you live or work:
examples: I came around to see you this morning, but you were out.
Someone called while you were out.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a period of time when someone goes away from home for a social activity:
examples: I can't go out tonight - I have work to do.
Do you want to eat out (= eat in a restaurant) tonight?
He asked me out (= asked me to go with him) to the cinema next week.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a time when someone is away from the main office in order to do a particular job:
examples: The thieves were spotted by a postman out on his rounds (= as he was delivering the post).
The police were out in force (= there were a lot of police) at the demonstration.

meanings.definition: In a library, if a book is out, it has been borrowed by someone:
examples: Both copies of "Wuthering Heights" were out.

meanings.definition: to the point where something is removed or disappears:
examples: The stain won't come out.
Cross out any words that are not on the list.
Never use water to put out fires in electrical equipment.
Our time/money/patience ran out.

meanings.definition: (in sport) no longer able to play because your turn is over:
examples: Two of the best players on the team were out after ten minutes.
New Zealand were all out for 246 (= the team finished with a score of 246).

meanings.definition: (in politics) no longer able to govern because you have lost an election:
examples: The Social Democrats were voted out after 15 years in power.

meanings.definition: to many people:
examples: The teacher gave out test books to all the students.
Greenpeace sent a letter out to all its supporters.

meanings.definition: spreading out from a central point over a wider area:
examples: The police search party spread out across the fields.

meanings.definition: When a book, magazine, film, or musical recording is out, it is available to the public:
examples: Is her new book out yet?
The new movie comes out in August.

meanings.definition: able to be seen:
examples: The stars are out tonight.
The rain stopped and the sun came out (= appeared).
In spring all the flowers came out (= their petals opened).

meanings.definition: used to make the meaning of a word stronger:
examples: We walked all day and were tired out (= very tired) by the time we got home.
It's up to you to sort this out (= deal with it completely).

meanings.definition: used with verbs describing sounds to emphasize the loudness of the sound:
examples: He cried out in pain as he hit his head.
Charlie Chaplin films always make me laugh out loud.

meanings.definition: a long distance away from land, a town, or your own country:
examples: The fishing boats were out at sea for three days.
They live out in the country, miles from anywhere.
He lived out in Zambia for seven years.
The weather's better out west (= a long distance away in the west of the country).

meanings.definition: If a light or fire is out, it is no longer shining or burning:
examples: When we got home, all the lights were out.
Is that fire completely out?

meanings.definition: away from the coast or beach:
examples: Is the tide coming in or going out?
You can only see the beach when the tide is out.

meanings.definition: (of information) no longer kept secret:
examples: You can't hide your gambling any longer - the secret's out.

meanings.definition: used to describe a person who is not heterosexual (= sexually attracted to men if they are a woman and women if they are a man) or not cisgender (= having a gender that matches the body they were born with) and who does not keep that fact secret from other people:
examples: She came out three years ago.
He hasn't come out to his family yet.
Is she out at work?

meanings.definition: (of a ball in a sport such as tennis) landing outside one of the lines that mark the area where the game is played:
examples: He thought the ball had bounced on the line, but the umpire said it was out.

meanings.definition: unconscious or sleeping:
examples: He passes out (= loses consciousness) at the sight of blood.
I was hit on the head, and I must have been out cold (= completely unconscious) for about ten minutes.

meanings.definition: not accurate:
examples: Our estimates were only out by a few dollars.
You were an inch out in your measurements.
Those sales figures were way out (= completely wrong).
I'm out $25 on this trip (= it cost me $25 more than expected).

meanings.definition: (used with superlatives) available or in existence:
examples: This is the best automatic camera out.
I think he's the greatest football player out.

meanings.definition: used to show that a period of time is finished:
examples: I think I can finish this project before the month's out.

meanings.definition: not acceptable or not possible:
examples: Smoking is definitely out among my friends.
The option of taking on more staff is out for the moment.

meanings.definition: no longer fashionable or popular:
examples: Every month the magazine lists what's out and what's in (= fashionable).
Trousers like that went out (= stopped being fashionable) in the 70s.

meanings.definition: to make known the fact that someone is not heterosexual (= attracted to men if you are a woman and women if you are a man) or cisgender (= having a gender that matches the body you were born with), especially when that person does not want other people to know:
examples: Hardly a week went by without someone famous being outed.
Outing private individuals is offensive behaviour.
She was outed as transgender by a sleazy tabloid.

meanings.definition: an excuse or reason for avoiding an unpleasant situation:
examples: We must arrange the negotiations so we have an out if we need it.

meanings.definition: used to add the meaning "not central" to nouns and adjectives:
examples: the outskirts of town (= the areas that form the edge of the town)

meanings.definition: used to add the meaning "going further" or "being better than" to verbs:
examples: She doesn't drink or smoke and I'm sure she'll outlive (= live longer than) us all.

meanings.definition: used to add the meaning "out of" or "away from" to nouns and adjectives:
examples: She turned away from their outstretched hands (= hands held out).

meanings.definition: from within to a place or position that is not inside a building or not enclosed or contained:
examples: I’m going out for a walk.
He leaned out the window and waved.
Our office looks out on a public park.

meanings.definition: away or absent from your home or place of work:
examples: I’ll be out tomorrow.
Leo went out to lunch .
We often eat out (= at restaurants).
Bill asked me out (= to go somewhere enjoyable together).

meanings.definition: If something is out, it is not where it is usually kept or belongs:
examples: I checked at the library and that book is out.

meanings.definition: away from a place or starting point, or far away:
examples: They moved out to the country.
Have you sent out the invitations yet?

meanings.definition: in the area beyond a building or room, or outdoors (= not in a building):
examples: It’s cold out today.
They camped out.
Keep out (= Do not enter).

meanings.definition: to the point where something is removed or disappears:
examples: The stain on my tie won’t come out.
Cross out the second number.

meanings.definition: completely, or as much as possible:
examples: She stretched out on the bed.
We were tired out.

meanings.definition: aloud, so other people can hear:
examples: Her mother called out to us.

meanings.definition: (esp. of a book, movie, or recording) available to the public:
examples: Is his new novel out yet?

meanings.definition: made known to the public:
examples: The secret’s out about her retirement.

meanings.definition: able to be seen:
examples: It stopped raining and the sun came out.

meanings.definition: no longer operating or working:
examples: The electricity went out during the storm.

meanings.definition: If something that burns is out, it is no longer burning:
examples: Be sure the fire is out.

meanings.definition: unconscious, sleeping, or not aware:
examples: He passed out (= became unconscious).
Matt was so tired, he’s out cold (= in a deep sleep).

meanings.definition: (coming) into a condition in which something has been used and no more of it is left:
examples: Our money ran out.
His luck was running out.
Renew your membership before the month is out.

meanings.definition: not fashionable or popular:
examples: Long hair is out.

meanings.definition: not acceptable, not possible, or not allowed:
examples: Thursday is out so let’s meet Friday.

meanings.definition: intending to do or get something:
examples: He’s just out for a good time.
The mayor is out to get some publicity.

meanings.definition: failing or having failed to reach a base:
examples: He was out on a close play at second base.

meanings.definition: an excuse or reason for avoiding an unpleasant situation:
examples: The kids need to get home, so we have an out if we need it.

meanings.definition: away from the main office, etc. in order to do a particular job:
examples: She is out on a service call, but will be back in about an hour.

meanings.definition: absent from the place where you work:
examples: He is out of the office right now.
I will be out for the rest of the morning.
He has been out sick all week.

meanings.definition: available for the public to buy:
examples: A new version of this phone has just come out.

meanings.definition: not working:
examples: The power has been out for two hours.

meanings.definition: not accurate:
examples: Our estimates were only out by a few dollars.
Those sales figures were way out.

meanings.definition: taking part in a strike (= refusing to work):
examples: The assembly workers have been out for a month.
Union members voted unanimously to go out on strike.

meanings.definition: active; doing the things you usually do:
examples: The doctor says she's making a good recovery, and she should be out and about in a few days' time.

meanings.definition: used with superlatives to mean by a great amount:
examples: She is out and away the best student I have ever taught.

meanings.definition: doing something, or intending to do something, for an unpleasant reason or only because it is good for you and not others:
examples: She doesn't usually help the charity - she's only out for the publicity.
He's always been out to cause trouble between us.
He doesn't care about the cause - he's just out to make money.
They're only out to advance their own financial interests.
These people are just out for what they can get.
Come on, she's only out for the bucks!

meanings.definition: In a theatre, if you say that someone is out front, you mean they are one of the people watching the performance:
examples: Don't worry about your parents being out front tonight.

meanings.definition: now known or able to be seen when it was hidden before:
examples: It's time this issue was brought out into the open.
The whole episode was shrouded in secrecy and I wanted to drag it out into the open.
Death had been a taboo subject and it's better to have it out in the open so we can talk freely about it.
Corruption in the industry was rife and they brought it out into the open.
He acted like all his family's secrets should just be out in the open.
Tensions were running high on the campaign trail and finally spilled out into the open after the candidate's thoughtless comments.

meanings.definition: If you say or read something out loud, you say or read it so that other people can hear you:
examples: I had to read the essay out loud in front of the whole school.

meanings.definition: without thinking carefully about which one to choose or what to do:
examples: I'm just pulling these ideas out of a hat.
He accused ministers of drawing numbers out of a hat after they said that they wanted to double the limit to around 56 days.
Every female employee had left, most picking lame excuses from a hat.

meanings.definition: without a job:
examples: How long have you been out of a job?
If everyone cleaned their own windows, I'd be out of a job.
Closing the mines put many local people out of a job.
She was stunned to find herself out of a job at the age of forty.
With those skills, you'll never be out of a job.

meanings.definition: If a machine or vehicle is out of action, it is not working or cannot be used: If a person is out of action, they are injured or ill and cannot do things they usually do:
examples: I'm afraid the TV's out of action.
Nearly 80,000 vehicles have been taken out of action by the explosion at the storage depot.
Jackson's torn ligaments will keep him out of action for the rest of the season.

meanings.definition: an arrangement in which two or more things are not positioned correctly in a straight line or parallel to each other:
examples: The problem is happening because the wheels are out of alignment.
As you get older, one or more vertebrae may get out of alignment.
The doctor had to reset his elbow: it had healed out of alignment after the accident.

meanings.definition: If two things or people are out of alignment, they are different from each other, or they disagree with each other:
examples: Many families live in communities where home prices are way out of alignment with incomes.
He realized that his approach was out of alignment with what voters wanted.
The CEO's offhand comment is out of alignment with the values and policies of our company.

out-of-an-abundance-of-caution.name: out of an abundance of caution

meanings.definition: in order to be extremely careful to avoid a particular risk, even if the risk is small:
examples: The airline said that out of an abundance of caution they would temporarily ground their entire fleet of planes.
These voluntary actions are being undertaken out of an abundance of caution.

meanings.definition: (in sports) not within the playing area:
examples: The ball was ruled out of bounds.
The ball went out-of-bounds.

meanings.definition: unable to breathe comfortably because of tiredness or excitement:
examples: He burst into the room, red-faced and out of breath.
I get out of breath if I do any kind of physical exercise.

meanings.definition: no longer operating as a company that produces, buys, or sells goods and services:
examples: This new tax will put a lot of small firms out of business.
A lot of hospitality venues went out of business during the pandemic.

meanings.definition: completely different or differently from the way someone usually behaves, or from the particular qualities that a person, place, etc. has:
examples: It would be very out of character of her to lie.
He hasn't been in touch for over three weeks, which is completely out of character.
Ordinary people can behave out of character when placed in extreme situations.

meanings.definition: not taking part in social or other activities:
examples: I hear she's out of circulation after her accident.
I've been out of circulation for a while and didn't see your email until today.

meanings.definition: (of money) not being used in the economy:
examples: The coin was taken out of circulation last year.
The bank said it had taken over 20,000 forged notes out of circulation across the country.

meanings.definition: not being passed from place to place or from person to person, or not available:
examples: I am very pleased that so many dangerous weapons have been taken out of circulation.
Many of the research materials he needed were out of circulation.

meanings.definition: If something, such as a machine or a military ship, is out of commission it is broken or not available to be used.
not working or no longer in use:
examples: My car is out of commission again.

meanings.definition: not healthy enough for hard physical exercise, as a result of not taking part in sport or other physical activities:
examples: When he started boxing, he was overweight and out of condition.
Her active job as a country vet meant she never had the chance to get out of condition.
The short run made me realize that I was more out of condition than I thought.
He was severely out of condition and lacked any recent match practice.
If you carry on like this, in a year you will be so out of condition that a comeback will be physically impossible.

meanings.definition: If you do something out of consideration for someone or something, you behave in a particular way because you are considering their feelings:
examples: A number of small changes were made to the film, out of consideration for international audiences.
She was furious, but hid her feelings out of consideration for the old man.

meanings.definition: If words are used out of context, only a small separate part of what was originally said or written is reported, with the result that their meaning is not clear or is not understood:
examples: The reporter took my remarks completely out of context.
He claimed to have been quoted out of context.
She stood by her husband and insisted that his remarks had been taken out of context.
Out of context, this paragraph makes absolutely no sense.
She said that the quotation attributed to her was accurate but out of context.

meanings.definition: because someone wants to know or learn about something:
examples: Just out of curiosity, I checked his social media pages.
They said they only picked up the bag out of curiosity and had no idea it contained cash.

meanings.definition: If someone is out of danger, they are no longer in a situation where they may be harmed or die:
examples: The doctors say he is now out of danger.
People naturally want to know that their loved ones are out of danger.

meanings.definition: If clothes, colours, styles, etc. are out of date, they are old and not fashionable:
examples: That radio looks so out of date.

meanings.definition: If information is out of date, it is old and not useful or correct:
examples: an out-of-date phone directory
The guidebook I had for Chicago was out of date.

meanings.definition: If food is out of date, it is old and not now safe to eat.
outdated:
examples: The information in the book is out of date.
out-of-date fashions

meanings.definition: laws, systems, processes, etc. that are out of date are no longer useful or correct because they are not based on recent changes or developments:
examples: Current regulations are out of date.
In some cases, information provided by U.S. authorities was proved to be 10 years out of date.
The technology being used in some employment agencies is hopelessly out of date.

meanings.definition: documents that are out of date are no longer legal because they do not contain recent details or information:
examples: Forty planes were grounded when the company forgot to put renewed insurance documents on board and they were not allowed to take off with out-of-date papers.
an out-of-date passport/license plate

meanings.definition: no longer considered to be modern or fashionable:
examples: out-of-date fashions/hairstyles
The ambience of the bar now feels about 30 years out of date.

meanings.definition: food, drink, or medicine that is out of date is no longer safe to eat, drink, or use because it has been kept for longer than it should have been:
examples: The local store is stocked with out-of-date tins of food and has inconvenient opening hours.

meanings.definition: outdoors:
examples: They waited out of doors in the cold for tickets.

meanings.definition: outdoor:
examples: They have some out-of-doors activities planned.

meanings.definition: investments, products, or services that are out of favour are no longer popular with investors or consumers:
examples: Shares in the out-of-favour telecommunications sector fell from 391p to 246p yesterday.
While the markets' attention remains firmly focused on the yen, the euro has fallen out of favor.
Airline stocks are currently out of favour with institutional investors because of the global economic slowdown.

meanings.definition: out of control: If you refuse something out of hand, you refuse it completely without thinking about or discussing it:
examples: Things got a little out of hand at the party and three windows were broken.
He went to see his doctor because he felt his drinking was getting out of hand.
Moving to London is certainly a possibility - I wouldn't dismiss it out of hand.

meanings.definition: in a position that is safe from harm or from which harm cannot be done:
examples: The children will be here soon - you'd better put that plate out of harm's way.

meanings.definition: If you drink in a bar out of hours, you drink alcohol at a time when it is not allowed by law: at a time when a business, doctor's surgery, etc. is closed:
examples: The police are trying to stop out-of-hours drinking.
If returning keys out of hours, put them in a place agreed with the rental firm.
Building out of hours was not an option as the hospital operates around the clock.
Where would you go for out of hours medical care?

meanings.definition: if an employee of a company works out of house, they work from home rather than in the offices of that company:
examples: Many of our project team-members are based out of house.

meanings.definition: if a company has work done out of house, it arranges for the work to be done by someone who is not a company employee, or by another company:
examples: The editing of our marketing communications is done out of house.

meanings.definition: not working or based at the offices of a company or organization:
examples: We provide both in- and out-of-house training.

meanings.definition: not conscious of where you are or what condition you are in as a result of taking alcohol or drugs: unhappy because you are not included in what is happening:
examples: She was lying on the sofa, totally out of it.
I didn't know anyone at the party, and I felt really out of it.

meanings.definition: not aware of what is happening:
examples: I'm sorry I forgot to call you back – I'm completely out of it today.

meanings.definition: If a joint in the body is out of joint, it has been put or forced out of its correct position by accident:
examples: I put my shoulder out of joint last weekend lifting heavy boxes.
The doctor told her that her hip was out of joint.
He fell awkwardly and his knee popped out of joint.
When she regained consciousness, her head hurt and her shoulder was out of joint.
My back had been put out of joint when I fell backwards off a stage.

meanings.definition: beyond what is considered acceptable behavior:
examples: You can disagree with her, but calling her dishonest was out of line.

meanings.definition: not having the success or good opportunities you wanted:
examples: The bike only comes in large sizes, so if you're a short person you're out of luck.

meanings.definition: machines that are out of order are broken or not working correctly:
examples: All elevators in the building are currently out of order.

meanings.definition: remarks or actions that are out of order are not acceptable under the rules:
examples: Proposals to amend the tax laws were ruled out of order by legal advisers.

meanings.definition: An object or person that is out of perspective does not have the correct size or position in comparison with other things in the picture, and therefore does not look real or natural:
examples: The painting had a naive, out-of-perspective style.
If you draw objects the wrong size, your painting will look out of perspective.
One error I see a lot in paintings is buildings that are out of perspective.
The drawing will never work if the different elements are out of perspective.
The skull is painted beautifully but the rest of the scene is out of perspective.

meanings.definition: used to show what something is made from:
examples: The dress was made out of velvet.

meanings.definition: used to show the reason why someone does something:
examples: I took the job out of necessity because we had no money left.
You might like to come and see what we're doing out of interest (= because I think you might be interested).

meanings.definition: from among an amount or number:
examples: Nine out of ten people said they liked the product.
No one got 20 out of 20 (= all the answers correct) in the test.

meanings.definition: used to describe where something came from or began:
examples: She dresses like a character out of a 19th-century novel.
I paid for the computer out of (= using some of) my savings.

meanings.definition: no longer involved in:
examples: I got out of the habit of riding my bike to work.

meanings.definition: from a place or position inside something to a place or position that is beyond it or not part of it:
examples: I jumped out of bed and ran downstairs.
My daughter just got out of the hospital.

meanings.definition: If you are out of an activity, you are no longer involved in it:
examples: He decided to get out of teaching.

meanings.definition: not in the best or in a correct state, or not in a particular state or condition:
examples: The picture was out of focus.
James has been out of work for over a month.
This dress is out of style (= no longer fashionable).

meanings.definition: with the help of:
examples: I paid for the computer out of my savings.

meanings.definition: (of a material or substance) by using, to produce something:
examples: The dress was made out of velvet.

meanings.definition: in a condition in which you have no more of something, esp. because it has all been used:
examples: We’ll soon be out of gas.
I’m out of patience with her.
We’re out of time – we’ve got to leave right now.

meanings.definition: coming from:
examples: She copied the pattern out of a magazine.

meanings.definition: because of:
examples: She volunteered out of a sense of duty.

meanings.definition: from among a group or a particular number:
examples: The poll showed that six out of ten people approved of the job the president is doing.

meanings.definition: in the wrong place or looking wrong:
examples: The boy looked uncomfortable and out of place among the adults.
The guitar looked out of place in a small study crammed with books.
The gallery in this tiny town would not be out of place in Sydney or Melbourne.
His shorts and T-shirt looked out of place in the office.
I always felt out of place among my sporty peers.

meanings.definition: If a ball or puck is out of play, it is not in a position where it can be hit, kicked, or thrown:
examples: The ball had gone out of play.
In tennis, the ball is out of play if it goes outside the lines or bounces more than once.
The pass was ruled incomplete because the ball was out of play when the quarterback threw it.
The puck went over the boards and is out of play.
The ball hit the ground before he recovered it and so is out of play.

meanings.definition: not straight vertically:
examples: The external wall is out of plumb by half a metre.
We need to know how different components may move, so that the building doesn't go out of plumb.
The planks on the west wall are slightly out of plumb.
The doors and walls of the temple were built deliberately out of plumb.
The weight of the roof is moving the walls out of plumb.

meanings.definition: books that are out of print are no longer available to buy because new copies are no longer being produced:
examples: Most of her books went out of print years ago.

meanings.definition: If fruit and vegetables are out of season, they do not grow in the area during that time:
examples: In Europe, tomatoes are out of season in winter.
The research suggests that frozen vegetables often have more nutrients in them than imported fresh vegetables that are out of season.
When fruit and vegetables are out of season, we just don't include them in our dishes.
We have a small greenhouse so we can grow tender greens and strawberries out of season.
I try not to buy fruit that's out of season.

meanings.definition: during the period when fewer people want to travel or have a holiday
during the period when it is not legal to hunt animals
not physically healthy enough for difficult exercise because you have not been involved in physical activities:
examples: I'm so out of shape that I get out of breath climbing the stairs.

meanings.definition: extremely expensive and more than you are able to spend: excellent:
examples: The price of the house we like is out of sight.
The group's new record is out of sight!

out-of-sight-out-of-mind.name: out of sight, out of mind

meanings.definition: said to emphasize that when something or someone cannot be seen, it is easy to forget it, him, or her
not able to be seen, and so not thought about:
examples: Problems in remote places can be out of sight, out of mind for many people.

meanings.definition: in an unhappy mood:
examples: Peter overslept this morning and has been out of sorts all day.

meanings.definition: away; not present in a place:
examples: I am at present out of station and will reply on my return.

meanings.definition: When someone is out of step, they do not lift the same foot and put it down again at the same time as other people:
examples: I'm no good at dancing - I always get completely out of step.
He would not tolerate seeing his soldiers march out of step.
She was walking out of step with the rest of the marchers.
Listen to the beat of the music and make sure you don't march out of step.
They marched for miles, not one person out of step.

meanings.definition: used to say that opinions, ideas, or ways of living that are different from those of other people:
examples: The Republicans are out of step with the country, Williams said.
He thinks that everyone is out of step except him.
On the issue of free trade, he is out of step with most of his colleagues.
Their behaviour is out of step with the teachings of the church.
Some of their traditions were seen as being out of step with American culture.

meanings.definition: not having the same ideas or beliefs as other people, or not being aware of other people's beliefs:
examples: The governor's remarks show that she is seriously out of step with the voters.

meanings.definition: products that are out of stock are not available to buy in a store because they have all been sold:
examples: You will be notified by email if any part of your order is out of stock.

meanings.definition: if a store is out of stock of a particular product, it has sold all of that product:
examples: We will recommend alternative products in the event that we are out of stock of that particular item.

meanings.definition: If something happens out of the blue, it is completely unexpected:
examples: One day, out of the blue, she announced that she was leaving.

meanings.definition: unexpectedly:
examples: My old roommate called me out of the blue.

out-of-the-corner-of-eye.name: out of the corner of your eye

meanings.definition: without looking at something directly:
examples: I was watching TV when I saw something move out of the corner of my eye.

out-of-the-frying-pan-into-the-fire.name: out of the frying pan into the fire

meanings.definition: said when you move from a bad or difficult situation to one that is worse
from a bad or difficult situation to one that is even worse:
examples: Many kids who try to run away from unhappy homes discover that they've jumped out of the frying pan into the fire when they try to live on their own.

out-of-the-mouths-of-babes-and-sucklings.name: out of the mouths of babes (and sucklings)

meanings.definition: said when a child says something that surprises you because it seems very wise
unusual:
examples: For the police, the incident was nothing out of the ordinary.
I don't think I did anything out of the ordinary.
I'm looking for something a bit out of the ordinary to liven up the living room.
It's our job to always be alert, looking out for things that seem out of the ordinary.
If you do notice something out of the ordinary, call the police.
Anything even slightly out of the ordinary worries him.

meanings.definition: not important to or not involved in a situation: unnecessary in a particular situation:
examples: He used to be an important member of the team, but he's gradually drifted out of the picture.
The new systems cut humans out of the picture altogether.

meanings.definition: not possible or not allowed:
examples: The class ends at 2, and leaving before then is out of the question.

meanings.definition: having no chance of being successful in a competition or election:
examples: He wasn't able to raise enough money for his campaign and declared himself out of the running.

meanings.definition: not having a problem or difficulty any longer:
examples: It's too soon to say if either airline is out of the woods yet.

meanings.definition: from nothing:
examples: I can't come up with €10,000 out of thin air.
They built the cell phone industry out of thin air in the mid-1980s.

meanings.definition: from nowhere or from nothing:
examples: She seemed to appear out of thin air.

meanings.definition: extremely good:
examples: What a restaurant - the food was out of this world!

meanings.definition: extremely good:
examples: The food at that restaurant is out of this world.

meanings.definition: not informed or not having the same ideas as most people about something, so that you make mistakes:
examples: A few of the older teachers are completely out of touch with their students.

meanings.definition: singing or playing notes that are at the wrong pitch (= level) or that do not agree with others being sung or played:
examples: The piano is out of tune.
Who was out of tune towards the end of that song?
Someone sitting behind me was singing out of tune.
I didn't want to be the person in church who sings out of tune.
The concert was great, apart from the oboe soloist, who was out of tune.
I thought the violins were slightly out of tune.

meanings.definition: not following the agreed order:
examples: You are not allowed to play a card out of turn.
She cut in front of the others in line and went on the slide out of turn.
The software patch fixes a design flaw that allowed players to play out of turn.
If you order out of turn, then the waiter might not be able to remember who ordered what at our table.

meanings.definition: not operating correctly or looking right:
examples: You can use Carol's old bike - the gears are out of whack, but it still goes.
My computer's all out of whack.
My routine has been thrown out of whack by the changes.
The whole real estate market has gotten out of whack.
Ticket prices are completely out of whack - $1,000 per seat? Absolutely not.
Their priorities are seriously out of whack.

meanings.definition: without a paid job:
examples: I've been out of work for the past six months.
The plant closed in November 2010, leaving 400 people out of work.
an out-of-work management consultant

meanings.definition: not having the knowledge, experience, or skills to deal with a particular subject or situation: in water that is so deep that it goes over your head when you are standing:
examples: I was out of my depth in the advanced class, so I moved to the intermediate class.
I'm not a strong swimmer, so I prefer not to go out of my depth.

meanings.definition: doing something that you are not skilled enough to do, esp. compared to other people doing the same thing:
examples: She has been working very hard on the project, but I think she's a little out of her league.

meanings.definition: unable to behave or deal with things normally because something has made you very worried, unhappy, or angry: extremely stupid or mentally ill:
examples: She was out of her mind with grief.
I'd go out of my mind if I had to do her job all day!
You must be out of your mind paying £500 for one night in a hotel!

meanings.definition: crazy or behaving in a crazy way:
examples: You have to be out of your mind to go swimming when it's below freezing outside.

meanings.definition: extremely silly:
examples: He must be out of his mind to have spent that much money on an old car!

out-of-from-the-corner-of-eye.name: out of/from the corner of your eye

meanings.definition: If you see something out of/from the corner of your eye, you see it but not clearly because it happens to the side of you:
examples: I saw something move out of the corner of my eye.

meanings.definition: having an opinion that is different from most people's and is unpopular:
examples: She's going out on a limb in criticizing her own party leadership.

meanings.definition: a rude phrase meaning having been forced to leave a job or place, especially because you have done something wrong:
examples: He's doing well in the company now, but there was a time he was almost out on his arse.
If you weren't my brother-in-law, I'd throw you out on your arse.

meanings.definition: a rude phrase meaning having been forced to leave a job or place, especially because you have done something wrong:
examples: You have one month to improve, or you'll be out on your ass.
When she gets tired of him, she'll throw him right out on his ass.

meanings.definition: infmlslightly crazy or not thinking clearly:
examples: You must have thought I was completely out to lunch when I forgot about meeting you.

meanings.definition: a flat, open container on a desk for letters and other documents that have already been dealt with and are waiting to be sent to someone else or put away:
examples: The letter is in your out tray.

meanings.definition: a container where a person puts letters and other documents that need to be sent to other departments or organizations:
examples: As usual, the amount in his in tray was significantly more than in his out tray.

meanings.definition: said to someone when you want that person to tell you something that they do not want you to know:
examples: What did he do then? Come on, out with it!

meanings.definition: strange, unusual, or completely wrong:
examples: I wouldn't vote for him – his ideas are way out in left field.

meanings.definition: in a place that is far from where most people live:
examples: They spend their vacations, out in the middle of nowhere, in a cabin in the woods.

meanings.definition: to be a better actor than someone else; to give a better performance in a film, play, etc. than other people:
examples: It is embarrassing that the non-human performers in this film out-act the human stars.
Supporting actors need to be careful not to out-act the stars.

meanings.definition: complete or in every way; used to emphasize an unpleasant quality of a person or thing:
examples: That's an out-and-out lie!
The whole project was an out-and-out disaster.

meanings.definition: complete; in all ways:
examples: He’s an out-and-out fraud.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         out tray  :
examples: A full out-basket at the end of the day is very satisfying.

meanings.definition: to bluff someone (= deceive them by making them think that you are going to do something when you do not really intend to do it) better than they are able to bluff you:
examples: It was a very tight chess game which she won by out-bluffing her opponent.
The commander had ingeniously out-bluffed a militarily superior enemy.

meanings.definition: to dance better than someone else:
examples: The final was keenly contested, but they were outdanced by the other pair in the end.
Despite being 20 years older than the rest of the group, she outdanced them all.

meanings.definition: to be more impressive than someone or something else, often by looking more shiny or more expensive:
examples: The red carpet can turn into a competition for the stars to out-dazzle each other with expensive gems.
These latest finds outdazzle even the ancient Egyptian treasures discovered last century.

meanings.definition: to debate a subject (= discuss it formally) better than someone else:
examples: Although out-debated by the opposition leader, the Prime Minister still won the vote.
As a trained lawyer, she could outdebate anyone.

meanings.definition: to achieve better results in doing something that was promised than someone else:
examples: The investment company claimed that it could out-deliver all its competitors in terms of growth.
We have allowed overseas competitors to outdeliver and undercut us.

meanings.definition: to design something better than someone else:
examples: The Formula 1 team have out-designed all their rivals this season with their new suspension.
Cutting-edge tech companies are always striving to outdesign their competitors.

meanings.definition: to earn more money than someone else:
examples: She started in a very junior role at the company, but was soon out-earning others who had been recruited before her.
The gender pay gap, where men outearn women, still exists.

meanings.definition: to eat more food than someone else:
examples: Despite being super-thin, she would always out-eat her dad.
He always out-ate me at the all-you-can-eat buffet.

meanings.definition: to be more impressive than something or someone else, especially by shining more:
examples: She wore a spectacular dress to the function but was out-glittered by the princess.
Although this necklace outglitters the others, it's actually much less valuable.

meanings.definition: the process of people permanently leaving a place in order to live in another place:
examples: The out-migration of people aged 20-34 is a serious problem facing North Dakota.

meanings.definition: relating to the ability to have mental experiences separate from your body, especially the ability to look at yourself from the outside:
examples: She seemed to be having some kind of out-of-body moment.
Some users of the drug reported an out-of-body feeling and losing control over their body movements.

meanings.definition: an experience in which you feel as if you have left your own body and can see it from the outside, usually from above:
examples: He had an out-of-body experience while undergoing surgery.

meanings.definition: the impression that a customer gets of something they have bought when they first take it out of its packaging and start to use it :
examples: The company has a reputation for delivering the best out-of-box experience when it comes to cell phones.

meanings.definition: agreed without involving a trial in a law court:
examples: an out-of-court settlement
My lawyer wants to settle out of court.

meanings.definition: an out-of-court agreement or deal is made between people involved in a legal argument without a decision needing to made in a court of law:
examples: The case was never tried because Laker reached an out-of-court settlement with the other airlines.

meanings.definition: if two people or companies reach an agreement out of court, they find a solution to a legal argument without using a court of law:
examples: Banks often opt to settle out of court.

meanings.definition: advertising that people see or hear when they are outside their homes, for example, on buildings or public transport:
examples: Creatives for out-of-home advertising have to take into account that the viewer is moving most of the time.

meanings.definition: used about money that you have to spend yourself rather than having it paid for you, for example by your employer or insurance company:
examples: All out-of-pocket expenses will be reimbursed by the company.
Under the new scheme, there are no out-of-pocket costs for preventative medical care.

meanings.definition: out-of-pocket costs, expenses, etc. are ones you have to pay yourself, rather than being paid by the company or organization you are working for:
examples: Employees will be reimbursed for any out-of-pocket expenses.

meanings.definition: out-of-pocket medical costs are not included in the price of health insurance:
examples: Under the current program, employees pay up to $7,000 in out-of-pocket costs before full coverage kicks in.

meanings.definition: relating to things or people that happen, live, are produced, etc. outside a particular state:
examples: The university is seeking to admit more out-of-state students.
An out-of-state corporate trustee can make it easier to avoid state income tax.

meanings.definition: outside a particular state:
examples: The majority of bears were shot by hunters from out-of-state.
Some people buy wine out of state, and ship it home.

meanings.definition: an option (= right to buy or sell shares, etc.) which has no value because the shares, etc. can be only be bought for above their present price, or sold for less than their present price:
examples: The best time to buy an out-of-the-money option is when you expect market volatility to increase.

meanings.definition: far from places where many people live or usually go:
examples: He grew up in an out-of-the-way place in South Dakota.
We found this great little out-of-the-way restaurant.

meanings.definition: away from where people usually go:
examples: We had dinner at a little, out-of-the-way place.

meanings.definition: in a place outside the main part of a town:
examples: an out-of-town shopping centre

meanings.definition: coming from outside a town or from another town:
examples: an out-of-town visitor/businessman

meanings.definition: an out-of-town shopping area or store is outside a town or city, rather than in the centre:
examples: out-of-town shopping centres/retail parks/superstores

meanings.definition: to be more organized than someone else, especially in a political campaign:
examples: He has dominated this year by out-organizing his opponents.

meanings.definition: (of living things) to produce more young than another group or another type of animal, plant, etc.:
examples: Eventually, a cell may crop up that is capable of out-reproducing its fellows.

meanings.definition: to row (= move a boat through water by pushing against the water with oars) faster or better than someone else:
examples: They totally out-rowed us.

meanings.definition: unusual or extreme:
examples: He is a great agent because he isn't afraid to give the more out-there acts a try.
Some of their ideas are totally out there.

meanings.definition: in large quantities:
examples: We have tourists here out the wazoo.

meanings.definition: a period when a service, such as electricity, is not available:
examples: The radio news reported power outages affecting 50 homes.

meanings.definition: a period when a service, such as electricity, is not available:
examples: The radio news reported power outages affecting 50 homes.

meanings.definition: to get an advantage over someone when agreeing a bargain (= an agreement between two people or groups in which each promises to do something in exchange for something else):
examples: The President returned from the summit meeting claiming that he had successfully outbargained the other attendees.
Despite a reputation as a tough negotiator, she realised that she had been outbargained in this case.

meanings.definition: to offer to pay a higher price for something than someone else, especially at an auction (= public sale):
examples: The retail group outbid all three competitors for space in the shopping centre.

meanings.definition: to offer to pay a higher price for something than someone else, especially at an auction (= public sale):
examples: They made a full-price offer but were outbid by another buyer.
He was outbid on every property he was considering.
The retail group outbid all three competitors for space in the shopping centre.

meanings.definition: to make more unkind or complaining remarks than someone else can make:

examples: Last spring, horticultural stock (plants) outsold manufactured goods (tools, sheds, and chemicals) by 57% to 46%.
Analogue radios are now outsold by digital radios by 30 to 1.

meanings.definition: to sell more products than a competitor:
examples: Airbus was outsold by its arch-rival Boeing in 2006 for the first time in five years.

meanings.definition: to be much more skilful and successful than someone:
examples: Ben Palmer easily outshone his rivals in the 200 metre freestyle.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         outshine

past simple and past participle of 
        
         outshine

in a sports game, to throw, kick, or hit the ball or puck (= disc used in ice hockey instead of a ball) at the goal more often than your opponent, or to be more successful at throwing, kicking, or hitting the ball or puck into the goal:
examples: The United States dominated the contest and outshot their opponents 23–2.
They outshot the Devils 22–11 in the first two periods.

meanings.definition: not inside a building:
examples: It was a sunny day outside.
Since it's such a nice day, let's eat/sit/go outside.
an outside light/toilet

meanings.definition: coming from another place or organization:
examples: The company has called in outside experts.

meanings.definition: In baseball, if a ball that is thrown to a batter is outside, it is thrown towards the side of home plate that is furthest away from the batter:
examples: The pitch was high and outside.
I swung and missed at an outside fastball.

meanings.definition: the most that would be accepted or possible:
examples: The outside limit/figure would be $350.

meanings.definition: not in a particular building or room, but near it:
examples: She sat for two hours on the floor outside his room.

meanings.definition: not in a particular place:
examples: Nobody outside this room must ever know what we have discussed.

meanings.definition: not within or part of something:
examples: I'm afraid that would be outside my job description.

meanings.definition: the outer part or side of something:
examples: The outside of the house needs painting.
The house looks larger when looked at from the outside.
The company needs to get help from outside (= from people who work for other organizations).

meanings.definition: slight:
examples: There's still an outside chance/possibility that Scotland will make it into the World Cup.

meanings.definition: the outer part of something, or the area or side that faces out or can be seen:
examples: She stood in the snow on the outside, watching him.

meanings.definition: not within or part of something:
examples: I live just outside (of) Baltimore.
Cars, movies, and radio linked small towns to the outside world.

meanings.definition: slight, small, or unlikely:
examples: There’s an outside chance that Boston will make it to the playoffs.

meanings.definition: a broadcast made away from the television or radio station
a phone call or connection going outside the place where you are:
examples: There's a private telephone if I need to make any outside calls.
You had to dial 9 for an outside call.
We were instructed by the manager not to put any outside calls through to the players' rooms.
Do you still have to dial 9 to get an outside line?
I don't know what was wrong but I couldn't get an outside line.
The rooms had telephones but no outside lines.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         non-executive director  :
examples: Two of the nine outside directors were discovered to have lucrative financial arrangements with the firm.

meanings.definition: on a football team, one of two players who attack down the left and right hand sides of the pitch
the part of the road nearest the vehicles going in the opposite direction, used especially by faster vehicles:
examples: She cruised by at 160 kilometres per hour on the outside/in the outside lane.

meanings.definition: the part of the road nearest the edge, especially used by slower vehicles
the part of a race track that is furthest from the centre
except for:
examples: Outside of us three, no one knows anything about the problem, yet.
Outside of his former teammates, who even remembers him?
It's absolutely the best film score you'll ever hear, outside of Hans Zimmer's work.
Outside of David Jones, who is even interested in this stuff?
Outside of Cameron and possibly Jake, no one is as much of a perfectionist.
At the time, I had no one to talk to outside of you and Maria.

meanings.definition: any shareholder who owns fewer shares in a company than the majority shareholder (= the one who owns the most):
examples: The fund is the largest outside shareholder, with a 21% stake.

meanings.definition: a person who is not involved with a particular group of people or organization or who does not live in a particular place:
examples: Outsiders have a glamorized idea of what it is like to work in Hollywood.

meanings.definition: a person who is not liked or accepted as a member of a particular group, organization, or society and who feels different from those people who are accepted as members:
examples: As a child he was very much an outsider, never participating in the games other children played.

meanings.definition: a person or animal with only a slight chance of winning:
examples: A complete outsider won this year's award.
The race was won by a rank outsider.

meanings.definition: a person who is not involved with a particular group of people or an organization, or who does not live in a particular place:
examples: I moved here three years ago, but I still feel like an outsider.

meanings.definition: someone who is paid by a company or organization to do a particular job, but who is not a permanent employee:
examples: In 2009, the company hired an outsider with marketing experience in an effort to revive its business.

meanings.definition: someone who is not directly involved in a situation:
examples: To outsiders, it looked as if the company was doing well.

meanings.definition: (especially of clothing) much larger than usual:
examples: They specialize in outsize clothes.

meanings.definition: outsized clothing is larger than the usual size:
examples: outsized trousers/shoes

meanings.definition: outsized profits, payments, etc. are extremely large and are considered too large by many people:
examples: Companies can't just ramp up their production capacity and expect to earn outsized profits.
They gained praise from institutions in their acquisition funds after generating outsized returns by well-timed sales of companies they control.

meanings.definition:
to 
        
         outwit
to obtain an advantage over someone by using your intelligence and often by using a trick; to outwit:
examples: You think you can outsmart me?
