If a company outsources, it pays to have part of its work done by another company:
examples: Unions are fighting a plan by the university to outsource all non-academic services.
Some companies outsource to cheaper locations to cut costs.

meanings.definition: to get work done by making a contract with another company to do it, often in another country, rather than in your own company:
examples: The candidate talks about working-class issues, particularly about jobs being outsourced overseas.

meanings.definition: if a company outsources work, it employs another organization to do it rather than using its own employees :
examples: As part of a recent restructuring, Anglian Water decided to outsource some of its operations.
The decision to outsource had been made for financial reasons.
Today they unveiled plans to close two factories and outsource production to Eastern Europe.
The bank was attacked over plans to outsource 4,000 jobs to Asia.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         outsource
If a company outsources, it pays to have part of its work done by another company:
examples: Unions are fighting a plan by the university to outsource all non-academic services.
Some companies outsource to cheaper locations to cut costs.

meanings.definition: the process of paying to have part of a company's work done by another company:
examples: The management guaranteed that outsourcing wouldn't mean job losses.
large Indian outsourcing firms

meanings.definition: a situation in which a company employs another organization to do some of its work, rather than using its own employees to do it:
examples: E-commerce, globalization, and outsourcing are all changing the production and distribution of products and services.
Proposals to reduce the current workload are expected to include the outsourcing of some planning work to the private sector.

meanings.definition: to spend more money on something than someone else:
examples: Democratic candidates tend to outspend Republicans.
Rich businessmen tried to outspend each other at charity dinners.

meanings.definition: expressing strong opinions very directly without worrying if other people are offended:
examples: outspoken comments
Mr Masack is an outspoken critic of the present government.

meanings.definition: (of a person) expressing strong opinions very directly without worrying if other people will be upset by them:
examples: an outspoken critic of corruption

meanings.definition: in a way that expresses strong opinions very directly without worrying if other people are offended:
examples: He was outspokenly opposed to the war and could be seen protesting in the town square every Saturday.
She was outspokenly critical of the country's foreign policy.

meanings.definition: spread as far as possible:
examples: a bronze statue of an angel with outspread wings

meanings.definition: clearly very much better than what is usual:
examples: an outstanding performance/writer/novel/year
It's an area of outstanding natural beauty.

meanings.definition: not yet paid, solved, or done:
examples: $450 million in outstanding debts
There are still a couple of problems outstanding.

meanings.definition: very much better than usual; excellent:
examples: You’ve done an outstanding job.

meanings.definition: not yet done, solved, or paid:
examples: My credit cards usually have an outstanding balance.

meanings.definition: an outstanding debt has not yet been paid:
examples: Most of the proceeds from the house sale were used to pay the outstanding mortgage.
an outstanding debt/balance

meanings.definition: used to talk about the total number of shares held by a company's shareholders at a particular time:
examples: As of July 23, the chip maker had about 12.3 million shares outstanding.
outstanding shares/securities/stock

meanings.definition: an outstanding problem or subject has not been solved or discussed:
examples: We still have some outstanding issues to discuss.

meanings.definition: an invoice that has not yet been paid:
examples: You can make payment of any outstanding invoices online.

meanings.definition: the total number of shares held by a company's shareholders at a particular time, which may be less than authorized issue (= the number it is allowed to sell):
examples: If their holdings exceed 5% of the total outstanding issue they are required to file a Schedule 13D with the SEC.

meanings.definition: the total number of shares held by a company's shareholders at a particular time:
examples: The exchange offer for all outstanding shares has been extended and will now expire on March 10.

meanings.definition: in a way that is clearly very much better than what is usual:
examples: He was an outstandingly successful mayor from 1981 to 1984.
She performed well but not outstandingly.

meanings.definition: a settlement (= place where people settle to live) in an area where few people live:
examples: The outstations were linked to the main towns by a public transport network.
The priest's teachings are shared by other church leaders working in the remote parishes and outstations.

meanings.definition: a station (= a building or place used for a particular service or type of work) that is in a different place from the main offices of an organization such as the army, the police, or a business :
examples: This is an outstation of the government's electronic intelligence centre.
The new season is about to start for the museum's outstations, and visitors can see many new exhibits.

meanings.definition: in Australia, a small farm with animals that is part of, but away from, a larger farm:
examples: Until a proper hut could be built at the outstation, shepherds may have lived in simple dwellings made of bark.

meanings.definition: a cheque from a bank that is not local
If you outstay something, you stay longer than is allowed by or for it. :
examples: Immigration officers are cracking down on visitors who outstay their visas.
The appearance of the boss caused a rapid scattering of employees who had outstayed their coffee break.

meanings.definition: to continue longer than another person or competitor:
examples: The dictator outstayed dozens of other leaders.
The horse outjumped and outstayed his four rivals to win the race.

meanings.definition: to continue to stay in a place although other people want you to leave:
examples: They were busy so I left - I didn't want to outstay my welcome.
It's always hard to know at these sorts of parties when you've outstayed your welcome.
I noticed James yawning and sensed that we'd outstayed our welcome.
If party guests outstay their welcome, what's the most diplomatic way of getting them to leave?
Occupying forces who were initially invited to help put down the uprising had built bases and outstayed their welcome, and the regional government was eager to see them all gone.
After a week of loafing on the couch, he's definitely outstayed his welcome.

meanings.definition: to stay too long:
examples: I left after two days - I didn't want to outstay my welcome.
I was careful not to outstay my welcome.
I'll go - I've clearly outstayed my welcome.
I felt like the dinner guest who'd outstayed his welcome.
I suddenly noticed my host yawning and thought I'd perhaps outstayed my welcome.

meanings.definition: reaching out as far as possible:
examples: He ran up to her, his arms outstretched.
She put some pesos into the little girl's outstretched hand.

meanings.definition: stretched as far as possible or held out in front:
examples: outstretched arms

meanings.definition: to be or become greater in amount, degree, or success than something or someone:
examples: The demand for food in the war zone now far outstrips supply.

meanings.definition: to be or become greater than something or someone in amount, degree, or success:
examples: Car dealers worry that demand will outstrip their supply.

meanings.definition: to be more successful than expected:
examples: Group sales were up 6% to $5.8 billion, outstripping Wall Street expectations of $5.47 billion.

meanings.definition: to grow or develop more quickly than something else:
examples: Credit card complaints outstrip all other bank-related grievances.
Supplies of goods and services are outstripping demand.
Output in the sector has increased, but has been outstripped by service sector growth and so has fallen as a proportion of the total economy.

meanings.definition: to be more successful than other companies or countries:
examples: Ratings of the latest BBC news channel have outstripped all their commercial rivals.
A high proportion of manufacturing businesses in Western Europe have now been outstipped by foreign competition.

meanings.definition: in cricket, the movement of the ball when it is bowled (= thrown to the batter) quickly and curves in the air so that it moves away from the batter:
examples: Outswing is harder for batters to deal with than inswing.
When the conditions are suitable, he's a master of outswing and inswing.

meanings.definition: out of:
examples: We'd better get outta here, man!
I'm outta here (= I'm leaving).

meanings.definition: (spelled the way it is often spoken) out of:
examples: I gotta get outta here.

meanings.definition: a short part of a film or television programme or music recording that was removed and not included, usually because it contains mistakes:
examples: They showed a video of funny outtakes from various movies.

meanings.definition: used to talk about the result for sales, growth, etc. achieved in a particular period, rather than what was expected or planned:
examples: He was budgeting for zero net new business this year, while expressing his hope that the outturn would be better than this.
The outturn was well below City expectations of an 0.8% increase.

meanings.definition: a total amount of goods or services produced during a particular period of time:
examples: The whisky was released in 2004 with an outturn of just 2400 bottles.

meanings.definition: to defeat someone by winning a greater number of votes:
examples: The Democrats were outvoted, as usual.
I suggested that we go out for a pizza, but I was outvoted (= most people did not want to).

meanings.definition: if a company, country, or group of people is outvoted by another, they do not achieve what they want because the other company, country, or group of people votes for something in larger numbers than they do:
examples: The Bank of England Governor was outvoted by colleagues on the Monetary Policy Committee over the proposed rate cut.

meanings.definition: relating to how people, situations, or things seem to be, rather than how they are inside:
examples: The outward appearance of the building has not changed at all in 200 years.
If he is suffering, he certainly shows no outward sign of it.
To all outward appearances everything was fine, but under the surface the marriage was very shaky.

meanings.definition: away from the centre:
examples: outward investment (= investment in other companies/countries)
We have the chance to build an outward-looking Europe that lives up to its global responsibilities.

meanings.definition: going towards a particular place, rather than returning from it:
examples: The outward flight/journey took eight hours.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         outwards
relating to how people, situations, or things seem to be, rather than how they are inside:
examples: There were no outward signs that she was injured.

meanings.definition: away from a particular place or toward the outside:
examples: The door opens outward.

meanings.definition: relating to money that is invested or spent in foreign countries, rather than in your own country :
examples: Any such fall would drive the dollar even lower, triggering further outward capital flows.

meanings.definition: money that people and companies in a country invest in foreign countries
An outward-bound ship or passenger is going away from home:
examples: At the port she managed to get a passage on an outward-bound ship.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to how people, situations, or things seem to be, rather than how they are inside:
examples: Outwardly, he seemed happy enough.
The men led outwardly normal lives as fathers and husbands.

meanings.definition: the state of being concerned with how people, situations, or things look or seem to be, rather than how they are inside:
examples: She is less worried about the outwardness of her image than she was in the early part of her career.
The outwardness of the manager's frustration with his team is a new thing; up until now, the trouble within the team has been kept mostly private.

meanings.definition: the quality or state of going or pointing away from a particular place or towards the outside:
examples: Our perception of distance seems to be as intuitive as our perception of spatial outwardness.
Outer space is just a colourless, weightless sea of endless outwardness.

meanings.definition: going or pointing away from a particular place or towards the outside:
examples: The door opens outwards.
It's much healthier to direct your emotions outwards than to bottle them up inside you.

meanings.definition: to be greater or more important than something else:
examples: The benefits of this treatment far outweigh any risks.

meanings.definition: to be likely to be more important than or have an effect on something else:
examples: The benefits of increased immigration outweigh the costs.

meanings.definition: to have more influence or importance than something else:
examples: Annual weather variations still seem to be outweighing any global warming trends.
Small changes in the tax burden are likely to be outweighed by other factors.
Medical experts maintain that the benefits of the new drug outweigh any risks.

meanings.definition: to be larger in number or amount than something else:
examples: Public finances showed a record cash surplus last month as surging income tax receipts outweighed a fall in corporation tax revenues.

past simple and past participle of 
        
         outweigh

meanings.definition:

examples: The benefits of this treatment far outweigh any risks.

meanings.definition: to get an advantage over someone by acting more cleverly and often by using a trick:
examples: In the story, the cunning fox outwits the hunters.

meanings.definition: to obtain an advantage over someone by being more intelligent; to outsmart:
examples: It is impossible to negotiate if one side feels that the other side is trying to outwit them.

meanings.definition: outside:
examples: 22 percent of the students are from outwith Scotland.

meanings.definition: work that is done for a company by employees who work at home rather than in an office:
examples: We are a small, family-run unit relying heavily on outwork.

meanings.definition: to work harder than someone else:
examples: They did everything they could to outwork the competition.

meanings.definition: (especially of an idea or phrase) old-fashioned and used too often in the past, so no longer useful or important
a Greek alcoholic drink with an aniseed flavour:
examples: She ordered a couple of ouzos (= glasses of ouzo).

meanings.definition:
plural of
        
         ovum specialized
shaped like a circle that is flattened so that it is like an egg or an ellipse:
examples: an oval mirror
an oval face

meanings.definition: an oval object or shape:
examples: Her eyes were large ovals.
Voters use a pencil to fill in ovals on the ballot.

meanings.definition: an oval-shaped sports track or playing area, or the building in which it is contained:
examples: The teacher ran around the oval with us.
The skaters executed a graceful turn at the far end of the oval.

meanings.definition: shaped like a circle that is flattened with two long, straight sides and round ends, or shaped like an egg:
examples: an oval table

meanings.definition: an opening that connects the middle ear to the cochlea in the inner ear (= a twisted tube that is the main organ of hearing):
examples: Conductive hearing loss involves structures from the external ear to the oval window.
These three small bones transmit vibrations across the middle ear, from the tympanic membrane to the oval window.

meanings.definition: in a way that looks like an oval:
examples: The young leaves of the plant are small and ovally rounded.
The queen pulled aside the white sheet covering the ovally shaped painting.

meanings.definition: of or relating to the ovaries or an ovary:
examples: ovarian cancer
an ovarian cyst

meanings.definition: either of the pair of organs in a person's body that produce eggs, or the part of any female animal or plant that produces eggs or seeds
either of the pair of organs in a woman’s body that produce eggs, or the part of any female animal or plant that produces eggs or seeds
shaped like an egg:
examples: The leaves are ovate.

meanings.definition: an occasion when a crowd of people expresses great enjoyment and/or approval of something with loud and long clapping:
examples: She was given a standing ovation (= the crowd stood up while they clapped) at the end of her speech.

meanings.definition: loud clapping that expresses a crowd’s great enjoyment or approval of something:
examples: At the end of the program, the dancers received a thunderous ovation.

meanings.definition: the part of a cooker with a door, used to bake or roast food:
examples: a conventional/gas/fan-assisted oven
a microwave oven
a cool/medium/hot oven
Place the cake in the oven and bake for 25 minutes.
Calcutta in summer is like an oven (= extremely and uncomfortably hot).

meanings.definition: part of a stove that is box-shaped with a door, in which food is baked or heated, or a separate device with this shape and use:
examples: Roast the turkey in a 325° oven for four hours.
a toaster/microwave oven

meanings.definition: long, thin pieces of potato that are baked in the oven rather than fried:
examples: Oven chips are so easy to make - you just stick them on a tray and put them in the oven.
My kids always love to have fish fingers and oven chips for dinner.

meanings.definition: a thick covering for the hand, used for taking hot things out of an oven
a device above a cooker that consists of a cover with anextractor fan (= a piece of equipment for removing steam, smoke, or unpleasant smells) inside:
examples: These ovens require no outside venting or oven hoods.

meanings.definition: a thick covering for the hand, used for taking hot things out of an oven
sold already prepared for cooking:
examples: an oven-ready chicken

meanings.definition: able to be cooked in an oven:
examples: a packet of ovenable chips

meanings.definition: able to be used in an oven:
examples: Is this dish ovenproof?

meanings.definition: containers in which food can be cooked inside an oven
above or higher than something else, sometimes so that one thing covers the other; above:
examples: The sign over the door said "Exit".
She held the umbrella over both of us.
Helicopters dropped leaflets over the city.
I put my hands over my eyes/ears because I couldn't bear to watch/listen.
I couldn't hear what she was saying over the noise of the planes taking off (= the planes were louder than her voice).

meanings.definition: in a position that is covering something:
examples: Put a clean cloth over the cakes while they cool.
I put a shawl over my shoulders.

meanings.definition: across from one side to the other, especially by going up and then down:
examples: She jumped over the gate.
The road goes over the mountains, not through a tunnel.
She is always chatting with her neighbour over the garden fence.
From the top of the tower you could see for miles over the city.
Tanks travel over the most difficult ground.

meanings.definition: falling down from somewhere:
examples: The coin rolled over the edge of the table.
Harold jumped out of the car just before it went over the cliff.

meanings.definition: falling because of stepping on something:
examples: She tripped over a toy lying on the path.

meanings.definition: more than:
examples: Most of the carpets cost/are over $5,000.
Children over the age of twelve (= older than twelve) pay the full price.
I value quality of life over money.

meanings.definition: increasing to further than a particular limit or point:
examples: They are already $25 million over budget.

meanings.definition: on the other side of:
examples: There's a bar over the road we could go to.
The story continues over the page.

meanings.definition: (referring to a cause of interest, worry, discussion, etc.) connected with or about:
examples: There's no point in arguing over something so unimportant.
I need time to talk/think over your proposal (= to discuss/consider it carefully).
The legal battle was over who should have custody of the child.

meanings.definition: during something, or while doing something:
examples: I was in Seattle over the summer.
Shall we discuss it over lunch/over a drink?
They took/spent an hour over lunch (= their meal lasted an hour).
It's fascinating to watch how a baby changes and develops over time (= as time passes).

meanings.definition: in control of or teaching someone or something:
examples: A good teacher has an easy authority over a class.
She's a sales manager but she has a regional sales director over (= with a higher rank than) her.
The victory over the French at Waterloo was Wellington's greatest triumph.

meanings.definition: using:
examples: They spoke over the phone.
We heard the news over the radio.

meanings.definition: sometimes used when talking about a calculation in which one number is divided by another number:
examples: 40 over 7 is roughly 6.

meanings.definition: from a higher to a lower position; down:
examples: The lamp fell over and broke.
He was run over by a taxi.
He was knocked over by a taxi.
The little boy fell over and started to cry.

meanings.definition: across; from one side or place to another:
examples: She leaned over and kissed me.
A fighter plane flew over.
Why don't you come over (= come to my house) for dinner on Thursday?
A friend of mine from France is over visiting us this week (= a friend came from France and is staying with us).
Now we're going over to (= there will be a broadcast from) Wembley for commentary on the Cup Final.
Come over here - it's warmer.
Who's that man over there?

meanings.definition: used to describe the way an object moves or is moved so that a different part of it is facing up:
examples: She turned another page over.
The dog rolled over onto its back.
The children rolled over and over (= turned over many times) down the gentle slope.

meanings.definition: changing or exchanging position:
examples: Would you mind swapping those plates over?
She changed over to editing from marketing.
Why should we hand over the money to them?
I've done everything I can - now it's over to you (= it's your turn to take action).

meanings.definition: above or higher than something else, sometimes so that one thing covers the other:
examples: A fighter plane flew over.
A man came to paint over (= cover with paint) the cracks in the wall.

meanings.definition: more than a particular amount or level:
examples: People who are 65 years old and over can get half-price tickets.

meanings.definition: (especially of an event) finished:
examples: I'll be glad when the competition is over.
I used to have a thriving business and a happy marriage, but that's all over now.

meanings.definition: extra; not used:
examples: I have some euros left over from the last time I was in France.
When all the guests had gone, we realized there was lots of food over.

meanings.definition: again or repeatedly:
examples: You ruined it - now I'll have to do it over!

meanings.definition: said when you are talking to someone by radio, to mean that you have finished speaking and will wait for their answer:
examples: "This is flight 595X. Do you read me? Over."

meanings.definition: in cricket, a set of six bowls (= throws) from the same end of the field:
examples: Simons took three wickets in his opening spell of 10 overs.

meanings.definition: too much or more than usual:
examples: The children got over-excited (= too excited).

meanings.definition: more than:
examples: a club for the over-50s

meanings.definition: across:
examples: Of course, the overland route is much slower than going by air.

meanings.definition: above:
examples: She was knocked off her bicycle by an overhanging branch.

meanings.definition: in, to, on, or at a position above or higher than something else, sometimes so that one thing covers the other; above:
examples: The sign over the door said, "Private."
He put a sweater on over his shirt.
The horse jumped over the fence.
I couldn’t hear what she said over the sound of the music (= The music was louder than her voice).

meanings.definition: across from one side to the other, esp. by going up and then down:
examples: Once we get over the bridge we’ll stop for lunch.
She tripped over the rug.
The car went over the cliff (= across the edge of it).

meanings.definition: Over also means on the other side of:
examples: Their house is just over the river.

meanings.definition: more than:
examples: Most of these rugs cost over $1000.
Children over 12 (= older than 12) pay full price.

meanings.definition: If someone or something goes over a limit or point, it increases beyond it:
examples: Construction costs are already $25 million over budget.

meanings.definition: divided by
using a device such as a telephone:
examples: They spoke over the phone.
We transfer files over the Internet.

meanings.definition: during a period of time, or while doing something:
examples: She made a lot of changes over the past six months.
Can we discuss this over lunch?

meanings.definition: greater in authority, power, or position than:
examples: Parents want to have control over their children.

meanings.definition: about or connected with:
examples: There’s no point in arguing over this.

meanings.definition: (esp. of illness) no longer suffering from:
examples: Is he over the flu yet?
His wife died last year and he’s still not over it.

meanings.definition: from a higher to a lower position; down:
examples: The little boy fell over and started to cry.

meanings.definition: again or repeatedly:
examples: You’ve ruined it – now I’ll have to do it over.

meanings.definition: Over also describes the way an object moves or is moved so that a different part of it is facing up:
examples: The dog rolled over onto its back.

meanings.definition: (esp. of an event) finished, completed, or ended:
examples: I’ll be glad when the meeting is over.
The game was over by 5 o’clock.
I'm worried about the test, but at least it will be all over (= completely finished)in an hour.

meanings.definition: too much or more than usual:
examples: overpriced
overdressed
He’s always been an overachiever.

meanings.definition: more or greater than:
examples: Free delivery on orders over $25.
Over 80% of temporary workers are part-timers.
The cable company has viewers in over 5 million households.
Shares fell by just over 1 per cent to 1,327p.

meanings.definition: during a particular period of time:
examples: The loan can be paid back in instalments over 12 months.
Sales went up 300% over only six weeks.

meanings.definition: in addition to:
examples: They receive extra money over and above the usual welfare payments.
They do random searches and pat-downs over and above the routine security check-ins.
He was seeking compensation over and above the medical costs.
That figure represents spending that was over and above what the government had budgeted to spend.
These people use their names and reputations to earn significant amounts of money over and above their already considerable salaries.
Legal fees can be recovered over and above the damage awards.

meanings.definition: completely finished:
examples: She gets unpleasant tasks over and done with as quickly as possible.
I knew I had to talk to Jack about the situation so I thought I might as well get it over and done with.
Well, that's Christmas over and done with for another year.
We just want the whole thing over and done with so we can get on with our lives.
As far as I'm concerned, the matter is over and done with and I've nothing more to say.
I just want to get the surgery done and over with, to be honest.

meanings.definition: said when you are talking to someone by radio in order to end the conversation, or when you humorously want to say that something is finished:
examples: "Thank you, control tower. Over and out."
"You have clearance to land." "Roger that. Over and out. See you on the ground."
"It was so good catching up with you! Have to run, over and out."
They left immediately after the party was done - no lingering or chatting, just goodbye, over and out.

meanings.definition: repeating many times:
examples: We have to explain the same thing over and over before he understands.

meanings.definition: happening or done many times:
examples: I read the article over and over till it made sense.

meanings.definition: If an egg is fried over easy, it is fried on both sides in such a way that the yolk (= the yellow part) stays slightly liquid:
examples: I'll have two eggs over easy.
Most restaurants will serve eggs over easy or sunny-side up if customers want them.

meanings.definition: Over easy eggs have been fried on both sides in such a way that the yolk (= the yellow part) stays slightly liquid:
examples: I've never really liked over easy eggs.

meanings.definition: If you say something will happen over your dead body, you mean that you will do everything you can to prevent it:
examples: "Joe says he's going to buy a motorbike." "Over my dead body!"

meanings.definition: If a drug, gun, etc. is available over the counter, you can buy it in a shop without having to visit a doctor or person in authority first:
examples: You can buy most cold remedies over the counter.

meanings.definition: An over-the-counter drug is bought from a shop without the person who buys it having visited a doctor first:
examples: an over-the-counter medicine

meanings.definition: used to describe shares that are traded directly between dealers (= people and organizations that buy and sell for others), rather than on a stock market:
examples: Brokers can use the system to look up prices or enter quotes for over-the-counter securities.

meanings.definition: (of drugs) legally sold without a prescription (= special written instruction from a doctor):
examples: The painkiller is available as an over-the-counter drug.

meanings.definition: used to describe shares that are bought and sold directly using a computer system, rather than on a stock market:
examples: Brokers can use the system to look up prices or enter quotes for over-the-counter securities.
Over-the-counter trading of Malaysian issues continued to be active.

meanings.definition: available to buy from a store without a prescription (= written instruction from a doctor):
examples: Strong sales of prescription and over-the-counter drugs helped boost the company's profits.

meanings.definition: after a period of time:
examples: I assume they plan to have children in the course of time.
Over the course of time, and once her parents' estate was settled, she received a small inheritance.
Shakespeare's plays were first printed in 1616, and, in the course of time, more editions were published.
We hope that over the course of time these two branches of the legal profession may be merged.
It is possible that over the course of time scientific research may be able to shed more light on the origins of the universe.

meanings.definition: gradually:
examples: Over the course of time, I've learned to live with my disability.
It seems that, over the course of time, his ideas about acting changed.
The book describes how early communities increased and concentrated their populations over the course of time.
Everyone changes over the course of time.
We hoped that the problems in their relationship would resolve over the course of time.

meanings.definition: used for describing someone who is old and no longer useful or attractive
no longer able to do something well because of age:
examples: I don’t think of myself as being over the hill yet.

meanings.definition: more than something is really worth:
examples: It's a nice enough car but I'm sure she paid over the odds for it.

meanings.definition: too extreme and not suitable, or demanding too much attention or effort, especially in an uncontrolled way:
examples: I thought the decorations were way (= very) over the top.
The speech was a bit OTT.
He realized he'd gone over the top with the seating arrangements.

meanings.definition: too difficult or strange for you to understand:
examples: I tried to take in what he was saying about nuclear fusion, but most of it went over my head.

meanings.definition: too difficult for someone to understand:
examples: Most of that lecture was over my head.

meanings.definition: in a share offering (= time when shares are offered for sale), extra shares that are available if all the main shares are sold:
examples: AT&T made an offering of 4.2 million common shares with an overallotment option of 630,000 shares.

meanings.definition: in basketball, a violation (= act of breaking the rules) that occurs when a player moving forward with the ball crosses the line in the middle of the court (= playing area) and then goes back behind it :
examples: The referee called Phillips for an over-and-back violation, and the Hornets lost possession.
An over and back violation caused the Tigers to commit a key turnover in the second half.

meanings.definition: to say that something is true too confidently or to make something seem greater, more important, etc. than it is:
examples: The author might possibly be over-asserting his case slightly.
Professionals have to remember not to overassert their own expertise.

meanings.definition: to borrow more money than you can pay back or pay the interest on:
examples: We did not overborrow but stuck to our limits.

meanings.definition: having borrowed too much money:
examples: People who are over-borrowed will run into trouble when interest rates rise.
Lending money to already overborrowed governments does not solve their problems.

meanings.definition: having borrowed more money than you can pay back or pay the interest on:
examples: Doubts remain about heavy lending to property developers and over-borrowed companies.
Americans are overborrowed.

meanings.definition: too full of light:
examples: In some places, residents are disturbed by over-bright street lighting.

meanings.definition: too strong in colour:
examples: The more vivid colours are so over-bright as to seem cartoonish.

meanings.definition: too happy or full of hope:
examples: An over-bright voice came over the public address system.

meanings.definition: the fact of needing something or someone more than is necessary or helpful, especially in order to continue existing or operating:
examples: She has few mental or emotional resources against stress, and an over-dependence on others.
There is no easy way to fix overdependence on unsustainable forms of energy.
The therapist must be careful not to encourage over-dependency.

meanings.definition: needing something too much in order to continue existing or operating, or needing too much support from someone:
examples: We're overdependent on oil as an energy source.
She would rather struggle on alone than be seen as over-dependent.

meanings.definition: to make too many changes to a text, film, etc. when deciding what will be removed and what will be kept in, in order to prepare it for being printed or shown:
examples: Don't over-edit the video - just remove the real mistakes.
Editors should not overedit.

meanings.definition: to make something seem larger, more important, better, or worse than it really is:
examples: Yes, there is a risk that the deal won't complete, but the market is over-egging it.
Many celebrities' memoirs overegg their difficult childhoods in order to flatter their later achievements.

meanings.definition: to make something seem larger, more important, better, or worse than it really is: to spoil something by trying too hard to improve it:
examples: We all know insurance claimants who have over-egged the pudding to increase their payouts.
It would be overegging the pudding to describe the system as universally popular.
There are some great moments, but the writer tends to over-egg the pudding with metaphors and similes when all she's describing is a group of women getting through the day.

meanings.definition: containing too much careful detail or too many detailed parts:
examples: The book is spoiled by over-elaborate writing.
He refused most of the overelaborate meal, saying that he never ate much at lunchtime.

meanings.definition: to add too much information about something you have said, or to explain it too much:
examples: I don't question what they say as long as they don't over-elaborate the story.
She does overelaborate from time to time and try to be too clever.

meanings.definition: the addition of too much information, too much careful detail, or too many detailed parts:
examples: In my opinion, his new song suffers from over-elaboration.
She manages to avoid any literary overelaboration.

meanings.definition: having feelings that are too strong, or expressing feelings in too strong a way:
examples: I didn't tell her because she always reacts in an over-emotional way.
I remember a meeting the evening before when we got a bit overemotional.

meanings.definition: done or said in a way that is too strong, or giving something too much importance or attention:
examples: Her mother gave an overemphatic nod.
His over-emphatic rantings soon begin to grate on you.

meanings.definition:
US spelling of 
        
         over-enamoured
to like something or someone too much:
examples: He is over-enamoured of making huge amounts of money and throwing extravagant parties in country houses.
He is one of those leaders who become over-enamoured of being in the limelight on a global level.

meanings.definition: having or involving too much energy:
examples: With excessive quantities of thyroid hormones, the patient may become over-energetic.
She had a hard time keeping up with the children, who were over-energetic and excitable.

meanings.definition: to create, design, or build something to be more complicated or perform more actions than is necessary or helpful:
examples: Her strategy is to over-engineer systems so that they will operate well even if conditions are more challenging than expected.
Technicians often overengineer a product, introducing numerous features that customers do not need.

meanings.definition: too enthusiastic:
examples: Her haircut looked as if her mother had been over-enthusiastic with the kitchen scissors.
One overenthusiastic gamer broke his controller when he threw it up in the air in excitement.
an over-enthusiastic children's television presenter

meanings.definition: to exercise yourself or an animal too much:
examples: Pregnant women should be careful not to over-exercise in the final weeks before giving birth.
Don't leave your dog in a locked car in hot weather, and never overexercise your dog.

meanings.definition: too great an increase in the size, number, or importance of something:
examples: He blamed this on an over-expansion of government power at the expense of local authorities.
There is a risk of overexpansion at the ends of the stent.

meanings.definition: the problem of expecting more good things to happen in the future than are likely to happen:
examples: Before the match, the team manager had warned them against over-expectation.
This unhappiness results from overexpectation, from the belief that we can be positive, happy, and motivated all the time.

meanings.definition: to explain something more than is necessary or helpful:
examples: Many writers and artists tend not to want to overexplain their works.
If you want them to believe you, it is important not to appear too defensive or to overexplain.

meanings.definition: to use too much of something, especially a natural resource (= minerals, forests, coal, etc.):
examples: The people of the wetland area had a sophisticated understanding of the need not to over-exploit its resources.
If we continue to overexploit bluefin tuna, stocks will soon be gone.

meanings.definition: the act of using too much of something, especially a natural resource (= minerals, forests, coal, etc. that exist in a place and can be used by people):
examples: Man's over-exploitation of the earth's resources has led to more and more people starving to death.
Cod stocks have plummeted through overexploitation by fisheries.

meanings.definition: the problem of removing too much of something such as a natural resource, especially by force:
examples: The over-extraction of the waters that once flooded the marshes has damaged this environment irrevocably.
They are campaigning about the problems caused by over-extraction of oil and gas resources.

meanings.definition: spending far too much money, or using far too much of something:
examples: Two million pounds for an electric guitar the singer used once seems a bit over-extravagant.
There have been complaints about the couple's overextravagant use of private planes.

meanings.definition: too extreme and unreasonable:
examples: The coach advised restraint, and warned that over-extravagant play would cause them to lose the match.
Over-extravagant claims by the unions have led to disappointment on the part of the workers.

meanings.definition: (especially of people and their behaviour) too energetic and enthusiastic:
examples: One over-exuberant audience member tried to sing along, but was swiftly silenced by a woman sitting behind.

meanings.definition: too simple, and not thought through enough:
examples: He spends his free time painting landscapes and writing overfacile poetry.
As a director, she refuses to provide audiences with scenes that give over-facile and immediate pleasure.

meanings.definition: having been seen, met, heard, etc. too many times before :
examples: The DJ played a dull, over-familiar selection of dance songs.
They have become overfamiliar with each other, and each feels their partner has nothing new to offer them.

meanings.definition: too informal and friendly, sometimes in a way that does not show respect to someone who is not a family member or close friend:
examples: A good manager should know how to be friendly without being over-familiar.
He often put his arm around Sophie, but was never overfamiliar with the others.

meanings.definition: too much knowledge of something, or the fact that you know it too well:
examples: It would be easy, through over-familiarity with the facts of climate change, to fail to appreciate the true implications for our future.
The lesson topic was not uninspiring. The problem was simply laziness and over-familiarity on the part of the teacher.

meanings.definition: behaviour that is too friendly and informal:
examples: The word "mate" has an uncomfortable over-familiarity to it when used between men who have never met before.
Her tone was firm and she spoke with warmth, but no overfamiliarity.

meanings.definition: giving too much attention to small details and wanting everything to be more correct than is necessary or helpful:
examples: He is critical of others, over-fastidious, and likes to be in charge of everything.
Her pronunciation is careful and exact, and sometimes sounds overfastidious.

meanings.definition: having too much body fat, in a way that may be unhealthy:
examples: People who work out in the gym and build muscle mass can sometimes be overweight without being over-fat.
Fast food and junk food have played a large part in the overfat society that we live in.

meanings.definition: to prefer or support one particular possibility, thing, or person too much:
examples: The advice he gave was not to over-favour local and national investments.
A clause like this may overfavour the buyer.

meanings.definition: the use of too much fertilizer (= a substance spread on land or plants to make the plants grow well), or the result of this:
examples: Over-fertilisation has led to some robust and dominant weeds.
Farmers are often unaware of the consequences of overfertilization.

meanings.definition: to use too much fertilizer (= a substance spread on land or plants to make the plants grow well):
examples: Be careful not to overwater or overfertilize.
We need to address the issue of people who over-fertilise their lawns, which can impact negatively on water safety.

meanings.definition: liking someone or something too much or liking doing something too much:
examples: People said that he was overfond of whisky.
She persuaded her overfond young boyfriend to spend hundreds of pounds on the ring.
Young people are over-fond of taking pictures of themselves and one another.

meanings.definition: not easily satisfied, or having standards about particular things that are higher than is helpful or necessary:
examples: They are not overfussy about using authentic Italian ingredients.
It seems unjust that the decisions of over-fussy officials can impact so negatively on our lives.

meanings.definition: having too much decoration, too many parts, or too many small details:
examples: The over-fussy outfit was covered in colourful bows.
The handful of overfussy arrangements on this album ruin what is otherwise an accomplished first release.

meanings.definition: An overfussy baby is more than usually unhappy or difficult to please:
examples: Parents of over-fussy babies will be surprised to discover that their over-attentiveness is making the situation worse.
As a baby, she was overfussy and could never settle without an adult to sing her to sleep.

meanings.definition: more generous than is necessary or helpful:
examples: Publicly funded companies should not be seen to be overgenerous to staff.
She always made sure we were well-fed and well-dressed, but she wasn't overgenerous with money.
an overgenerous salary/allowance/bonus

meanings.definition: in a way that is more generous than is necessary or helpful:
examples: I tipped the porter, perhaps over-generously, to judge from his reaction.
The cake was stuck in the tin, because the syrup had been used overgenerously.

meanings.definition: to make something seem far better than it is and therefore much more attractive:
examples: The film over-glamorizes the life of a man who actually committed some horrendous crimes.
It is easy to over-glamorise what the island has to offer.

meanings.definition: to pick something up and touch, hold, or move it with your hands more than is necessary or helpful:
examples: Wash your hands in cold water and don't overhandle the dough.
Add sea salt and freshly-ground black pepper, then mix, taking care not to over-handle.

meanings.definition: done or decided in a hurry, sometimes without necessary care or thought:
examples: You shouldn't panic into making an over-hasty decision.
We will listen to what they have to say before we reach any overhasty conclusions.

meanings.definition: a very strong feeling that you are similar to someone and that you can understand that person or their situation because of this, in a way that may be harmful or unhealthy:
examples: In some cases, problems may result from an over-identification with their parents.
As a biographer myself, I know something about overidentification with your subject.

meanings.definition: the act of recognizing someone or something as having a particular problem or characteristic when they do not:
examples: The over-identification of students of colour with special needs is a knee-jerk response to a more complex problem.
The overidentification of children for special education is an issue we must address for the good of our education system as a whole.

meanings.definition: to recognize someone or something as having a particular problem or characteristic that they do not have:
examples: They are wary of over-identifying schools that shouldn't be identified as needing help.
Depression in young people is difficult to identify and at the same time it's overidentified.

meanings.definition: to feel too strongly that you are similar to someone, or that something is important, in a way that may be harmful or unhealthy:
examples: Sometimes parents can over-identify with their child's sports career.
When I started out, I was very young, and I found that I was overidentifying with my students.

meanings.definition: often imagining things that are not real or not likely to happen:
examples: It's hard to believe this is anything other than the product of the mind of an overimaginative screenwriter.
Perhaps I am being over-imaginative in my understanding of what they are planning.

meanings.definition: to cause someone to feel much more admiration or respect than is usual or normal:
examples: He was not in the least over-impressed by her public position and was a lot of fun to be with.
He is trying his hardest and I think maybe he is trying sometimes to overimpress.

meanings.definition: the problem of owing more money than you can pay back:
examples: It is difficult for a country to exit from a situation of over-indebtedness.
People often take the wrong advice when they are under the intense strain that overindebtedness brings.

meanings.definition: having too many industries or depending too much on industry, in a way that is harmful to the economy, health, or the environment:
examples: City homeowners are complaining that the area is becoming over-industrialized.
The over-industrialised production of unhealthy foods is putting the entire planet at risk.

meanings.definition: given or having too much knowledge or information about something:
examples: It's better to look at the exhibits than bury your nose in a guidebook or be over-informed by the audio guide.
She described the members as intolerant, overinformed, middle-class cranks.

meanings.definition: saying or doing something too often, too firmly, or too loudly:
examples: He once told me off for being rude to an overinsistent beggar on the Tube.
The atmosphere was ruined by the over-insistent music.

meanings.definition: too extreme, forceful, or strong:
examples: We all need to relax a little, and look outside and beyond our over-intense preoccupations with ourselves.
She had recently ended a somewhat overintense relationship with an older man.

meanings.definition: to invest too much money in a particular activity or economy:
examples: Asset price deflation can encourage households and businesses to over-consume and over-invest.

meanings.definition: a situation in which more money is spent on something than is needed or wise :
examples: It became apparent that there had been over-investment in certain areas of the economy.
Manufacturers persistently overestimated future demand, leading to huge overinvestment.

meanings.definition: a situation in which more time, effort, etc. is used on something or someone than is needed or wise:
examples: Emotional overinvestment is when you focus too much of your thoughts or emotions on a thing or person.
By the end, it's impossible to share in or even comprehend their crazy over-investment in one another.

meanings.definition: a situation in which too much money is invested in a particular activity or economy:
examples: Years of over-investment have left the region with more factories making chips than the global economy can sustain.

meanings.definition: bigger than usual or bigger than necessary:
examples: The boy was sitting up, watching him with dark, over-large eyes.
Unskilled rural migrants left the land, adding to the already overlarge pool of labour in many towns.

meanings.definition: too large in quantity or too expensive :
examples: The government have given sensible rather than over-lavish investment incentives to boost the economy.
There was criticism of a tendency towards overlavish expenditure on the part of some senior executives.

meanings.definition: an over-leveraged person or business has borrowed too much money in relation to their ability to pay it back:
examples: When prices collapsed, many over-leveraged developers went bankrupt.

meanings.definition: too closely based on the exact or basic meaning of something without looking at the wider meaning :
examples: Officials seem preoccupied with an over-literal interpretation of the rules, regardless of the environmental consequences.
The author's style is a little rich for my taste, and the translation is overliteral.

meanings.definition: Over-literary writing or language is too formal or too high-level for the situation. :
examples: Plays do not have to be literary to be good, and indeed, if they are over-literary, they will often fail.
To get to the point where something happens, the audience has had to sit through 45 minutes of dutiful and over-literary exposition.

meanings.definition: to control or organize someone or something too much, especially in business, in a way that is annoying and even harmful :
examples: My impression is that many teachers feel undervalued, under-led, and over-managed.
The easiest trap for a manager to fall into is to overmanage.

meanings.definition: An over-mannered style of speech, writing, or behaviour is very artificial:
examples: Most of the tracks on this album are absurdly overblown, including the somewhat overmannered vocals.
Rather than watching this over-mannered biography of the original domestic goddess, why not cook one of her recipes instead?

meanings.definition: Over-mature plants, vegetables, fruits, etc. have grown beyond their full adult size or the point when they are in their best condition. :
examples: Over-mature trees are liable to lose branches in storms, or through old age or disease.
When overmature, the fruit can become spongy and bitter.

meanings.definition: too large or too powerful, in a way that is harmful to others:
examples: The government is often accused of being over-mighty.
Human errors are often caused by over-mighty egos.

meanings.definition: too unwilling to talk about or recognize your own abilities and achievements :
examples: At the risk of sounding over-modest, how should I know who's right?
He was never overmodest about his achievements, sometimes growing exasperated at the lack of recognition.

meanings.definition: with a lot of muscles that are too developed :
examples: His girlfriend was tall and athletic, bordering on over-muscled.
He is just an overmuscled young kid who is not very bright.

meanings.definition: unhealthy because of eating too much, or too much of the wrong foods :
examples: None of the study participants was considered over-nourished as a child.
Obesity is on the rise in developed countries, perhaps because we are overnourished.

meanings.definition: Something that is over-obvious, especially a work of art, makes its points in a way that is too clear and too strong:
examples: The main defect in this kind of harmony is its tendency to become over-obvious and mechanical.
The period detail is persuasive without, mercifully, being overobvious about it.

meanings.definition: very certain about your beliefs, and expressing your ideas very strongly and often, in a way that can annoy other people:
examples: Most of us are either over-opinionated or under-opinionated.
The book is also a little overopinionated, which is out of place in a textbook.

meanings.definition: the quality of being too full of hope and emphasizing the good parts of a situation too much:
examples: We have lived through countless cycles of over-optimism followed by stark reality and angry retribution.
The foreign minister warned against overoptimism at the prospect of reaching a peace agreement any time soon.

meanings.definition: too full of hope or believing too much that good things will happen in the future :
examples: People are over-optimistic about their retirement, and that's dangerous.
The event made a large loss after overoptimistic forecasts of visitor numbers and entry prices that were too high.

meanings.definition: too hopeful, or too ready to believe that good things will happen in the future:
examples: He fears that analysts are being over-optimistic about future company earnings.
Planning for the project was grossly inadequate and overoptimistic, particularly as regards staffing.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows that you are too full of hope or believe too much that good things will happen in the future :
examples: The painting didn't fetch anything like the price we had over-optimistically hoped for.
Many have come to resent the presence of foreign troops because they overoptimistically thought they would solve the country's problems.

meanings.definition: to organise something too much:
examples: I have to work harder on writing than I do on other things and probably over-organize in compensation.
Do not be tempted to overorganise or regiment a child's life.

meanings.definition: too organised, in a way that can be annoying:
examples: An overlong CV is often an indicator of an overorganized, underachieving candidate.
I found him fussy, over-organised, dogmatic, and a little domineering.

meanings.definition: Over-packaged goods are wrapped in more plastic, paper, and cardboard than is necessary:
examples: When are we going to stop consuming over-packaged junk?
Consumers in the region are prepared to boycott brands they feel are over-packaged.

meanings.definition: Someone who is over-particular is never satisfied and always wants close attention to be given to every detail. :
examples: It was said that he had not been over-particular about the means by which he had acquired his fortune.
He gained a reputation for being demanding, overparticular, and obsessed with details.

meanings.definition: to use too much pedal (= the part of a piano that you press with your foot to make the sound continue) when playing the piano:
examples: Pianists who over-pedal will be suitably punished for bringing the music into disrepute.
As a whole, the performance sounded a bit mushy and overpedalled.

meanings.definition: to plan something in too much detail:
examples: Over many years of solo travelling, I've learned not to overplan, to pack light, and to stay open to adventure.
In the past few decades, arts policy has been overplanned and over-regulated.

meanings.definition: to plant too many plants, or too many of a particular plant:
examples: I tend to overplant, because I like the feeling of profusion.
They would over-plant an area and then remove trees that were not performing well.

meanings.definition: to plant one type of plant on top of a different type of plant:
examples: Don't forget to over-plant tulips with wallflowers.
A permanent clump of allium is overplanted with the crimson-flowered broad bean.

meanings.definition: too exact and accurate, when this is not necessary :
examples: Rewatching these old movie stars, we are struck by their florid gestures and over-precise diction.
The analysis is overprecise, and I think unpersuasive.

meanings.definition: the problem of doctors giving people drugs to treat medical conditions too often, or when it is not necessary :

meanings.definition: too simple or easy:

meanings.definition: in a way that is too simple or easy:

examples: We cannot overestimate the importance of this work.
The benefits of nuclear technology, she said, had been grossly overestimated.

meanings.definition: to think that someone is stronger, or more skilful, intelligent, or determined than they really are:
examples: They were forced to the conclusion that they had overestimated him.

meanings.definition: a guess that is too high in amount:
examples: The shortfall was caused by an overestimate of revenue last year.
Experts put remaining tiger numbers at somewhere between 5,000 and 7,000, although this could be an overestimate.

meanings.definition: to think that something is or will be greater, more extreme, or more important than it really is:
examples: I’m afraid Theresa is forever overestimating her strength.

meanings.definition: to think that something is or will be greater or more important than it really is:
examples: I think we have grossly overestimated the pace of growth.
Most people overestimate what they can achieve in a day and underestimate what they can achieve in a year.
Assess your potential earnings honestly - don't overestimate.

meanings.definition: to think that someone is better at doing something, more intelligent, etc. than they really are:
examples: I thought they would pick it up very quickly, but I overestimated them.

meanings.definition: an opinion that something is larger or more important than it really is:
examples: Experts put the figure at $6 million, though this may be an overestimate.

meanings.definition:

         overestimate
to guess an amount that is too high or a size that is too big:
examples: I overestimated and there was a lot of food left over after the party.
Most of us overestimate how much time and energy we have.
According to the survey, agents frequently overestimate the size of rooms.

meanings.definition: to think that something is better or more important than it really is:
examples: We cannot overestimate the importance of this work.
The benefits of nuclear technology, she said, had been grossly overestimated.

examples: They were forced to the conclusion that they had overestimated him.

meanings.definition: to think that someone is stronger, or more skilful, intelligent, or determined than they really are:
examples: They were forced to the conclusion that they had overestimated him.

meanings.definition: a guess that is too high or too big, or the act of making such a guess:
examples: The reporting error led to an over-estimation of the number of cases of the disease.
Overestimation of damage is common with insurance claims.

meanings.definition: a judgment that something is better or more important than it really is:
examples: They admitted an initial overestimation of the benefits of the scheme.
She suffers from a poor understanding of the game combined with an over-estimation of her own ability.

meanings.definition: the act of judging or calculating the quality, importance, amount, or value of something to be greater than it really is:
examples: We are victims of an over-evaluation of the attributes of physical beauty, which leads society to prize them above all else.
Overevaluation of assets caused a global financial crisis.

meanings.definition: to make something seem a lot larger, more important, better, or worse than it really is:
examples: I'd say that she tends to overexaggerate rather than that she lies.
You can't over-exaggerate the significance of the election result.

meanings.definition: a statement that suggests something is a lot larger, more important, better, or worse than it really is:
examples: It's not an over-exaggeration to say that they are on the poverty line.
Her account of the event was taken very seriously, as she is not known for overexaggeration.

meanings.definition: to excite someone or something too much:
examples: Try not to overexcite the children just before their bedtime.
Stress can over-excite the brain, clouding our thoughts.

meanings.definition: too happy and enthusiastic:
examples: I get absurdly overexcited at Christmas.
The theme park was full of over-excited children.

meanings.definition: too active:
examples: The drug is thought to reduce pain by calming overexcited nerve cells.
You may be followed down the street by a swarm of over-excited bees.

meanings.definition: to make too much mental or physical effort, or to cause a person or an animal to do this:
examples: Horse owners should be careful not to overexert their ponies.
Overexerting mentally or physically can exacerbate symptoms.

meanings.definition: the use of too much mental or physical effort:
examples: After two heart attacks and a bypass operation, he's trying to avoid overexertion.
The panic attack was brought on by her over-exertions during the show.

meanings.definition: to increase too much in size, number, or importance, or to make something increase too much in this way:
examples: If you hold your breath, air can trap in the lungs and the lungs will over-expand.
Many tech companies overexpanded as home working increased, and will now face job losses.
She overexpanded the company's operations in Germany.

meanings.definition: more clear and exact than is necessary or helpful:
examples: The dialogue in this scene is over-explicit in a way that it is not in the rest of the film.
The song makes over-explicit what would be more subtly expressed through metaphor.

meanings.definition: showing or talking about sex, violence, etc. in a way that is too detailed :
examples: She accepts that some people think her costumes are overexplicit, but prefers the word 'sexy' to 'raunchy'.
over-explicit TV documentaries about surgery

meanings.definition: to make someone or something experience something too much, or for too long, risking harm:
examples: He is another employee who was regularly overexposed to lead, arsenic, and cadmium in his 26 years at the plant.

meanings.definition: to give too much attention to someone or something in newspapers, on television, on social media, etc.:
examples: His parents and his team protected him from being overexposed, keeping him from doing interviews and turning down endorsement deals.

meanings.definition: to give too much light to a piece of photographic film when taking a photograph:
examples: Unfortunately the light was too bright and my pictures were all overexposed.
Since my camera allows me to preset exposure above and below the automatic reading, I typically overexpose my shots by one f-stop.

meanings.definition: If a photograph is overexposed, too much light was allowed to reach the piece of photographic film when taking it:
examples: Many of the show's paintings give the impression of overexposed photographs.
Light can leak in and leave some photographs over-exposed.

meanings.definition: having been given too much attention in newspapers, on television, on social media, etc.:
examples: Some young hip-hop artists today are probably overexposed.
The actor was so overexposed that most of the country was tired of reading about her.

meanings.definition: having experienced something too much, or for too long, risking harm:
examples: The insecticides were widely used in farming, and the overexposed mosquitoes quickly became resistant to the chemicals in them.
Parents are concerned about young brains being overexposed to the radio waves emitted by phones.

meanings.definition: having too much of a particular type of investment, financial product, etc., so that you risk losing money:
examples: By the end of the 1980s, many UK banks were overexposed to overseas lending risks.
Most regional US banks are very overexposed in real estate.

meanings.definition: the fact of experiencing something or being affected by it because of being in a particular situation or place for too long:
examples: A child's development can be irreversibly stunted by overexposure to lead.
They were concerned about their children's overexposure to violence.

meanings.definition: the fact of a person, event, or information appearing or being discussed too much in newspapers, on the television, on social media, etc.:
examples: He worries about overexposure and how his friends will react to his new level of fame.
The show died a sudden death from overexposure after ABC decided to air it four nights a week.

meanings.definition: the fact of a piece of film being in the light for too long when a photograph is being taken:
examples: He rescued the photo from overexposure and processed it in his darkroom.
The photographs were partially bleached by overexposure.

meanings.definition: to spend too much money, or borrow more money than you can pay back:
examples: It is a sad fact that many people overextended their mortgage commitments and now face difficulties.
Borrowers overextend themselves in refinancing to cover unforeseen expenses.

meanings.definition: to try to do more work or other activities than you can manage:
examples: The fear of failure can lead young people to overextend themselves.
He rejects opportunities that he thinks would overextend the firm's resources.

meanings.definition: having spent too much money, or borrowed more money than you can pay back:
examples: Typically, it is people in their late 30s with mortgage commitments who find themselves overextended.
He predicted that the nation's overextended banks would start to fail.

meanings.definition: having more work or other activities than you can manage:
examples: The survey showed dads feel overextended and underappreciated.

meanings.definition: an area of very rough water caused by a raised area in the ground under the water, or by the meeting of two currents (= movements of water in a particular direction):
examples: The water can throw up great overfalls, which small boats should try to avoid.

meanings.definition:
US spelling of
        
         over-favour
having been given too much food :
examples: An overfed horse which has too little exercise is likely to be over-excited.
They are not malnourished, but they are certainly not overfed.

meanings.definition: to give a person or animal too much food:
examples: Many owners accidentally overfeed their pets.
It's difficult to overfeed a breast-fed baby.

meanings.definition: the practice of giving a person or animal too much food:
examples: Many parents mistake overfeeding for love.
Even slight overfeeding can lead to unpleasant digestive outcomes.

meanings.definition: catching too many fish in an area of the sea, so that there are not many fish left there:
examples: low fish stocks caused by overfishing

meanings.definition: an occasion when an aircraft flies over a place:
examples: Residents campaigned to reduce airline overflights in the area.
An overflight after the hurricane revealed a shocking level of damage.

meanings.definition: When a liquid overflows, it flows over the edges of a container, etc. because there is too much of it:
examples: The milk overflowed when I poured it into the jug.
Because of heavy rain, the river may overflow its banks.

meanings.definition: If a container or a place overflows, whatever is inside it starts coming out because it is too full:
examples: Oh no, the sink is overflowing all over the floor.
The bin was overflowing with rubbish.

meanings.definition: When a place overflows, or people or things overflow from somewhere, some people or things have to come out because it cannot contain them all:
examples: The bar was so full that people were overflowing into/onto the street.
His room is overflowing with books.
The train was full to overflowing (= so full that there was not space for any more passengers).

meanings.definition: If you overflow with thoughts or feelings, you express them strongly:
examples: They were overflowing with emotion at the birth of their baby.
Suddenly, her anger overflowed.

meanings.definition: an amount of liquid or number of people that cannot fit in a space:
examples: I put a bucket underneath to catch the overflow from the water tank.
We can't cope with this overflow of patients from the other hospitals.

meanings.definition: a pipe that carries away water that is not needed
(of a liquid) to flow over the edges of a container because there is too much, or to contain more of something than can be held:
examples: Because of the heavy rains, the river overflowed its banks.
The sink quickly overflowed, flooding the room.
The train platform was overflowing with passengers.
