meanings.definition: too much attention given to one particular person, subject, or thing :
examples: He warns against an over-focus on punishment rather than rehabilitation.
She questioned why there had been the huge overfocus on uniform policy.

meanings.definition: to give too much attention to one particular person, subject, or thing:
examples: We don't believe you can over-focus on this problem.
It is not healthy for patients to overfocus on their therapist.

meanings.definition: to do even more than what is expected, hoped for, or promised:
examples: We will fulfil our obligations to the very end, but we are not over-fulfilling them.
They are a successful business, always striving to overfulfil the expectations of their clients.

meanings.definition:
US spelling of 
        
         overfulfil
to provide more money to pay for an event, activity, or organization than is necessary:
examples: If we don't spend the entire budget, the government may decide that the program was overfunded.
Companies don't like to over-fund pension plans because there is no access to the money once it's inside a plan.

meanings.definition: having or receiving more money than is necessary or allowed:
examples: Some local companies are sitting on overfunded pension plans, while others are putting lots of money in funds that have too few assets.

meanings.definition: the act of providing or receiving more money than is needed or allowed for a particular purpose, organization, etc.:
examples: Some departments may, through overfunding, be absorbing an unfair amount of scarce resources.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         over-leveraged
a written or spoken statement in which you say or write that something is true all of the time when it is only true some of the time, or the use of such statements:
examples: It is an overgeneralisation to say that he never helps in the house.
Perceptions of the religion have suffered from overgeneralization.

meanings.definition: a way of thinking in which someone expects something negative to happen in all situations because of a previous negative experience :
examples: There may be overgeneralisation of a fear to situations that resemble the original traumatic situation.

meanings.definition: the use of a rule of language in situations where it does not need to be used, or the incorrect use of a word to refer to a similar, but different, thing :
examples: Overgeneralization is what makes a learner produce the ungrammatical form "goed" instead of the correct form "went".
In the early stages of word learning, overgeneralisation often occurs, when a child uses the wrong word to name an object.

meanings.definition: to say or write that something is true all of the time, when it is only true some of the time:
examples: It's important not to overgeneralize about people in this age group.
I really believe he tends to overgeneralise in this article.

meanings.definition: the quality of being more generous than is helpful or necessary:
examples: They met to agree a settlement intended to correct the over-generosity of the previous deal.
Their over-generosity with their younger child caused jealousy amongst her older siblings.

meanings.definition: to control and direct the public business of a country, city, group of people, etc. more than is helpful or necessary:
examples: Poor farmers in the region have been over-governed for centuries.
He has a tendency to micromanage and overgovern, creating an unhealthy work environment.

meanings.definition: to eat too much grass in an area or to have too many animals eating grass in an area, which damages the environment:
examples: The pasture land had little grass on it, indicating that it had been overgrazed.
We can keep two ponies in the field, as long as they don't overgraze it.

meanings.definition: a situation in which there are too many cows or other animals eating grass in an area, which damages the environment:
examples: Another problem is erosion of stream banks caused by overgrazing.

meanings.definition: above the surface of the earth:
examples: It's much better to put cables overground than underground.
After a couple of hours, the many underground and overground streams began to look like a river.
Many of the Tube's usual three million daily users switched to the roads and overground trains or walked.

meanings.definition: An overground activity is not secret or illegal, or is accepted by most people:
examples: Illicit operators are connecting with overground businesses where money can be laundered.
Once a scene goes overground, the people who started it often lose interest.

meanings.definition: covered with plants that are growing thickly and in an uncontrolled way:
examples: The field is overgrown with weeds.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that has grown too large:
examples: Cottonwood has become an overgrown town with inadequate facilities.

meanings.definition: used to describe an adult who behaves like a child:
examples: They're acting like overgrown kids.
Jim is just an overgrown schoolboy.

meanings.definition: having a thick, dense covering of plants growing in a wild way:
examples: The playground is overgrown with weeds.

meanings.definition: (of people) grown large or too large:
examples: Even Professor Adams looked like an overgrown schoolboy beside him.

meanings.definition: (especially of a throw) made with the arm moving above the shoulder:
examples: an overhand throw/serve
Throw it overhand.

meanings.definition: (esp. of a throw) made with the hand and part or all of the arm moving above the shoulder:
examples: an overhand pitch
Throw the ball overhand.

meanings.definition: to stick out over something at a lower level:
examples: Several large trees overhang the path.

meanings.definition: to have a negative effect on a situation:
examples: Overhanging the controversy is the question of how much the administration knew about the arms deal.

meanings.definition: the part of a rock or roof that sticks out over something below:
examples: The church is unsafe because it was built on an overhang.

meanings.definition: something that has a negative effect on a situation:
examples: Prices are unlikely to increase while there is an overhang of 40,000 unsold new houses.
Latin America's current debt overhang

meanings.definition: (of something at a high level) to stick out farther than something at a lower level and therefore not to have any support from below, or to hang over:
examples: The balcony overhangs the patio, creating a shady place to sit.

meanings.definition: a quantity of goods or other things that have not been sold when they should have been:
examples: We're about to enter the selling season with a really big supply overhang.
Prices are unlikely to increase while there is an overhang of 40,000 unsold new houses.

meanings.definition: a situation on a stock market in which a quantity of shares is available but not sold, reducing their price:
examples: The potential overhang of more than 200 million shares of stock is one of a number of financial and legal risks that investors in the company face.

meanings.definition: to bring down the price of something because there is too much of it available:
examples: Massive gold stocks continue to overhang the market, traders say.

meanings.definition: sticking out over something that is at a lower level:
examples: the overhanging branches of a tree
He glanced up at the overhanging rocks.

meanings.definition: to collect too much of a crop, plant, animal, or fish to eat, so that there is not enough left :
examples: We need to be careful that we don't overharvest this precious resource.
Wild turtles have been over-harvested for food, medicine, or as pets.

meanings.definition: to repair an engine, machine, etc. so that every part of it works as it should:
examples: I got the engine overhauled.

meanings.definition: to completely change a system so that it works more effectively:
examples: The government has recently overhauled the healthcare system.
The school chose to overhaul its curriculum by equipping classrooms with new technology.

meanings.definition: to completely change something, especially by getting rid of some people or things and replacing them with others:
examples: Most women don't overhaul their wardrobes from season to season.
The restaurant has overhauled its menu, cutting portions and eliminating items with lots of calories.

meanings.definition: the act of repairing an engine, machine, etc. so that every part works as it should:
examples: I took my motorbike in for an overhaul.
Our gas turbine division is now a world market leader in the repair and overhaul of industrial gas turbines.

meanings.definition: the act of completely changing a system so that it works more effectively:
examples: They announced plans for a radical overhaul of the country's political system.
Such changes call for an overhaul of the way Britain runs air travel.

meanings.definition: the act of completely changing something, especially by getting rid of some people or things and replacing them with others:
examples: There is likely to be a major overhaul of the squad this summer.

meanings.definition: to repair or improve something so it works well:
examples: They repaired and maintained aircraft and overhauled their engines.
Congressional leaders are considering overhauling the Clean Air Act.

meanings.definition: to repair or improve something so that every part of it works as it should:
examples: The government plans to overhaul bank regulations.
The network has been overhauled and upgraded.
I got the engine overhauled.
The new CEO's mandate from the board had been to overhaul the company from top to bottom.

meanings.definition: the act of repairing or improving something so that every part of it works as it should:
examples: The firm's organizational infrastructure needed a major overhaul.
Critics of the overhaul argued that yesterday's changes were only cosmetic improvements.

meanings.definition: above your head, usually in the sky:

This room needs overhead lighting (= lights in the ceiling).

meanings.definition: relating to the overheads of a business:
examples: One way of increasing profit margins is to cut overhead costs.

meanings.definition: in sports played with a racket, hit from above head height:
examples: The winning shot was an overhead smash at the net.
Squash has fewer overhead shots than other racket sports.

meanings.definition: in sports such as basketball, thrown from above head height :
examples: She set up the score with a two-handed overhead pass to Donnelly.

meanings.definition: a transparent sheet used for showing text or pictures with an overhead projector
at a level higher than a person’s head; in the air or the sky above the place where you are:
examples: overhead lighting

meanings.definition: the regular and necessary costs, such as rent, heat, electricity, and telephone, involved in operating a business:
examples: overhead expenses

a device that makes large images from a flat, transparent sheet and shows them on a white screen or wall
a piece of equipment that shines images from a flat transparent sheet onto a white screen or wall:

meanings.definition: the regular and necessary costs, such as rent and heating, that are involved in operating a business:
examples: The combined company aims to reduce annual overheads by as much as £2 billion.
Many big companies have been hit by high overheads and falling sales.
low/small/reduced overheads
In an early restructuring move, the company is shutting stores and cutting administrative overheads.
The merger cut overhead costs in half.

meanings.definition: to hear what other people are saying without intending to and without their knowledge:
examples: I overheard a very funny conversation on the bus this morning.
He overheard his daughter telling her doll not to be so naughty.
We overheard them say that they didn't really like the food.
I'm sorry, I couldn't help overhearing.

meanings.definition: to hear what other people are saying unintentionally and without their knowledge:
examples: I overheard a funny conversation on the bus this morning.
They were so loud, I couldn’t help overhearing.

meanings.definition: to (cause to) become hotter than necessary or wanted:
examples: I think the engine is overheating.
It isn't healthy to overheat your house.

meanings.definition: If an economy overheats, it grows very quickly, so that prices, etc. increase quickly.
if an economy or market overheats, it grows too quickly, causing inflation and other problems:
examples: Excessive liquidity is causing the economy to overheat.
The property market has overheated dramatically in the past 12 months.

meanings.definition: If a situation is/gets overheated, strong feelings, especially anger, are expressed:
examples: Things got a little overheated at the meeting.

meanings.definition: too much very fast growth in an economy, with the result that prices increase too quickly:
examples: The central bank has raised interest rates in an attempt to prevent overheating and recession.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of
        
         overhang
to catch and kill too many of a particular type of animal or bird, so that there are not enough left :
examples: Did mammoths go extinct because humans over-hunted them?
Leatherback turtles were listed as endangered after being overhunted for their eggs and for human consumption.

meanings.definition: the problem of catching and killing too many of a particular type of animal or bird, so that there are not enough left:
examples: Larger, long-lived, slow-breeding animals are more susceptible to overhunting than other animals.
Sixty years ago, grey whale numbers were down to a few hundred because of over-hunting.

meanings.definition: to advertise or discuss something in newspapers, on television, etc. too much, so that it seems bigger or better than it really is:
examples: He believes the threat has been over-hyped and that people need to continue with their normal lives.
I hate to overhype, so I recommend you try it for yourself.

meanings.definition: to advertise or praise something more than it deserves in newspapers, on television, online, etc., in order to make people excited about it and want to buy, try it, invest in it, etc.:
examples: People wondered aloud whether the company had been overhyped.
Probably only one in 20 of these stocks will retain their present over-hyped levels.

meanings.definition: Something that is overhyped is advertised or discussed in newspapers, on television, etc. too much, so that it seems better than it really is:
examples: In my opinion, the company's products are overpriced and overhyped.
This has to be the most over-hyped film of all time.

meanings.definition: to allow yourself to have too much of something enjoyable, especially food or drink:
examples: I wish I hadn't overindulged so much last night.
Some people regularly overindulge in alcohol.

meanings.definition: to allow someone to have more of something enjoyable than is good for them:
examples: Arthur obsessively tried being the opposite of his father by overindulging his eldest son.
It's not good for children to be overindulged.

meanings.definition: behaviour in which you allow yourself to have too much of something enjoyable, especially food or drink:
examples: For many Americans, Thanksgiving is a time of overindulgence.
Overindulgence in food and drink is a big danger for those who live alone.

meanings.definition: behaviour in which you allow someone to have more of something enjoyable than is good for them:
examples: Her father thought he had to be mean, to counteract her mother's overindulgence.

examples: Try not to overreact to criticism.

meanings.definition:
present participle of

to react in an extreme, especially an angry or frightened, way:
examples: Try not to overreact to criticism.

meanings.definition: the action of reacting in an extreme, especially an angry or frightened, way:

meanings.definition: to say that you have done, earned, sold, etc. more than you really have:
examples: When preparing your taxes, don’t overreport capital gains or underreport capital losses.

meanings.definition:
past participle of 
        
         override
(of a person who has the necessary authority) to decide against or refuse to accept a previous decision, an order, a person, etc.:
examples: Every time I make a suggestion at work, my boss overrides me/it.
The president used his veto to override the committee's decision.

meanings.definition: to operate an automatic machine by hand:
examples: He overrode the autopilot when he realized it was malfunctioning.

meanings.definition: to take control over something, especially in order to change the way it operates:
examples: The pills are designed to override your body's own hormones.

meanings.definition: to be more important than something:
examples: Parents' concern for their children's future often overrides all their other concerns.

meanings.definition: to travel on public transport further than your ticket allows you to:
examples: There is a $20 penalty for passengers who travel without a ticket or override.

meanings.definition: a device that changes the control of a machine or system in special situations, especially from automatic to manual:
examples: The heating system has a manual override.

meanings.definition: in American politics, an occasion when an elected group of people refuses to accept a decision made by an elected leader:
examples: The vote fell short of the majority needed for an override of the Governor's veto.

meanings.definition: to ignore or refuse to accept a suggestion, idea, or method that already exists or operates:
examples: The legislature voted to override the presidential veto.

meanings.definition: to refuse to accept or to decide against a previous decision or order:
examples: It takes a two-thirds vote of the House and Senate to override the governor's veto.
Every time I make a suggestion at work, my boss overrides me.

meanings.definition: to be more important than something else:
examples: The common good, he argued, overrode minority interests.

meanings.definition: to stop a machine operating automatically, and control it yourself:
examples: He overrode the autopilot when he realised it was malfunctioning.

meanings.definition: a vote or a decision that ends or changes an earlier law or decision:
examples: The city council voted in favor of a tax override.

meanings.definition: a way of changing the control of a machine or system in special situations, especially from automatic to control by a person:
examples: The heating system has a manual override.

meanings.definition: If unwanted people or things overrun, they fill a place quickly and in large numbers:
examples: Rebel soldiers overran the embassy last night.
Our kitchen is overrun with cockroaches.

meanings.definition: to continue past an intended limit, especially a finishing time or a cost:
examples: My evening class overran by ten minutes.
It looks as if we're going to overrun our budget.

meanings.definition: a finishing time or a cost that continues past an intended limit:
examples: The project was plagued by cost overruns and delays.
Politicians, facing budget overruns, continue to cut spending.

meanings.definition: to spread over an area quickly and in large numbers:
examples: The city has become increasingly unpleasant because it is overrun with tourists.

meanings.definition: to continue past an agreed or expected limit, especially a finishing time or a cost:
examples: Analysts say the cost of the improvements are bound to overrun.
The 45 minutes allocated for the briefing overran by almost 30 minutes.

meanings.definition: the fact that something has cost more money or taken more time than planned, or the additional amount of money or time spent:
examples: He expects the department to cover this year's overrun by moving money from development.
We found projects had an average time overrun of 17%.

examples: The Air Force was recalling troops from overseas bases.

meanings.definition: to sell more than is available:

meanings.definition: to go further than what is considered acceptable or correct:

meanings.definition: to behave in a completely unacceptable way:
examples: You've overstepped the mark this time, Simpson - you're fired!

meanings.definition: to make someone too excited or interested in something:
examples: In some people the drug may even have the unexpected effect of overstimulating instead of sedating.
It is important not to overstimulate children just before bedtime.

meanings.definition: to have too great an effect on the growth, development, or activity of something :
examples: Policymakers need to be careful not to overstimulate the economy when an oil shock hits.
Too much fear can overstimulate our imagination: we jump at every creaking floorboard, until it becomes impossible to relax.

meanings.definition: to cause a part of the body to produce too much of a particular substance or have too great an effect on a process :
examples: According to some experts, dairy products can overstimulate the ovaries to produce more oestrogen.

meanings.definition: too excited or interested in something:
examples: Children become so overstimulated by heavy schedules of activities that they can't sleep at night.
In our electronic age we are overstimulated, overworked and yet somehow under-skilled.

meanings.definition: made to grow or develop too much, or to be too active:
examples: In our current overstimulated society that is so mechanical and industrial, there is a hunger for high-level, human-crafted products.
They argue that modern racial discrimination is an overstimulated response to what might be called an "alliance" detector in the human brain.

meanings.definition: producing too much of a particular substance or having too great an effect on a process:
examples: The pancreas becomes overstimulated and produces too much insulin.
With lupus, an overstimulated immune system attacks the body.

meanings.definition: making someone too excited or interested in something:
examples: Kids have grown up in such a noisy, overstimulating situation that they really don't know how to have a quiet mind.
She continues to find inspiration in the crazy, overstimulating tangle that is Mexico City.

meanings.definition: the fact of being made too excited or interested in something, or a situation in which someone feels like this:
examples: Avoid caffeine, daytime napping, and overstimulation in the evening to aid sleeplessness.
She turned to escape the overstimulation, but the crowd of people made her passage difficult.

meanings.definition: the fact of having too great an effect on the growth, development, or activity of something:
examples: Such overstimulation of the economy risks taking us into higher rates of inflation.

meanings.definition: the act of causing a part of the body to produce too much of a particular substance or have too great an effect on a process:
examples: Overstimulation of the adrenal gland interferes with cortical levels.

meanings.definition: to (cause to) have more goods or supplies than are needed:

meanings.definition: to spend or borrow more money than you can pay:

meanings.definition: If something is oversubscribed, people still want to buy things, especially shares or tickets, although all of them are already sold:

meanings.definition: if a share issue (= occasion on which new shares are sold) is oversubscribed, people want to buy more shares than are available:

meanings.definition: a greater supply of something than is needed:

meanings.definition: to defeat someone completely or be much better than him or her; to perform extremely well:
examples: Last time we played them, we owned them!
Beyoncé owned that stage tonight!

meanings.definition: to accept and be responsible for something:
examples: It's your life - own it.
I own who I was, and so I’m always open to admitting fault and talking through it.

meanings.definition:

         anything  :
examples: I haven't heard owt about it.
Is there owt to drink?

meanings.definition: a bull (= male cow) that has had its reproductive organs removed, used in the past for pulling heavy things on farms, or, more generally, any adult of the cattle family
an adult animal of the cattle family, esp. a male that has had its sexual organs removed
used to describe a vehicle or piece of farm equipment that is pulled by an ox (= a male cow):
examples: an ox-drawn cart/plough

meanings.definition: a tall plant that grows in grass, with flowers that have white petals and a yellow centre:
examples: Meadows bloom with ox-eye daisies, ragged robin, campion, and cranesbill.
Tennessee has oxeye daisies on its list of invasive plants and wants to be rid of them.
He has made an ox-eye daisy puree, which is served with new potatoes.

meanings.definition: a plant that has heart-shaped leaves and pale flowers and sometimes grows in gardens as a weed (= a plant that is not wanted):
examples: We saw a lot of oxalis when we visited Crete.
I spent all afternoon pulling out oxalis from the flower beds.

meanings.definition: a curved lake that was originally a bend in a river but became separated when the river took a new, straighter course
the universities of Oxford and Cambridge, considered as a unit separate from other universities in Britain:
examples: Many members of the British government went to Oxbridge (= a college at either Oxford or Cambridge).

meanings.definition: belonging or relating to the universities of Oxford and Cambridge:
examples: She's an Oxbridge student.
He's very Oxbridge in his manner (= behaves as if he went to a college in Oxford or Cambridge).

meanings.definition:
plural of 
        
         ox

a UK-based organization that works to help people who are extremely poor and suffering by, among other things, collecting old clothes and other unwanted things and selling them at low prices in special shops
a city in south east England, famous for its university
a type of fairly formal man's shoe, usually made of leather, that fastens with laces
trousers with a wide and loose style:
examples: She was wearing a pink shirt and khaki Oxford bags.
It's fashionable to wear Oxford bags and flat shoes this season.
His latest collection features white Oxford bags.
The trousers were similar in width to a pair of Oxford bags.

meanings.definition: a man's shirt made of a particular type of heavy cotton cloth
a county (= area with its own local government) in central England:
examples: Bicester Village is in Oxfordshire, an hour from London.

meanings.definition: the process of a substance or chemical element oxidizing:
examples: Sulfuric acid vapor is a product of the oxidation of sulfur compounds from marine algae.

meanings.definition: the process by which iron and steel rust
Oxidation is also the chemical process by which an atom or group of atoms loses electrons.
An oxidative chemical reaction adds oxygen to the tissues of the body:
examples: oxidative damage
Stress cardiomyopathy is associated with increased oxidative stress.

meanings.definition: a chemical combination of oxygen and one other element:
examples: iron oxide
an oxide of copper

meanings.definition: a chemical combination of oxygen and one other element:
examples: nitrogen/iron oxide

meanings.definition: the process of a substance or chemical element oxidizing:
examples: Oxidization has turned the rocks bright mauve, ochre, green, turquoise, and purple.

meanings.definition: If a substance oxidizes, it combines with oxygen and loses hydrogen to form another substance, and if something oxidizes a substance, it causes it to do this:
examples: Iron oxidizes to form rust.
When you heat fat, it oxidizes easily.

meanings.definition: If a chemical element oxidizes, it loses electrons (= very small pieces of matter with negative electrical charge) and if you oxidize it, you cause it to do this.
to react with oxygen and rust
Oxidize also means to cause an atom or group of atoms to lose electrons during a chemical reaction.

examples: Iron oxidizes to form rust.

If a substance oxidizes, it combines with oxygen and loses hydrogen to form another substance, and if something oxidizes a substance, it causes it to do this:
examples: Iron oxidizes to form rust.
When you heat fat, it oxidizes easily.

meanings.definition: If a chemical element oxidizes, it loses electrons (= very small pieces of matter with negative electrical charge) and if you oxidize it, you cause it to do this.
a device, usually attached to the end of a person's finger, used to measure the level of oxygen in their blood :
examples: Since the oximeter amplifies the pulse signal, it will pick up a complete loss of a pulse, but not significant decreases.
Before induction of anaesthesia, the baby should have an oximeter probe taped on the right hand.

meanings.definition: the activity of measuring the level of oxygen in someone's blood using a special device, usually attached to their finger:
examples: Oximetry was carried out in 87 normal healthy children.
Oximetry is not as accurate as the measurement of arterial blood gases.

meanings.definition: a wild plant of the primula family with several small, pale yellow flowers growing together on a long stem:
examples: The ground was covered in primroses, oxlips, cowslips, and violets.
Protesters claim that the oxlip is threatened by the airport expansion.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Oxfordshire: used when writing addresses:
examples: Chalgrove Field, Oxon

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Oxford: used after someone's name and qualifications to show that they have a degree from Oxford University:
examples: Rebecca Cox, MA (Oxon) (= she has a Master of Arts degree from Oxford)

meanings.definition: meat from the tail of an ox, or the tail itself:
examples: oxtail soup
I bought an oxtail to make some soup.

meanings.definition: a person's armpit (= the hollow place under your arm where your arm joins your body )
a mixture of oxygen and acetylene (= a gas) that produces a hot bright flame, and that can be used for cutting metal:
examples: an oxyacetylene lamp/torch

meanings.definition: a strong drug that reduces pain and is related to codeine:
examples: oxycodone addiction

meanings.definition: a chemical element that is a gas with no smell or colour. Oxygen forms a large part of the air on earth, and is needed by animals and plants to live.
a colorless gas, one of the chemical elements, that forms a large part of the air on earth and is needed to keep most living things alive and to create fire
a place where you pay to breathe pure oxygen in order to improve your health and help you relax
the extra oxygen that the body uses during exercise, which must be replaced when resting
a piece of equipment that can be put over a person's nose and mouth to supply them with oxygen
a container with oxygen inside it, used for helping people to breathe, for example when they are very ill, or when they are diving underwater
a clear covering put over the head and upper body of a person who is ill to provide oxygen to help them breathe
to add oxygen to something:
examples: Fish tanks often have a pump which oxygenates the water.

meanings.definition: to get oxygen into a substance

to add oxygen to something:
examples: Fish tanks often have a pump which oxygenates the water.

to add oxygen to something:

meanings.definition: the process of adding oxygen to something:
examples: Oxygenation of the blood is a key function of the lungs.

meanings.definition: the bright red form of haemoglobin (= substance in red blood cells) that contains oxygen
the bright red form of hemoglobin (= substance in red blood cells) that contains oxygen
the bright red form of hemoglobin (= substance in red blood cells) that contains oxygen and gives blood its bright red color
two words or phrases used together that have, or seem to have, opposite meanings:
examples: The very notion of an entrepreneurial company man is an oxymoron.
For most of the nineteenth century, scholars treated “medieval science” as an oxymoron.

meanings.definition: a phrase or statement that seems to say two opposite things, as in "jumbo shrimp" and "agree to disagree"
(of two words used together) having, or seeming to have, opposite meanings:
examples: Cultural tourism is close to being an oxymoronic phrase.
It might sound oxymoronic but there is such a thing as an interesting utility.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to two words or ideas that are used together, but have, or seem to have, opposite meanings :
examples: The organization oxymoronically describes itself as "an independent company funded by the government".
Mob Street was deserted and must be America's most oxymoronically named thoroughfare.

meanings.definition: a hormone that helps with labour (= the process of pushing out a baby) and helps women and female mammals to produce milk

another spelling of 
        
         oi
a Yiddish exclamation used when someone is upset, shocked, disappointed, worried, etc.:
examples: When she speaks of her children, she rubs her face and sighs, "Oy."

meanings.definition: a large flat sea creature that lives in a shell, some types of which can be eaten either cooked or uncooked, and other types of which produce pearls (= small round white precious stones)
one of two small pieces of chicken at the bottom of the backbone, which taste particularly good:
examples: Chicken oysters are those juicy little chicken pieces hidden away between the leg and the backbone.

meanings.definition: a water creature that grows within a shell, some types of which can be eaten, and other types of which produce pearls (= small, round, white stones used in jewelry)
a restaurant, or part of a restaurant, where mainly oysters are served:
examples: Whitby's oldest oyster bar serves glistening oysters in unpretentious surroundings.
The stylish Number Thirty Three has an oyster bar and à la carte restaurant.

meanings.definition: a place on the bottom of the sea where oysters breed:
examples: Each island provides opportunities for fishing its respective oyster bars.
The mouths of the south rivers are defined by massive oyster bars.

meanings.definition: an area at the bottom of the sea where oysters live
a small plastic card that can be used as a method of payment on buses, trains, and the underground in London
small, round, dry pieces of bread that are crunchy (= make a noise when eaten), served especially with some types of fish soup:
examples: Serve the chowder in large soup bowls with oyster crackers on the side.
This simple oyster stew can be served with oyster crackers for a quick lunch.

meanings.definition: a type of mushroom that looks similar to an oyster and grows on some trees:
examples: Main courses included filo tartlet filled with creamed oyster mushrooms, spinach, and goat's cheese.
In the wild, oyster mushrooms are primary decomposers of newly dead trees.

meanings.definition: a black-and-white bird with long legs and a long red beak that lives on the coast and eats mainly shellfish (= sea creatures that live in shells)
a dish of oysters (= large flat sea creatures that have a shell) cooked on half of a shell with butter, herbs, and a covering of very small pieces of bread:
examples: The restaurant is famous for its oysters Rockefeller.
He ordered the oysters Rockefeller.
The oysters Rockefeller were bursting with flavour.

air that is clean and pleasant to breathe, especially near the sea

An ozone-friendly product does not produce gases that are harmful to the ozone layer:
examples: ozone-friendly packaging
an ozone-friendly refrigerator

meanings.definition: used to describe a product that does not produce gases that are harmful to the ozone layer:
examples: We now use only ozone-friendly packaging.
The company produces ozone-friendly refrigerators.
